number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												I really enjoyed the story of the game, it's definitely got adult themes but they're not shoe-horned in there to be edgy or shocking, it has to be there with the story being told. It's got some fantastic ideas in there, I was skeptical about the main character however, but it may be me being a bit picky because of the range of quality in the voice acting that sometimes hit or missed for me. A couple of scenes or conversations made me think that maybe some lines needed re-writing but in truth, that's my only problem with the writing here. Susan Ashworth, as a character, as much as it pains me to say this, was not someone I as rooting for but I'm being picky. I did on a few occassions say outloud to my laptop "Why aren't you saying this?!" I'll refrine from plot spoilers but, as it is with every adventure game with a dialouge option, they won't say the bleeding obvious. A lot of hard work has gone into this and I can see that in the characters and level design. I just wish the quality of mics were even across the board, it sounds like some people did either their lines over skype or right before they went to bed.The game play is around puzzles and logical/lateral thinking and there were a few I were stuck on but as I don't play a lot of them, I was surprised that the puzzles were fresh, solvable and quite original which made me want to see the next puzzle there, the next thing I had to do. All in all, the game has its moments where you feel tense and excited and it was a good experience. It's full of ideas, it's full of life, funnily enough, for a game about death. For me this is why I kept coming back, your experience with the character may vary but she wasn't totally unbearable to me but never had her moments where I laughed.The sound design on this game is an incredibly mixed bag. The music is great and you'll want to listen to more of it, it'll build and it'll be effective but then just cut out when they need it to and it abruptly stops. There's one sound that plays for multiple effects, but hey, you don't play this for the sound do you? The sound is a mixed bag but the graphics and attention to the levels and story is where the most focus has gone I feel. Although hard work must have been made to record and mix all those lines of dialouge, I don't feel like it's on par at times with the game world they've created. All in all, this is a good game, buy it. Even though I have a few negative points about it, there more production points than gameplay points. The way the game plays is solid and it never gets boring or repeats the same idea over and over again.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												The Cat Lady succeeds in engrossing you where so many AAA titles have failed in the past in a way in which baffles and confuses me even an hour after finishing the game. It's one of those rare experiences akin to Gone Home that has a snowball effect when it comes to character and plot development, taking you on a rollercoaster ride of emotions that seems to only build on itself faster by the minute as it comes to what I considered a timely conclusion.Another aspect of this game that reminded me of Gone Home was how it managed to make me somehow relate and feel connected to the protagonist, even though I myself am a 27 year old male with a fairly positive outlook on life and the character is a middle aged woman with rather sad case of depression (for good reason as you will find out later in the game). Adding to its ambiance is an exceptional soundtrack, that while being a bit rough around the edges is so in such a way that lends itself to the art style of the game.The way in which the plot revealed her background story kept me intrigued, and is delivered in such a way that you are thrown into a situation wondering "what the hell just happened" but don't have to wait too long to fill in the gaps and arrive at the "Aha!" moment. The game is obviously not without its quirks, many times I was presented with duplicated voice loops and the setup utility/screen resolution options are largely useless, however none of these problems ruined the atmosphere for me. I personally would have like the use of the mouse in the save menu and did have the game crash once during my play through.In summary I would recommend this game to anyone that considers a great video game experience to be more than just a sum of its parts, what the developers have managed to do with an outdated game engine, low res graphics and a keyboard only control scheme has somehow evolved into one of the best gaming experiences I've had in my life.

Good music that fits the atmosphere.All in all, a good game. I had fun playing it.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												The Cat Lady tells the tale of Susan Ashworth, a woman pushed to suicide by the events of her life. However, once dead, she meets up with a mysterious figure called the Queen of Maggots who has bigger plans for Susan... namely, pitting her against five serial killers, aka Parasites. Susan really has no choice in the matter: in fact, she cannot die until she kills all of the Parasites. With that, The Cat Lady begins, a macabre little game that is surprisingly touching while still being spooky.Above all else, The Cat Lady's art style is one of its best features. Objects are put together in a collage-like style, with color used to set the mood (and often effectively). Combined with the soundtrack, which ranges from death metal(?) to eerie creaking, breathing and heartbeats, it's all too easy to set the average player on edge for some of the scarier scenes. Make no mistake, this game doesn't rely on jumpscares to get your pulse racing. Rather, your own unsettled nature becomes your own worst enemy. For a game with an unkillable protagonist, still making a player scared is quite an accomplishment.Still, those worried about the scariness shouldn't pass up this game. Underneath the 'horror' aspect is a moving story about death, depression, and the various ways of coping with both. Both Susan and sidekick Mitzi are highly empathetic characters and it won't take most players long to get attached to both of them. The game does suffer from a few moments of melodrama, but they're short and easily forgotten.Overall, if you're looking for a story driven game with plenty of the macabre, and you don't mind a little horror mixed in, The Cat Lady might just be for you. And if not... pick it up anyways.

content:
Posted: May 8, 2014
												When i started this game, i was not sure at all what to expect.  Jump scares, freaky characters, ghost or ghostlike thingamabobs, disturbng images, horrific deaths.  And yep, there those in there.  With more to boot, but that was not what kept me going.  It was the unflinching humanity of the main character and how she really dived into her psyche to confront what drove her to suicide.  Endings may vary a bit, but it was my desire to see her move forward with the story that kept me intrigued.  None of the "Oh, god when will I find the right combo of items??!!" or "I hate this pixel hunting chore!" it was more "Well, that didn't work so what next...ah...makes sense...and the story unfolds nicely there".  Good pacing.  Nicely thought out and artfully done.  Really, what a good adventure should be.  Well done.  I played all the endings too.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												The Cat Lady took me completely by surprise.  When I first heard of it, I identified a few primary adjectives that applied to it: dark, horror, atmospheric, indie, adventure, interesting.  The "interesting" bit was why I decided to torrent it out of a casual curiosity.  I bought it after having completed it, because it absolutely deserves it.If you have not yet watched the game's trailer, then I highly recommned it before proceeding in this review in order to really get a feel for the game's style and theme.  After having seen the trailer, I was immediately interested, but the game's tremendously heavy tone was a little worrisome at first.  Of course, it was one of things that drew me to it in the first place, but at the same time one of my greatest fears for the game was that it would end up being an overly grimdark puddle of emo for emo's sake.  Thankfully, my concerns were completely unfounded as the game surprised me with the depth and dynamic qualities of its story and characters.  The quality of the game's protagonists is incredible.  They feel tremendously real despite their extreme circumstances and their growth and development as characters is one of my very favourite things about the game.The art and music are also both consistently top-rate.  Some may find the paper-cutout animation style a bit off-putting, thinking it primitive, but I could not disagree more.  Its brilliance lies in how beautifully it expresses the game's core themes.  The player character, Susan Ashworth, is a sufferer of chronic, even suicidal, depression.  To her, the world is a dark, colourless place and people are hated reminders of her own prison of sorrow and alienation.  The game's bleak depictions of environments and unnatural, eerily-jerking character animations express this perfectly.The game's soundtrack is simply superb and the game does an incredible job of using music to convey emotion and intensity within the narrative.  It doesn't serve as a backdrop to fill dead air as it so often does in other games, but really, truly contributes to the strength of the narrative in wonderful ways.The only area I honestly think the game could be improved is the audio-recording quality for one or two of the minor characters.  If you have read other reviews, this issue will surely have caught your attention, but don't let its significance become overstated.  The main characters are voiced and recorded expertly and the overall game really isn't detracted from by these few technical failings.  Once you have played the game, you will think back on the wonderfully realized characters, moving story and consistently powerful conveyance of theme and emotion, not the odd technical hiccup of inadequate recording equipment.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												Wow. I don't think I can speak highly enough about this game. From its dreamlike (and/or nightmarish) presentation to its mournful story, The Cat Lady offers a truly unique experience - so much so that I don't even want to spoil the premise of the game.  Make no mistake though, this game does *not* hold back, and this confronting nature is what makes it so memorable. On the one hand, The Cat Lady is one of the most disturbing games I have ever played. A host of horrible people do horrible things chapter after chapter, in complete gory detail...yet with enough restraint to prevent it from being a hokey splatterfest. Gruesome stuff indeed!On the other hand, however, The Cat Lady is also one of the most human games I have played. For all of the horrific things in this game's world, the game is surprisingly at its most powerful during its quiet moments. The plot, characters, dialogue and visuals all tie together to explore serious topics: depression, suicide, loss, loneliness. You'll feel your character grow as you make choices throughout this game,  and you'll witness your character's growth take centre stage for the story- and that is a very rare thing indeed. Anyone who cares about storytelling in videogames should definitely check this one out.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												The Cat Lady is one of the few games I would actually consider to be a work of art.As you've probably seen, The Cat Lady is a side-scrolling horror game that follows a lonely 40 year-old woman named Susan Ashworth who decides to commit suicide. The game has a mature and well-written story with a genuinely likeable (and in some cases despicable) cast of characters, and the majority of the voice acting is excellent. The Cat Lady also features an unusual and refreshing visual style which uses a sparse colour palette and even though it sometimes doesn't look very nice I believe this is intentional choice by the artist. The game also has an excellent soundtrack that perfect compliments they different areas of the game.The game, however, is not perfect. For some reason every save creates a new save slot, preventing one playthrough from using just one save slot. The game also lags slightly and occasionally crashes, although this may just be because my computer isn't very very strong. There are a few minor typos throughout, but nothing that detracts from the experience.Overall, I would recommend The Cat Lady for anyone look for a good story or horror experience in a game, or who just wants to try something different.

												 The Cat Lady is an amazing game with very few faults. Though the art style seemed a bit odd at first, I came to love the animation and blurriness which really gave the player of being in Susan's shoes. It is an unsettling game full of imagery and puzzles and even a  couple of small jump scares. Amazing character development and interactions.The only compaint would be how much the game seems to crash. My computor is an impressive one, yet the game still crashes and announces that it is "out of memory" which my computor is not. And with such long, unskippable dialouges, replaying LARGE portions of the game without the ability to save at points is difficult when the game crashes.But that point still does not detract with a game that should make horror history.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Oh where to begin. Most people had heard about this game once big youtubers played it and with the sudden interest, it gained enough attention to get greenlit on steam. One thing that bothered me watching them play is that I feel they didn't take the game seriously.The Cat Lady is about Susan Ashworth, a woman suffering from depression who has decided to commit suicide. Susan is given a second chance (and immortality at that) to find a reason to live, but along the way she will meet "parasites", people who pretty much make you lose faith in humanity and are the most disgusting individuals. It is Susan's job to eliminate those parasites. The game is made by a developer known for dark and twisted games. That style fits perfectly here. A word of caution if you did not look at the rating, there are very mature themes and sensetive material which may trigger some people. Please keep that in mind before purchasing. At times it can be hard.The gameplay is basic like a lot of adventure games for the pc along with puzzles. Now as for the story, it really hit home for me. As one who has struggled with depression and suicide before, I really synced with Susan and was absorbed with her tale. I wanted the best for her and I shared in her hatred of the parasites. I didn't want to stop playing until the very end. The game takes maybe 5-7 hours to finish, but keep in mind there are multiple endings and multiple choises for most situations. I have replayed several times.I have recommended this game before to friends who didn't understand depression and how it affects someone to give them an idea. You see the suffering, the negativity, the toll it takes on someone and how it can affect their life. It can be an eye opening experience.And I must say at the end at the final screen, I cried. I will not spoil it, but it really resonates and the end made the entire experience worth it. Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												The Cat Lady is one of the most sensational games i've ever played. The Story, Characters, Music. And even the art style is beyond that of most games today. For a game that was cheaper to make compared to something like Beyond: two souls (which can't be compared fully) The Cat Lady is a becon of hope that games can be 2d and have an extreame amount of deep story and characters. Not to mention humor. I would recommend this to anyone who is into such deep storylines and has a love for loveable characters, because you won't be disappointed. It has a few scares along the way but if you can brave through them. The experience its self is breath taking. It yields such a great feeling of accomplishment when a puzzle is completed and progress to the main story.  I personaly did not think i would grow to love it as i do now. But you have to play it or watch it on youtube to fully grasp how great it is. However i do believe playing it is just as good as watching it.And those who continue to play through it will be rewarded by a special secret morle of the story which i think everyone on the internet can honestly relate to :) i won't spoil that but its worth the play to hear it :). So i will end my review saying i would give the cat lady 10/10 There has been noting i have liked more then this for such a long time, its weird, warming, creepy and even disturbing. But some how its extreamely loveable. The music is amazing. The entire experience is incredible and unique. And The Cat Lady, has changed the steryotype of any cat lady in my opinion :) i will never look at any "Crazy cat ladies" the same way. Because i will alwasy think of that special Susan Ashworth when ever the name is raised :)And a big thank you to the Devs for making this game. It deserves to be on steam and more.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2016
												This game was one of the most surprising, terrifying, dark, uplifting, beautiful, and uttermost oustanding rollercoasters I've ever been on. Not only uniquely crafted with the art style and crazy good music suitable for every chapter, the game gives a great tale about a "crazy" cat woman named Susan finding her way back to humanity, love, and happiness: things she believed she lost due to multiple tragic events in her life. While the player witnesses the world in her eyes and the gradual development of a stronger and improved Susan through gameplay, the players also end up learning with Susan and are forced to ponder tough topics such as suicide, depression, murder, and forgiveness. Although the game doesn't necessairly list solutions to these difficult subjects, the player definitely cannot help but walk away with a whole different perspective at the end of this game on what it truly means to "live"I literally give this game a 10/10 and would reccomend it to anyone who's able to stomache gore, suicide as well as other issues not suited for younger teens and children along with those with a weak tolerance to horror.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
												This game is one of the best horror games. There is no denying that, and it's pretty hard to actually deny. The way the game is executed, is just done in the most perfect way. You, the player, feel like you are in Susan Ashworth's boots.Let's do some main story here. (Spoilers(?))You are suicidal, Susan feels as though she has nothing to live for, no friends, no life, nothing. That's the way this game makes you feel, like nothing. You start off as a husk, a woman who has nothing to live for, in the verge of writing her suicide note, until she puts her head into the noose. You are dead.You wake up. In a dream-like world, it's quite the long grass sways in the wind. You see a pile up of crashed vehicles, you head towards it, go to the ambulance, open the door. It's you. You're in the ambulance. You start to panic, and lift the key on a necklace off your own neck. You approach a woman sitting on a porch, and at this point, I think it's up to you to find out what happens next!It's an amazing horror game, and I'm sure everyone has heard of it. I highly recommend it to anyone who ever feels that they have nothing to live for, this will show you what people will go through to help others. Pick up this game, play it, love it. Enjoy the story. Enjoy your life.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												9/10A visually stunning, unique, psychological adventure game, the cat lady is by far one of my favorite games I've played to date. Its story and array of characters are extremely well thought out, with only minor conflicting elements here and there that one could easily look over. I think one of my favorite things about this game is that the protagonist, Susan, is extremely relatable in most aspects, especially if you are someone suffering from depression. The game handles it very well, and doesn't dare sugarcoat the negative aspects of the illness. It's in your face, along with many other uncomfortable themes people never really want to think about when playing a game, but that, I think, makes it all the more fun.The puzzles in the cat lady are moderately difficult. There were times where I was stuck and had to pull up a walkthrough because I missed one tiny detail, but other than that - it was very enjoyable. You may get frustrated playing the cat lady, but rest assured, you are not the only one that screams "What the hell is your moms name?!?!" repeatedly at the screen until you manage to figure it out. All in all, a magnificent game with incredible artwork that works perfectly with the story and overall theme of the game. But wait, you ask yourself, why is she giving it a 9 out of 10 if she likes it so much?Well, that's very easy to answer:There  was a severe lack of cat puns through the course of the game. Not once did I hear "How do you like meow?" or "Are you kitten me?" not even a "Purrfect"! and for that greatly missed opportunity I'm going to have to deduct a point. If you're looking for cat puns in a game called the cat lady, you're going to be terribly disappointed.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2014
												"The Cat Lady" is an independently made point and click game. Yet, that is not all it is. It is a game that explores death, monsters and ultimately life itself. There are no demons or ghosts in this game; and it tries to tell its player exactly that: there are no supernatural monsters. The only monsters are us. As Susan goes through each challenge, we discover with her just what we would do to stay alive. She regains her humanity bit by bit and her journey, despite her state at the beginning, is one of life. Susan and the player learn about life and just how precious it really is. It also helps that the concept was probably the best in game storyline in years. I could not help but wish I had come up with it first. Bravo. Buy this game. You will not be disappointed.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2016



YouTube™ Video: The Cat Lady (2012) - PC - Review 

			Views: 99		

			A great time to upload this during the YouTube censorship campaign! Support me on Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/pvthudson		

The Cat Lady is without a doubt one of the sickest and darkest games that I’ve ever played. You play as Susan Ashworth, a lonely depressed and anti-social woman who has no family, no friends, and nothing good going for her. So one night she decides to commit suicide by consuming a bunch of sleeping pills in front of her favorite cat. What follows is a roller-coaster of morbid surrealism as she wakes up in a strange forest and keeps finding corpses of herself. She eventually meets a strange old woman who calls herself the Queen of Maggots and gives Susan immortality and tells her she must kill 5 Parasites. Susan then wakes up in a hospital bed and was told that she was in a coma from the sleeping pill overdose.This game is weird, strange, sick, and gross. It is an adult game intended for mature audiences and deals with suicide, depression,♥♥♥♥♥♥ mental health, online harassment, and more.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2014
												T H E     C A T     L A D Y	           .   .   .   Suicide is not the end.     Imagine your life in it's darkest moments, trapped in a bleak, meaningless circle of dead ends and false hope. You wake up every day, only to realize it will be the same as yesterday. Only to realize that the life you have been living for the last ten years means nothing anymore. You have no friends, you have nothing to motivate you, and you have no one to care about you. Happiness now seems like a dark puddle you sometimes see your face in on a rainy day, stripped of any emotion.     You think to yourself:  This is it. I am not worth anything to this world. Thanks for nothing. Goodbye.	  So, that evening, as you prepare for your last night on this planet, you reflect on your past - who you've hurt, what you regret, the mistakes you made and wanted to change. You come to the conclusion that the world is not meant for you. You are not meant for it. Dying is now your only friend. It tempts you, haunts you, sings to you. You give in once you see the sleeping pills. All thirty four of them. Swallowed. In moments you can no longer see the dim lights of your apartment. You fade, in a blur, out of reality. A moment later, you vanish. You have killed yourself. No one will miss you. No one will care...     . . .But. What if you were offered a second chance? A chance, not to exact revenge on the people you hate most, but to change your very life and it's purpose. What if someone offered you the keys to fulfill what's been missing in your life. To truly find the happiness you once held, long ago, in those brighter, long forgotten days.  What if your most darkest, ugliest hatred gave you immortality? In exchange for death?	       You think this over. Question the morality of the offer. What have you got to live for anyway? Why would this... "person", so to speak, even give this type of chance to someone as pathetic as you? As worthless and miserable and unforgiving as you? After all, YOU were the one who took those pills to end the torment and suffering, to be free of the hostile pain that has swelled inside you for so long. Why even bother? Considering the fact that you are already dead, and that you probably won't be given another chance like this, you don't have a choice. Immortality does have it's price. But that's not why you accept. You hunger to kill these five people, to end their reign of terror upon the mortal realm, to make them pay for the horror they have caused others... People like you.      You accept this strange woman's offer, doubting everything she even says, but somehow knowing that killing those five people will somehow solve everything that has plagued your life. You feel eagerness tingling inside you for the first time in years - a yearning to actually do something good, something that will help the world and regain your sense of purpose. You feel reborn again. Finally, you have a purpose. A reason to continue living. A call to action.      Now it is time to find those five people. To confront them for who they really are. You are to become. . . T H E     C A T     L A D Y

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												Technically, The Cat Lady is a deeply-flawed indie game.  The engine is absurdly antiquated, clunky and unstable. The sound mixing is at times amateurish.  It's a point-and-click adventure without the point and clicking, as all interactions are done using the keyboard's arrow keys and space bar.  The game also runs at 800x600.Creatively, though—artistically—The Cat Lady is wonderful.  Well, wonderful may be the wrong word.  This is grindhouse horror.  Bloody imagery, rusted machinery and deprecated rooms accompany its muted tones and grim environment.  Nothing's 'wonderful' in Susan Ashworth's world, a fact that leads the protagonist to her suicide attempt in the game's introduction.No, the Cat Lady isn't wonderful, per se.  It's captivating, provocative and memorable.  It's also dark, unrelenting and austere.  That's usually how it is for sufferers of depression.  That's how it is for Susan.  But as she drifts throughout her despair, the story provides her with the ability to put matters into her own hands—whether she likes it or not.The Cat Lady is a worthwhile, fantastic experience if story-driven horror/adventure calls out to you.  Though its design is decidedly rough around the edges, its vision and its story do make up for it.  Those rough edges are nevertheless a shame, as they diminish what I feel could have otherwise been a masterpiece of its genre.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2016
												I really, really wanted to like this game. I loved the art style in the trailer, I love the idea of games that discuss mental illness in a non-glorified way. I love shorter, story-based, choice-based games. But after finishing this game, I was left wanting so much more.This is a puzzle game, but several of the puzzles just don't make sense. Certain objects just don't logically fit together, and yet you have to assume that they do in order to progress. Several cut scenes reference Downfall, but having never played it, I had no idea what their significance was. My biggest complaint is that there aren't enough opportunities for actual gameplay. Many points in the game would have been really interesting, challenging puzzles, but instead were turned into cutscenes. I was pretty disappointed, especially given that the game is supposed to be a horror genre. The voice acting is pretty terrible, and the audio quality shifts from character to character. It's very inconsistent, as is the writing. I genuinely believe that this game could have been so much better if it were about 6 hours longer, giving more time for character development and for each chapter to include more actual gameplay. Overall, a decent game for the price, but I wouldn't necessarily recommend it.

Posted: June 5, 2016
												I don't know what kind of game I was expecting when I started The Cat Lady, but 15 minutes in I was totally hooked. This is a great adventure game. Spooky, with a good story, and a surreal, nightmarish atmosphere. This game has cannibals, and serial killers, and a madman who frames their victims, posing them using wires and cables as art exhibits, and one guy is attacked and eaten by cats, and there's a young woman dying from cancer, and there's an middle-aged woman dying of depression. Bare cupboards and spoiled milk and peeling paint and everything all mixed up in a giant pot of unsettling clip-art style scenery. WEIRD

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												I am pleased to report that the fatal error that was occurring has been fixed! The developers solved the problem in just a few days, and for that I would like to thank them. You do not often see such diligent support from devs, but in this case they have done right by everyone, so that is awesome. So the cat lady is indeed an amazing game. It is a story driven 2D point and click style game. The puzzles I have encountered so far are not too difficult, and if you do happen to get stuck there are many resources online that you can get hints and tips from. So in that sense the game is not frustrating. The real emphasis of this title is on the story, and damn is it an interesting one. Let me say this, if you have ever experienced a deep depression you will almost instantaneously relate and connect to the games main character. It is clear the writer or writers of this game know what they are talking about. They have crafted a deep, dark, and in many ways outright creepy story. Hands down one of the best stories in gaming I have yet seen. I supported this title on green light and I am very happy to see it on Steam. If you grew up on point and click style adventure games, and you enjoy dark stories, then you owe it to yourself to buy this game.

number of helpful: 10 of 19 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												I know that often people will say that you have to go from beginning to end before you can judge something; however, I believe that mostly applies when you plan to give great praise to something.  However, after 4 chapters of Cat Lady, it's obvious that it does not merit great praise because, no matter how great the ending might be, the middle is so poorly written that, much like its suicidal protagonist, nothing could save it.Chapter 1 does a great job by first pulling in the audience with impeccable pacing, score, and cinematography.  Although the narrative is weak; dialogue is used sparingly enough to allow for the other pieces to be at the foreground of the gaming experience.Chapter 2, things change.  The visual and auditorial aspects of the game get pushed aside to make way for the disinteresting, uncomplex, and seemingly endless dialogue.  With narration coming to the foreground, the game shifts from a pleasurable experience to a very tedious one filled with boring conversations for any audience member whose spent more than a few seconds thinking about life, whatsoever.Chapter 3 puts further emphasis on the narrative and, once again, to the detriment of the game.  Character development is stereotypical and the narrative is contorted, at times, just to keep the story going in a particular direction.  For example, although we saw the character go through some emotional breakthroughs in the previous chapters, she somehow instantly slips back into severe depression over the most miniscule of inconveniences.  In Chapter 3, she has a complete emotional breakdown which escalates into suicidal thoughts.  What for?  Bad coffee, a burnt meal, and criticism from her neighbor for deciding to play the piano at 2am in the morning...  That's all it takes, apparently.  So, despite any judgements regarding the protagonists emotional realism, she just comes across as immature, inconsiderate, and selfish.  And I have a hard time sympathizing with that...Chapter 4.  The protagonist continues to complain with same incoherent thoughts and the game basically goes nowhere.So, all in all, is this game a good game?  Well, in my opinion, after 4 chapters played, it's a complete disaster as far as writing is concerned.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												I wanted to like this game, because it had an interesting concept. But the voice acting was just too spotty (sometimes excellent, sometimes recorded on a very terrble mic). It was distracting pretty much 100% of the time. The art was also hit or miss, with some backgrounds and little details being beautiful,but the different expressions of the protagonist looking the like they were drawn by different people and were meant to convey every different stage of her life. There were some moments that were enjoyable (like telling a guy where to shove it after he yells about you playing the piano), but a lot of the time the story drags. It often felt like it was edgy for the sake of being edgy, rather than for a point. Usually the next step was intuitive, but then there were times where I had to pull up a guide because the next step made little sense or something was broken (such as having to follow a raven, only the raven didn't spawn so instead I walked in circles for ten minutes). Tl;dr: cool idea, fell short in storytelling and often times tried to achieve something greater technically than the creators were capable of.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												If I could blend the psychological despair of Silent Hill 2, the free-flowing dialogue and character development of The Longest Journey, and the ultraviolent vengeance of the Kill Bill films... I might come close to describing what I enjoyed about The Cat Lady. If you enjoy captivating, character-based storytelling, and (mostly?) psychological horror, you will definitely enjoy the game. There are many visceral horror elements too, but ultimately, I was left with a story about the human desire to prevail over despair and darkness. I think the game designer was bold in telling this story, and I feel it is a story that needs to be told... especially in video game form!At first, I was concerned about how streamlined the play style appeared to be (e.g. using only the arrow controls on the keyboard,) but I ultimately found it liberating. The puzzles were mostly intuitive, although I had to seek some help during the more surreal sequences. The voice acting is predominantly solid and believable. I became attached to some of the characters, and was sad to have finished the game as quickly as I did.I really hope to see more works from Remigiusz Michalski in the future. This is the kind of adventure game that will stick with you, long after play time is over!

There is gore and blood, but given the modest graphics and slower gameplay, it lacks the fast-paced shock value present in most horror games (which is fine by me, I like my horror a bit more cerebral). It's very thematic and the mood is just right. If you're looking for a creepy side scroller with an interesting supernatural story that won't tax your system, then this is the game for you. It's sort of like a horror version of Myst, crossed with a Choose Your Own Adventure book. Recommended.UDPATE: changed review to reflect bug fixes

content:
Posted: March 27, 2014
												So. You're playing as Susan Ashworth, a depressed middle-aged woman who tries to commit suicide by swallowing a bunch of pills... And that's where the game begins. This game deals with some really serious and heavy stuff... cancer, depression, suicide and death.  It is kinda gory and it has a depressing and a very.. very dark and morbid atmosphere.You may have to get used to the visuals and controls at the beginning but it fits the game perfectly. The story is strong. But what really made me love and appreciate this game is how accurately and perfectly it describes how it feels to suffer from depression. If you have ever experienced depression this game and Susan's character will probably bring back some memories and make you tear up. The story had me crying so many times, it's a rare thing when a game can actually touch your heart and emotions.It is a horror game but without relying on jumpscares or monsters. The horror comes in pure story form. With that being said, this won't be a game I would recommend to everyone. It doesn't have much gameplay and there is A LOT of reading involved. If you're not into that kinda stuff you will not enjoy this game.But like I said.. ''The Cat Lady'' has one of the most emotional storyline I have ever seen in a video game and it will be worth your time. It has a very complicated but deep message to tell in it's story.Susan Ashworth, you're my hero!10/10 (I'm more of a dog person though) .

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												Not too shabby, but definitely flawed.  An emotional exploration of depression. 8/10.The Cat Lady is an introspective adventure game that follows a suicidal woman given the burden of immortality by an eldritch queen of maggots. The protagonist, Susan Ashworth, is forced to rid England of an array of serial killers, herein referred to as "parasites," so that she can be given the opportunity to die. The journey to end their lives has our heroine interacting with a constellation of characters who embody philosophical insight on the human condition, and the plight of the chronically, fatally, and/or mentally ill. The puzzles range from boringly simple, such as showing the player a pattern and asking them to repeat it, to artificially confusing, as in the infamous tornado summoning ritual from Castlevania II. Still, many puzzles balance level design and game mechanics well enough to produce a fun challenge. The art is good; although I may have my issues with the way the director chose to balance monochrome with color, the game overall encapsulates a memorable, pretty aesthetic.The cast is effectively written and admirably layered. In The Cat Lady, we see various aspects of Susan and a handful of supporting characters. Even the parasites, who are disappointingly one-dimensional, offer iconic personalities and well-constructed allegory.However, the one-dimensionality of the parasites brings me to a critical flaw of this game's rhetoric: in order to achieve sympathy for depressed people, the director throws psychotic people under the bus. Instead of purporting the validity of mentally ill lives, the game separates mental illnesses into good (potentially self-destructive) and bad (potentially externally destructive), suggesting that people with mood disorders belong to the former category, and that people with violent psychosis belong to the latter. Bear in mind the ableist demeanor of the game should you choose to buy it.All things considered, I recommend this game. It may have its flaws, but its pros do outweigh its cons. If you suffer from depression or a similar affliction, I doubly recommend it.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2014
												I can't recommend this game enough. Although I had read that it's great before I bought it, it surpassed my expectations by far. I've never been so touched and shaken at the same time by a game (well, maybe with Legacy of Kain series, but that's a different genre). I just finished it today and I'm planning to replay it again, to collect all achievements and try all the choices. But even though I loved it, I have to warn you: this game is not for everyone.This adventure game is definitely a unique one. Not only because of the unusual visual style, but mainly for its dark themes and story. Susan Ashworth, the main character, is very easy to sympathetize with. The music is well-chosen and even though you may find the visuals odd at the beginning, they fit the game amazingly. The story is strong. But what really made me fall in love with this game is how accurately it describes how depression feels; it is a spot on. If you have ever experienced depression, this game and Susan's character will move you even more. For cat lovers, psychological horror fans and people I mentioned above, this game is a must-play. And even if you aren't one us these, give it a shot. It's definitely worth it.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2014
												There were a lot of things to like about TCL.  The gameplay reminds me of classic pc adventure games - walk left and right, examine/take/combine things, solve simple puzzles, choose dialogue options.  They did a solid job of implementing these familiar elements.  It took around eight hours to complete, which felt just about right to me.  I will probably get one more playthrough down the road.The game brought a lot to the table in terms of an presenting an original story idea that worked well in a horror/adventure format.  I liked the pacing of things - sometimes scary, sometimes emotional and dialogue focused, sometimes brief exploration and puzzle solving.  The voice acting was above average and the music was fantastic and well-timed.  TCL was a memorable experience.  If you think you would enjoy an emotional, gory, horror/adventure game then you probably won't find anything better, or anything quite like it.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
												So The Cat Lady... Going into this I didn't really know what to expect. The Indie/horror tags sort of... drew me in. I'm very interested in atmospheric games and independent developers tend to either hit the ball out of the park or make a jump scare induced piece of crap. This game was not only satisfying, but very deep and thought provoking at times which is something I don't often expect in games that aren't made by well-known people. The atmosphere is great, the art style is a nice change and it's so simple. The puzzles are odd at times but it's nothing that is impossible to solve. Just search everything twice and attempt an item on everything and you'll do just fine. My only critique would be that, for a game that seems to center around making your own choices (seen throughout the achievements and conflicts in game), your choices don't seem to have any real consequences or impact. Which is a real shame because it made the game seem a lot less like I had control and more like it was playing itself at times. I'd give it a 4/5 and do highly recommend it to those who like the... dark and grotesque side of humanity.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												The Cat Lady - while for some the name of the game might sound weird considering its theme, it is, after all, a horror game with psychological influences. You get to play Susan, a woman who attempted suicide and through some bizzare event got the superpower of immortality as she goes on to kill serial killers. While the plot in itself might not sound that strong, the level of detail with which the events are detailed is amazing and truly realistic. The characters are quite believable in what they do and make you either love or hate them according to their actions and what they say, so the game does a fantastic job in immersing the player in it. In the end, due to this level of detail the story is saved and becomes rather interesting. The element of danger and the plot twists really complete this experience.The graphics are not amazing, but this is a more of a 2d horror game after all. There is gore however and some nudity, so be prepared. Especially for gore, which is all over the place. So the game is 18+ (though we know you won't care about this even if you were under 18, isn't that right?)In terms of sounds and music, I belive they fit with the theme of the story and the music usually starts at the right time and only helps you get into the story even more. Overall, The Cat Lady shows an attention to details and an interesting story due to said details. This makes it a good game worth buying.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
												It's incredibly hard to do this game justice by trying to describe it in a review, but I will say this... this game is amazing. It's original, disturbing, full of sadness and at times, terrifying. I don't think I've ever played anything like it before and in terms of story and experience/emotional connection, it is one of the best I have ever played. And I've played a lot of games.The soundtrack is fantastic as well.It's definitely not for everyone though - some won't like the very dark subject matter or the violence. And the graphics are - well, sometimes they work perfectly to create an original, twisted atmosphere - but the animations are not great to say the least. The actual gameplay mechanics are extremely basic - it's kind of a 'point and click' game where you actually can't point and click (it's keyboard only - basically you just use the arrow keys and enter to move, select and interact). I've noticed a few reviews mentioning bugs and crashes but I have to say, I didn't encounter any. The puzzles are OK - definitely logical, and pretty simple (which I guess can be either a good or a bad thing depending on what you want from a game). The voice acting is somewhat hit and miss.Despite its shortcomings however, the story and characters absolutely carry it through. From the moment I started playing it grabbed my attention with its grim beginning (as it happens right at the very start of the game before you even do anything, I don't think it would be a spoiler to say that it starts with the main character's suicide note) and played, captivated, right through to the end without stopping, It's rare that a game compels me this much. It's rare that a game makes me feel in the way that this did. And I won't forget it.So much love has clearly gone into this game. Get it, and experience it. Edit: It's also a perfect pick for the 'I'm not crying, there's something in my eye' award!

content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												The Cat Lady gets an easy TWO thumb recommendation from me. It has it's minor flaws and I would not say it's for everybody but it's most definately still great. The music is ordinary and the interface is below average at best. The art is mediocre and the animations are just plain laughable. However, rising out of this morass are a story and central character so good that you start to see this game as a glittering diamond from a dull bit of coal.Susan Ashworth struggles with depression, isolation and is recovering from a suicide attempt.  While in a limbo/bardo state of consciousness, she meets a harbinger-of-woe type figure that warns her of coming tribulations. She returns to life to face these obstacles with a very unique power; she cannot die. The game then unfolds as she meets these adversities as she struggles with ongoing depression and the dark events that somehow plague her. Susan also eventually befriends another character, Mitzi. Mitzi has her own crosses to bear and their two destinies dramatically entwine as they share a part of each others burden.You may think that being unable to die would make a central character seem omnipotent and render a game unchallenging but this is NOT the case. It's true that the puzzles in this game aren't particularly taxing but it's unlikely you'll play the game perfectly the first time and Susan will still suffer. Oh, she'll suffer. Likewise, you may think that a game which deals with such topics as murder, isolation, bitterness, loss, domestic disputes, sadism, addiction etc would be a downer. Again, it's NOT. This game deftly walks such a fine line. Much of this game entails a lot of storytelling, flashbacks and lots and lots of dialogue. This, coupled with Susan's occasional forays into deathless states, results in some very non-linear story and gameplay. This is why I would warn some players off this game. Some gamers just want constant action and thrills and spills. They should avoid this one as they'll find it slow and uninteresting (it's their loss).Ultimately, this is a game that examines some of the darkest aspects of humanity yet leaves us feeling optimistic. It tackles difficult subjects such as depression and it's ramifications hopefully and realistically. It's refreshing to play a character that's so flawed and heavily burdened. It's also rewarding to play such a character who's capable of learning and positive growth; friendship can overcome isolation and hope can trump despair. It's no wonder that so many people (those who suffer depression/isolation and those who don't) have responded to this game so positively. I am full of admiration for its creator and regard this game as something of a groundbreaking achievement.

												A perfect game about a green eyed lady who loves cats. It really shows what depression and suicide is, sometimes with a cold humor, other times with just the bluntness of it. The ''lesson'' that the game shows with the storyline, not just about life, but how you handle things, is that final touch who makes ''The Cat Lady'' an unique game (such as Downfall). I enjoyed every moment of the gameplay. It's really worth it. ''Come inside, my darlings. I've missed you!''

content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												This game is dark. Really, really dark, and I love it.The Cat Lady follows the story of Susan Ashworth, a woman who lives alone in an old, rundown flat. Right from the beginning, this game takes a dark turn. The game begins with Susan committing suicide, and as far as you're know, she succeeds. She does survive the attempt, but from that point on, nothing really seems to go her way.The game follows Susan as she tries to cope with her seemingly crushing depression and hopelessness. There are many times when it's hard to differentiate between what's real and what's a seeming dream state. Time and time again she is faced against people who embody the worst of humanity, whether it's someone's insane idea of art, cannibalism, beauty, power over another's life, or how life just isn't fair. There were times when I felt uncomfortable or squeamish. Even with the slightly twisted and not-quite-right art style, I found it to be a bad idea to eat while playing this game. The brightest part of the game is easily Mitzi, but even that is too short.The art style and music only emphasize the psychological effect of the game. The game is primarily black and grey and most colors are muted at best, if present at all. The colors are bright only to emphasize some horror or gruesome scene, such as blood, a person's eyes, or to highlight an important decision. The music intensifies the atmosphere, and like any good horror/suspense game, emphasizes events or actions with appropriate songs. The stranger the event, the more demented and twisted the music becomes; complete a puzzle or unlock a door, the music seems to become more uplifting and bright; assemble a weapon to punish the ones who have hurt you, and the music takes a sinister tone. Overall, this is a dark game that focuses on mature themes that may put off a few people. I would heed the 18+ warning at the beginning of the game. There are lots of rather disturbing scenes involving killing, many forms of mutilated corpses, disturbing images, and torture. However, it is definitely worth a play through, if only to get a glimpse into the psyche of the insane.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
												Strangest game ever, but in a good way. The story is dark and twisted. The humor is twisted also. It's got all of the classic horror elements... Moths, bare light bulbs dangling from fixtures, black and white/noir environments, maggots, etc. The dialogue is pretty varied, but always interesting. The puzzles and events are not annoying or tedious, and are entertaining enough as well. The story seems pretty linear. Choices don't seem to lead to long-lasting changes, they just trigger different cutscenes and replies that shortly follow, but it's fine.Overall it's a really good game. The art style is... Interesting, a mix of photos/photomanipulation/drawing. It does a good job of creating environments that look both real (because of photos of real objects) and fake (due to odd arrangements and manipulation) at the same time, which is often disturbing.The only major weak point is the character animation, which is a bit odd at times - sort of contorted cardboard puppet-like stuff going on. Usually it's pretty good and this is not too noticeable, but during long dialogue scenes with lots of back and fourth it can be a bit much. The UI is also a little weak, limited to up down left right and enter, which usually gets the job done. However, character movement sometimes interferes with item selection, which can be annoying.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												3/5 Average game. May have good points, but its bad ones bring it down.Don't get me wrong, just because I don't recommend it means it's a bad game. It's just that it's not a game for everyone. The premise is great, but the execution leaves a lot to be desired. There are many scenes that take too long and there is no option to skip them. Which isn't that bad the first time you played it, but oh god does it show in a second playthrough. For the save option to appear you need to press ESC, but it will NOT work during a cutscene or dialog (which, you know, the game is full of). So you may have pressed it at some point and, since nothing came up, thought it didn't serve a purpose. My first time playing the game I made it to Chapter 4, and since I didn't see the save option nor the game told me about it, I supposed it autosaved. Playing everything again was a chore. Chapter 3 introduces mechanics that you won't see ever again. And the way they work, it's almost a guarantee that you will "fail" it the first time. Chapter 4 has a particular scene where the game slows down a LOT making the game unplayable. I thought it was a glitch so I had to load another save file only to have the same results.And it seem that at the end the creator forgot what the game was about. Let me put it like this: You play a game where the objective is to find your 5 cows that escaped from the barn. When looking for the first one you travel through the mountains, fight wolves and swim through a lake. And you think "Well, so far it's good. I wonder if it gets better". But then you find the next 4 cows all in the same place just eating grass. And then you turn arounds and see a duck and scream "Johnson! There you are, I've been looking for you for years." So you take your duck back to your barn where he uncovers the hidden gold of Mr. McNugget... And you just wonder, wasn't this game supposed to be about something else? Now, as I said before, the premise of the game is very interesting. At the beginning of Chapter 4 a new character will be introduce that makes the game feel less depressing, even the main character will act different and make the game more enjoyable. It's definitely an experience, I'm glad I played it, but it could have been better.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												The bar is set pretty low if this is considered one of the best adventure games of the past 5 years. The writer and voice director bit off more than they could chew, aiming for a sophistication and intelligence in storyline and dialogue that they may not have the skill to reach. Credit for the attempt, but it wasn't a success. Speaking of voice acting, you could tell that most of these were done by devs or friends of devs, really giving their best effort. But it was clear right away they weren't hiring professional voice actors, save for a few semi-pro actors giving middling performances at best. In a story not well-served by the art, they really needed to nail the voice-acting at least. But so many of the performances were ham-fisted and unnatural. Just seems like a well-done amateur effort, through-out. Not a professional one.Edit: To be clear, btw, regarding storyline and dialogue, the game aimed for greater heights than most videogames, so credit for trying something most couldn't achieve, though it still missed the mark. The faults in writing were more on the end of the amateur dialogue, which wasn't helped by even more amateur performances. Games CAN shoot high and actually hit this mark, though it's rare. Telltale's Season 1 of TWD is one example, as is their TWAU. This one doesn't come close, though. Sorry.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 15, 2016
												I wanted to like this game. It was described to be like things I like. Bad dialog, bad voice acting, slow pacing, and cliched themes killed it for me. Some dialog options and NPC comments were just unreasonable. I often found myself frustrated with conversations that seemed unrealistic. A lot of it just didn't make sense. No nanny/nurse/neighbor would say things like that. I would not say anything like my given dialog options in response. The voice acting sounds like they emailed scripts to random friends and wished them luck. It was all very inconsistent. It's worth hiring a professional for these things. The slow pacing is further hindered by drawn-out cut scenes that you can't skip. Much of the imagery has been done before. I don't expect everyone to reinvent the wheel on every new horror game or movie, but some things have been done to death, like the eyeballs, rundown hospitals, and I rolled my eyes so hard when I heard "one always lies and one always tells the truth." Most of the things that were original from a horror/gore perspective were just boring, but I did like that monster from Chapter 5. Other than that, you have your typical adventure game tactic of 'I don't know why I'm picking this random thing up, but I'll rub it on some other random things later.' At least I got a laugh out of it when Monkey Island did it. Here, not so much. The story wasn't bad, but I didn't find it as intriguing as others did. Maybe I would have enjoyed the story more without the above distractions.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2016
												Initially I loved this. It has a compelling story, interesting characters, good use of psychology, interesting visuals and sound. The main thing that's missing from this game is the game-ness. I went into this expecting to make moral decisions, but I'm being led along a straight line with no choices. Perhaps there's more choice than I see, but if so then that's a problem too--a game should at least provide the illusion of choice.What sticks out the most is that often dialog options aren't a tree--they're a list. I get to choose which sequence I pick them in, but I'm not allowed to continue until I've chosen them all. There's no fun in that.This isn't a game where one shapes the character's path. It's a puzzle game, and not a great one. That's a pity, because the world and the story and the stylistic elements are interesting.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2014
												Great art, great music, gripping story, an interesting take on adventure game mechanics - but it's all nearly sabotaged by (yes, you guessed it) awful, woeful voice acting. Most actors don't seem to "get" the emotions behind their lines, and some (for instance, the first nurse in the hospital) are using sub-standard equipment which sounds absolutely garish on headphones (quite possibly phase-inverted?). It's jarring and with no way to silence the voices (save for muting all audio), it detracts from what should be a gripping, immersive experience. I'll give it a "yes" based on its strengths (though not at full price - wait for a sale!), but it's like seeing a team win via a controversial call when you know if they had been in normal form they would have won by a longshot. Frustrating, frustrating, frustrating.

												This isn't anything like your Amnesia: The Dark Descent or Fallout games; it's a simple point-and-click with graphics and voice-acting that are very reminiscent of visual novels. It's a fantastic, mature horror game of which the story contains a relatively accurate portrayal of depression, and the whimsical harshness of the tracks created for this game (of which I also must highly recommend) hit home just as hard. It would be nice for everyone to give this game a chance, especially those who are heavily affected by depression; however, a word of warning must be given for its often macabre images and blunt presentation which can be upsetting.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												There's good and bad in this game. I got The Cat Lady as a gift from a sibling. Upon first playing the game I didn't expect much out of it- in terms of looks, the character design sometimes has an odd, unpolished look (proportions are often unabashedly off) and speaking animations are often odd South Park-esque head waggling. (I'm not sure if these issues were intentional, and meant to make them puppet-like, or not.) The titular cats look like their running/jumping animations were done by an alien who never saw a cat, and was just guessing.Additionally, some of the 'missions' can be frustrating- sometimes it can seem less like a puzzle and more like a dull back-and-forth at the beginning of the game. The music with vocals that they got is also eye-rollingly wannabe-APC. It's less annoying than MCR, but takes itself far too seriously- juxtaposed with emotional scenes, it detracts more than it adds. Sounds are often looped poorly, or too quickly, and random lines of subtitle are all-capsed or just ill-fitting to the voice acting, which is pretty good- they had a surprisingly large cast for such a small game.On to the good: I wouldn't be so hard on the game if it wasn't one that I really liked, and this game has one of the most honest portrayals of depression that I've ever witnessed in a game, and a storyline that was refreshing and relatable. It doesn't hit everyone in the same way, but I personally felt invested in the story and sympathetic to Susan, who, though you can play her in several different ways, has a storyline that always makes sense. I felt, despite the supernatural elements, that she was a fairly realistic person and I regard the game fondly enough to get my friends to play it. TL;DR, mediocre visuals, good plot. Quick play and definitely worth it.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 4, 2015
												Wow. This game, is just amazing. It's one of those games that takes you for a ride on the emotional rollercoaster. What is "The Cat Lady" exactly? When I first got this game, I wasn't really surprised, even the name was kinda plain for me, didn't really catch my attention. I was expecting some kind of survival horror 2-D game like The Lone Survivor, but I was wrong. It's more like....It feels like Clock Tower, for example.The cat lady is like one of those old point and click games, minus the pointing and clicking, because you move around and interact with stuff using your keyboard. It's not quite a survival horror game like I thought, it's got it's scary parts, but I wouldn't go as far to call it like that. It feels more like a psychological kind of game. And man, it doesn't fail at that. You are Susan Ashworth, a lonely, severely depressed woman who tried to commit suicide at the beggining of the game. As you progress, you'll find out why, and what made her feel like she did.Now, let's talk about the points of this game.+ The visuals. The graphics are gritty, almost comic like, they are pretty good, and most of the time, the atmosphere and the backgrounds are haunting, dark and scary, or just plain depresing with lots of gray and black. That's something I love!+ The music is amazing. You get both instrumental songs, and songs with lyrics that are haunting and sorrowful. The whole soundtrack of this game is definitely worth it, you should give it a try even if you don't play the game.+ The plot, characters, and character development. As I said before, it's one of those emotional rollercoaster kind of games, sometimes you can even feel the depression and loneliness of the main character, it makes you think about suicide, not as in killing yourself, it makes you think about suicide as in why it happens, what drives somebody to try to take his or her own life, and what makes somebody cling to life with a smile on their face. I don't wanna spoil anything, but I just wanna say that this was top notch.+ Voice Acting. It's pretty damn good, or at least, so I think. It's quite soothing at times, emotional at others.+ The endings. Powerful enough, even if they were mostly text based in the form of a last narration. - To be fair, I encountered a few technical issues now and then. For example, (correct me if I'm wrong), you can't overwrite save files, so, I had saves like "Save 1, Save 2, Save 3", so on, and so on 'til 30 or so. Also, I encountered some kind of issue, I inspected something, snatched a knife, accidentally inspected it again, and it made my game crash. I didn't save, so I had to backtrack all the way to that point again. It isn't really disruptive, if you don't intentionally or accidentally inspect certain items twice.- It seems like you cannot change the resolution. (Correct me if I'm wrong)- This game suffers from some framerate issues, that are only worsened by the fog in some parts of the game. Most of the time, it's just mild FPS lag, nothing too bad. BUT, there comes a point where you are outside of your apartment with fog all around it. My god. The framerates dropped so bad, that something that would be like 1 minute long took me like 5 or so. Dead serious. Thank goodness, it only happened at that specific point of the game on chapter 3? If I'm correct? All in all, this game is definitely worth it, it's not particularly challenging, other than basic problem solving skills most of the time, and the plot and plot twists are amazing. Try it for yourself, if you are into games like this, perhaps like clock tower, you won't be dissapointed.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
												I thought the game looked a little off when I first watched a trailer of it, but the art style was so unique, I was incredibly intrigued. That, and who can pass up a game called 'The Cat Lady' when you are almost a cat lady yourself? So I went in with unsure expectations, but was incredibly blown away. I was not expecting the game to be as dark as it was, despite that it's correctly labeled as horror. But as a massive fan of any horror games, I loved it. There's a good amount of gore, and graphic images of suicide. But they aren't done for a 'shock' factor as much as elegantly explaining the story. The voice-acting is gorgeous and what music is noticeable matches the dark atmosphere of the game perfectly. There are multiple endings for the choices you make in the game. I commonly list this game as my favorite unknown/underrated game without hesitation. It's gorgeous, and incredibly well done. I'll be definitely playing 'Downfall' [the prequel game] and hope for more games by the same people/team soon!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 28, 2014
												This is a good game. I really liked the writing. If nothing else this is worth buying for the writing alone. Add to it that the soundtrack is simply amazing and you have a really good adventure game experience. I found myself thinking about the plot lines and what the plot brought up during the day. This game did what a good game like it should do. It got me engaged in the story.It's not perfect though. The puzzles aren't challenging at all. Also the game is just about one of the ugliest games I've seen. I fooled myself into thinking that the game was purposefully artsy ugly for all of about ten seconds before I decided that it was just straight up ugly. Especially the character models. It sort of works with the type of story that it is and the subject matter, but that doesnt' really make it any better to look at.There is some middle ground too. The voice acting is odd. Some of it is stellar, some of it is awful. The quality of the voice recordings varies pretty greatly too. Some people seem to have done their dialogue through a tin can while others must have had a legit recording set-up.The flaws are pretty minor in comparisson with what is a great story. If you love to read, love coffee, love cats, love thinking about the sad things in life, love questioning what's in it all, and just in general love a good bit of game writing try this out.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
												The Cat lady is a graphic adventure that will plunge you into the mind of a suicidal woman named Susan Ashworth. The way this game conveys the feeling of anxiety, loneliness and depression to the player can just be classified as masterful. All the choices made by the developers are just so right that they must be mentioned: the music, the art, the style of the gaming mechanics, the horrifying images and demential scenes, and the whole setting of the game itself, are just wonderfully executed. There are even some quite funny as well as interesting touches of humor that will make you at least smile sometimes.Overall, this game isn't an AAA production, that's for sure, but it doesn't really need to be so. The creators of The Cat Lady clearly know how to adjust the correct screws in order to unscrew your own mind and submerge you into a greatly reproduced dark atmosphere. Let's just say that it will sometimes probably tear your mind a little with some really crazy stuff. Transmitting emotions through a videogame is not an easy task, and that's why it must be praised when a little piece of art like this is found.I definitely recommend playing The Cat Lady, but only if you like deep stories in the form of graphic adventures. FPS-only players might (most definitely) find this game boring. Anyway, if you are like me and enjoy a slow-developing, deep story, prepare for a few good hours of gaming. And I won't say anything else, because playing and experiencing the game for yourself is the best way to understand what I'm trying to say (and I don't want to spoil the best parts, either).Final appraisal: 8.5/10

content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												(I played a DRM-free version of the game and got a steam key after finishing it, when it got greenlit, that's why it shows almost no playtime)(+There's a summary in the end of the review)The Cat Lady is one of the more twisted and extraordinary adventure games I got the chance to play.Actually, I played the demo first, which does give you the sense of "bizarrity" of the game, but it really surprised me that the main character is a bitter, suicidal woman.And that's in a way what the game revolves around, the cat lady, whose life feels like there's no point in it anymore.This is a very unusual subject for video games, and the content is very unusual accordingly, and as a rule this game has a very adult story and content.The game looks very simplistic, but it is pretty impressive for an indie game. Without too much budget (I guess) and without too much 'technology' (The game is made with the AGS engine whose style is of the old-classic adventure games), the developers created a fascinating world, with interesting characters, bizzare storyline, and creepy atmosphere which would easily humiliate some mediocre horror video games.I found the story a bit complicated, you can't always tell what's 'real' and what's in Susan's (the main character) head, you can't fully understand all the details and their meaning (or at least I didn't on my first playthrough) but that made it all the more interesting, and would make me play the game again sometime, just to experience it again.I found the voice acting not so good at times, but considering the rest of the game's aspects, it's forgivable and doesn't hurt much the experience. I was quite content with the gameplay, at first it seemed too simple, but the puzzles were good enough to keep you busy for a while (they weren't hard, but also weren't that obvious). Unlike other classic adventure\AGS games, it's not the same old point-n'-click interface, but a bit different (and well explained in the game), and completely cancels the pixel-hunting which I really don't like in adventure games.There were only two things which REALLY annoyed me in the game:1)Illusion of choices, at some points in the game's dialogues you have different options to choose, so different that you'd imagine it could affect the outcome of your actions and the way the game continues. That's not true, and it could be a very nice addition to the game. The only point where your choices does matter is in the last chapter of the game, where you can get a couple of slightly different ending depending on what you chose earlier.2)A technical problem - you have limitation for 50 saves only. Maybe some people wouldn't need so much slots anyway, but I did save quite often. And then suddenly, without any warning, you can't save anymore, with no explanation in the game itself! I had to google around to find out what's the problem. And in addition, you cannot delete you saved game in the game itself (I found no way to do that), you'll have to manually locate the saved games in your computer and delete some or most of them. That's a serious problem, which I assume won't be fixed.Summary:+Bizzare, interesting, deep story about human feelings and depression, with great conclusion and a message+Simple yet great atmosphere, great psychological horror environment+Good graphics and soundtrack+Good gameplay mechanics, no need to pixel-hunt that missing object+Interesting characters+Nice puzzles+More than one ending-You may not get the entire story on the first time-Very linear although it seems like it isn't-Mediocre voice acting at time-Some minor graphical glitches (very few)-50 saves limitation, no option to delete saved game in-game

												This game was a surprising, an unexpectedly jarring. The visual style was quite jarring, but very effective.The sound seemed spot on.The narrative came across as a bit confusing and haphazard at first, but as the game went on things tied together.Going between the other and real world gave the whole game a very surreal quality.The ending- whichever one you get- ends up touching a very tender part of one's heart.
