content:
Posted: October 28, 2016
												The Cat Lady is a great old-school-style story/adventure game!(I would say "point and click game", but there is no pointing or clicking.  You use the arrow keys along with the return key to play the game, spacebar to speed up dialogue, and escape key to bring up load/save menu etc...)Your character, (Susan), starts the game by attempting suicide, but instead of dying, she is given immortality by "The Queen of Maggots".  "The Queen" demands that you first kill off 5 "Parasites" before she will let you die.   Susan is deeply depressed and just wants to not exist anymore.  Having no choice but to carry out the mission "The Queen of Maggots" demands of her, Susan is brought back to life and your story begins to unfold as the game progresses from there...I'll go ahead and let you know that this game is more story than actual gameplay, but there are enough puzzles to be solved to keep you on your toes and entertained.  There are also many different choices in choosing dialogue when talking to other characters which in some instances alters the story a bit.  (I need to replay it and see what all I can change up in the story.)  The story is very entertaining.  The graphics are not anywhere near "next gen", but for a game like this, it looks great.   The sound/voice acting is great.  The music is great.  The puzzles in the game are just hard enough to make you scratch your head a bit before you figure it out.  Now the bad news about The Cat Lady is that it's set in low resolution and I'm not sure if you really can set it to 1080p etc..  My monitor is native 1080p and The Cat Lady does load up in full screen for me, but just low resolution.  Oh well.  It just makes this dark twisted game look even grittier.  Some more bad news is that in certain instances the game lags.  (Trust me, my computer shouldn't lag playing this game.)  It's only a few parts that lagged briefly anyway though.   Another minor gripe I have is that you cannot delete your save game files within the game menu (At least with the default version of the game from Steam).  I was reading about patching it to fix this issue, but I haven't done so yet.  You may want to go ahead and patch the game yourself before playing it.All in all, I would highly recomend getting The Cat Lady!  It's a great adventure/story game that should not be overlooked by anyone who likes this genre of gaming!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												THE TEAL DEER REVIEW: The game is great surreal fun until the end, at which point it falls short of finishing its own story. It shines brightest at art, the plot (until the end), and its ability to explore states of consciousness. The game is at its worst technically and during its finale, making this a 4 out of 5 star game for me--the mechanics problems were incredibly intrusive during the game, and while the concept, art, and music are unique, even brilliant, the end was annoying as hell.It's worth playing, but I hope the development team continues to hone its skills before publishing another game. They should be encouraged to keep developing, but need more experience before making full use of the concepts and resources they've created.THE LONG-AS-HELL REVIEW: It's hard to write a concise description of this game, which is no small feat in the gaming market. It's definitely horror, it's highly psychological, and it's a point-and-click. Past that point, however, it's hard to say what this game is. It could be an exploration of what it's like to be suicidally depressed (and, in fact, it raised goosebumps on me repeatedly by the degree to which the characters acted exactly like someone suicidally depressed.)It could be an exploration of what it's like to be horrifically unlucky. The chain of coincidence surrounding Susan manages to be both catastrophic and plausible, itself no small feat. When you find out why she hates flowers, you'll know what I'm talking about. Life has beaten Susan down to the point that she is, in essence, a shell of a person for the first chapter.It could be an exploration of how little trying to be a good person actually effects your life. Susan is not a bad person (and in fact, tries in her own way to do good, even though she doesn't always succeed.) She is capable of and does engage in acts of vengeance both petty and not-so-petty, as well as fighting back physically against various other characters. In the end, however, Susan only manages to do a little good in a very dark set of situations. As a character reminds her late in the game, life is not fair, and we cannot always understand or anticipate the results of our actions.It could be a surreal exploration of states of consciousness. From background props to puzzles, the game is highly surreal, partnering more photorealistic images to strange, disorted dolls, grayscale human figures and the occasional splash of color. Susan's state of mind is echoed in the distortions of her environment, the dull gray of much of the scenery, and the vivid gore of the puzzles. The puzzles themselves are often built around methods of self-harm, and the scenery makes it clear that she is unable to find the peace she seeks, right up until the end of the game.It could even be about the kind of bonding people who are broken do with one another, how people with bitter, broken lives learn to care about each other.If I had to sum the game up in a few words, I would say that it is an exploration of suicidal depression, and of the seductive madness that goes with it. If you've ever listened to "Paint it Black" and empathized entirely, you can fully understand Susan's state of mind (and will probably need to stop the game and do something else on occasion for the sake of your sanity.)Where the game explores that state of mind, it is brilliant.The plot, however, moves into other themes as the game goes on. When it does, it starts to experience problems, particularly where the plot tries to deal with redemption. Parts of the thematic choices are spot-on, but they are surrounded by what seems like an attempt to make a neat end on a messy and rather endless process. While the ending acknowledges this explicitly, the characters themselves don't seem to empathize with, understand, or even feel in any significant fashion the lines of dialog they have been given.Or, to put it another way, I don't believe that Susan cares about her "friend" or that she would be able to resolve the ending. Her rage and depression are crystal clear. Everything else is murky and/or not believeable.The end comes on like a wreck--you don't see it coming, and considering the content, you should.Mechanically speaking, the game moves like molasses. Characters pause, the game freezes for a few seconds, the characters are very slow to respond to cues, and various other performance-related issues caused small but irritating stoppages in my gaming experience. I'm playing this with a one-month old NVIDIA GTX 660, 16 GB of RAM and an AMD Phenom II (6 cores), with appropriate and up to date drivers for the NVIDIA--I doubt very much the performance issues are hardware related.The game does NOT autosave for you, and you will need to maintain your progress yourself. Unlike other reviewers, I didn't mind this. I've played too many old games to be bothered by a lack of autosave, and typically save games myself as a matter of course.The graphics and art themselves are an interesting mixture of what looks like stock art, MS paint-esque figures, photos and what appears to be stock textures. The net result is a bit like the work of Dave McKean, though less polished. The whole, while a bit chaotic to the eye, is not displeasing and has the effect of reinforcing story themes.Musically, I was reminded a little of certain early NIN tracks. The music did, at intervals, function to reinforce themes. However, the chapter endings were a bit indulgent of the soundtrack. As a result, while the soundtrack was pleasant, it was a bit overpowering of the story, and should have been less emphasized in the course of chapter endings.The script was rife with grammar errors of various descriptions, which made me cringe a bit during major scenes.I am comfortable recommending this based on the originality of the game, but I have to note that the developers need more practice. I will continue to buy games produced by these developers, crossing my fingers that the elements I've noticed had problems continue to be a focus for improvement from them.This game, when it's on point, is amazing.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												I 100%´ed the game today and well... totaly worth it.Before we get to all the nice stuff, let´s get the crapy things out of the way. There were several things bugging me through the hole game. First of all: the synchronization. I´m totaly fine with the voice actors though they sound bored sometimes but the soundquality is horrible. Everytime a person shouts, it hurt´s to listen. If you play the game, I recommand to lower the volume. Second thing that bugs me is the soundtrack. In some parts of the game the soundtrack contains vocals. Maybe it´s just me but somehow these feel unfitting. Not becouse it´s not my kind of music but because they (at least in my case) drag the attention from the game to the soundtrack itself. I would have prefered a more ambient kind of sound on these parts. The controls also need some time to get used to it and even if you get used to it... it feels clunky...Now that these mainissues are out the way let´s get to the awesome stuff! If there is one thing I like in games it´s a good story. And I appreciate a good story even more when it´s not afraid to touch more mature and serious subjects just as depression, suicide and how a good written character deals with these things. On first sight it might bother that nearly everything is just black and grey with a little bit of white here and there but I liked it that way. It underlines perfectly how Susan, the protagonist, views the world. Of cause there are colors but they are usually rare and as a result, they get a special meaning this way. You will know then you see it.I´d also like to mention that "Harvester Games", the Devs, have also made two other games in the same style (someone did some research here xD). The first one is "Downfall" (original from 2009 but the game get´s a remake 2015) and "Lorelai" is supposed to get in production once the remake of Downfall is done. Don´t know about you guys but I will play these these two. ^^

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
Crude, but worth it - story for adultsThis one is really hard to review or recommend - most people are just going to be turned off by the crude graphics and clumsy controls. But if you can get past that, you've never played a point and click adventure like this, I promise. It's adult - in the thematic sense. The graphics are ugly, the people are ugly, the themes and the things that happen are really disturbing...  but in the end I felt really positive about it, and this is the sort of thing you're just never going to see in another video game, and you can never experience something quite like this in another medium.Somebody wrote a good story, and then by god, did the best they could to present it. It's got some technical rough edges, and it breaks all the rules, but you can feel the heart. This is about as indie as it gets, and the soundtrack is quite good.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												Very well-written adventure/horror game right here. I'd say the strengths are especially in the characters, as they really do make the story as effective as it is. The puzzles are also pretty good, not resorting to moon logic and keeping tasks simple without ever directly pointing you to the answer, as well as taking full advantage of the environments. If I had to say one thing against it, the pacing can be a bit wonky at times, especially chapters 4 and 5. Still, glad I played it, as it's a good though not amazing adventure game. The music's wonderful too and the art style works really well despite the low-quality animations; it helps more than it detracts, really.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												If you can stomach gore and themes of suicide and depression, please play this game. It's sure to get you hooked and definitely worth the money. It's a point-and-click adventure, but without the pointing and clicking - it uses simple keyboard controls (you will only need the arrow keys, enter and esc) which take some time getting used to, but it also means there's no pixel hunting involved. Just a heads up so you know what to expect. From what I hear, there's multiple endings and it definitely has some decisions that are for you to make, but even without trying to get all the endings, you'll be busy for at least 6-7 hours.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												This game is very good 7.5/10. It is very uplifting if you play to be a good person, there isn't really a moral choice system but rather a work hard system. This looks at the crippling pain those who live with depression suffer from, and does the job very well. This game is well made only irritating me once or twice because it thought i wanted to interact with someone a foot in the other direction but they were very much the minority. The game does also suffer from adventure game logic meaning you can go back and forth for a screwdriver because a knife won't work for prying something open. This did irritate me but really I ordered an adventure game so maybe I should have expected that. It did ruin the flow of the game on occassion however and that I was not happy with.The game's story is a double edged sword. It is deep, dark and very open. Most of the time I would wander through the game marvelling at the level art, I was terrified and shocked in some scenes when you see the depravity and horror that the Cat Lady works on. Other times however the dialogue goes on forever, you can't pause during the dialogue and it feels completely disconnected from the story that you are currently working towards. I had a scene that lasted for twenty minutes and couldn't pause, luckily my gf was able to answer the door and phone that both needed attention during this time. The game would be well served from warning you. Seriouly though. The story is fantastic. It honestly shocked me deep down with a wonderfully written story. The story and the aesthetic make up for everything else that I have been really petty in complaining about. This is fantastic, the level design is awesome, the otherworldiness of the design is reminscent of Giger without being all sexual and creepy. Awesome game for those who want some complexity in their gaming time.Get this game, it is very exciting. I recently played Wolfenstein: The New Order, The Amazing Spiderman 2, Dark Souls and Thief alongside this. I only enjoyed this and Dark Souls so infinitely more worth your time despite it being a 2-D adventure game.Run down for those who care about scores-1 for adventure game logic running the flow-1 for long dialogue-.5 for not having pause always available.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												Highly, highly recommend this game.  The story and characters are among the best of any game I have ever played.  It is impossible not to become emotionally involved with the characters due to excellently written dialogue and good voice acting, accompanied with an amazing musical scoreThe game is reminiscent of a great book that you cannot put down, and I found myself looking forward to dialogue in a game, something I do not think I have done since older rpg games.Controls simple, but effective, and puzzles are always very logical so you do not spend time frustrated.A must have for many types of people•	Those who love story driven games•	Those who enjoy darker games or enjoy dark comedy•	Those who just love great gamesI would also recommend this to people who suffer from mental illness, and in particular, depression, as the game itself examines it in such detail.  However, on the other hand if you feel uncomfortable with the illness, or talking about suicide, this game is definitely not for you.I can guarantee, if you get into this amazing game, you will not be able to put it down.  On a personal note, I play many games, and this is one of the very few that struck such a cord with me.  I really could not put it down.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												To put it simply, The Cat Lady is the kind of breath of fresh air that the Indie game community needs in the midst of the endless zombie survival shooters (gag).  This game has a different approach to horror; one that creeps slowly into your chest as the world you inhabit becomes increasingly more oppressive and surreal.  The moments of action are brief (par for the course for these kinds of adventure games), but the build-up to each is tense.  The best feature, however, is the story: heartwrenching, engaging, mature, and utterly unforgettable.The only complaints are with the presentation: in particular, the sound design and the user interface.  While the music is absolutely brilliant (though I could have done without the lyrical tracks), the transitions between different scene themes don't have any fades or blends, making them quite jarring and sometimes ruining the mood.  The voice actors sound like they were recorded using cheap webcam microphones, and a couple of them sounded like complete amateurs.  The user interface is not the most intuitive, either; you can't delete or overwrite saves, so you end up having dozens of save files in your folder by the end of the game.Apart from these quips, the core of the game - the story - is nonetheless stellar, and I would recommend it to anyone looking for an affecting experience.  Just know that it truly does earn its 'M' rating - if you're not mature enough to be interested by the themes explored in this game (depression, suicide, the value of life and the price to save it), then you should pass.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												This game is a fantastic exploration of some of the deepest life's problems and strongest emotions. Susan Ashworth is The Cat Lady with a very deep seated rage which has created her morbid depression. Her own depression saves her in a strange way when she commits suicide but comes back to life.Facing her deep rage she confronts the most wicked people in the world, those with a sheer hatred of all things good, and engorging themselves on the destruction of the most precious in life, people (in fact, literally in some cases). In this point-and-click adventure game, solving puzzles to deal learn about the truth of life and the truth of evil, Susan grows and becomes a stronger person, until she finally finds her calling in the world, which redeems her and finally gives her hope to live... a thought she was entirely convinced could not be possible.This game doesn't deal with evil in the ways most other pieces of their genres do. Most games have ruthless villaines that do more than just be an irritating jaugernaut. Rather, it deals more in depth with what evil truly is. The people she must face are true bona fide psychopaths.The gore of this game makes sense. I wouldn't ordinarily play a gory game, but because of the philosophical nature, it's excusable. It's rather shocking however, throughout almost the entire game. A user only gets a brief relief from the horror.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												The Cat Lady is one of the most meaningful games I have encountered in a long time.The main character, Susan Ashworth, is easy to connect to. Despite her age, past, and living conditions, I believe anyone could find a connection with her. Especially those who have stuggled with depression and suicide. A game that explores the deeper meaning of an end, the effects it has on others, and brings it all together in a way to show a worth of a person's existence, good or bad. Each person is a piece in this life, as every character in this game has a point of being in it. Some may complain about the graphics, audio, or physical gameplay. I, myself however, believe it adds to the charm of it. Pops of colour are surprising and comforting, as well as they can be disturbing. The Cat Lady has many elements which make it a worth while game to devote some time to. 8 Chapters can be completed in roughly 8 hours, making this game easy to complete. It has multiple endings to discover, and the truest ending leaves the biggest impact.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												Short and sweet: 7/10Pros:-Fantastic storyline-Interesting art form-Very atmospheric without the need of jumpscaresCons:-The animation, as stated before, is an aquired taste. Very choppy and almost cheap looking, but nonetheless interesting.-The game saving. There is no option to override a save, as far as I've found, and instead you must sequentually title your saves (Save1,Save2,etc.). On top of that, if you don't save often, you can get stuck at your last save, and in my case lose the items in your inventory making it impossible to finish-The graphics configuration. Trying to find the correct setting for your monitor is fairly difficult, considering there's no cut and dry "1920 x 1080" mode.-Often very slow gameplay, your mind is 20 feet ahead of how fast the character can walk, making it very frustrating.Overall the gameplay outweighs the cons.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												A great adventure through cerebral awareness and unawareness of your own cognitive psychology...   I do suffer depression and can relate to this game well...  it is a very abruptly shocking yet thought provoking story into the mind of what really happens on the rollercoaster of life in mind of a person who is severely depressed or suicidal.  You won't really get the message until the end... this isn't a game for entertainment... it is an tale of elightenment and awakening...  with both harsh realities and crazed mental fantasies that fill all the voids...    Well done to everyone who created this...  Now I am wanting to listen to the soundtrack... this is something that will always stick with me now until I die...

												There are no proper words to describe the experience of playing this. It's very difficult to play, there are parts where you can get stumped and you spend more time in this game trying to figure it out to get to the next level. However, I think the graphics, the story, the characters all were perfect. It's not a long game nor too short and the music really added to the tone of the game. This game wasn't much scary as it was creepy- definitely interesting and fun to play. Captures the players focus on an emotional level and keeps you immersed as you resolve each task. More than just a game, it is a work of art. Well worth the 10$ would greatly recommend anyone to get this game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
												This is my first review as a steam user, and I've decided I'm not going to say a whole lot about the game as it may spoil things. So from my angle, I'd have to say the story is one that is shrouded in darkness, darkness that fills peoples souls that are chronically depressed. The way the graphics keep everything gelled together, dark, black and white, with one of the only colors being red and blue (hint,hint) is truly interesting. As I write this, It seems Jimi Hendrix has found himself on my radio with his song "Manic Depression". I guess this is a coincidence...So a game I would recommend. A dark atmosphere, puzzles throughout are not mind busting, or too breezy, just average i would say. If you seek out games that have a high difficulty to them, then you won't find them in this game. The puzzles just come and go, basically. So the player moves from side-to side either solving a puzzle or speaking with someone, obviously.Between the really great voice-acting (The actors themselves can be found on facebook, twitter etc.) The truly interesting journey to the end of the story, as well as the bonus inclusion of acheivements and trading cards, this game is worth the purchase. Also, I found the music terrific, as much as i enjoyed the voice-acting. I found myself on the "Start" screen many times getting ready for a session, And i would just listen to the music that plays on this screen...very melancholic. I discovered there is a put-together soundtrack offering of this game, unfortunately though, the only place i could find it was on iTunes. A bit dissapointing for my as I prefer my music to be at least CD quality...So yeah, check this one out. If you could do for something dark and a bit twisted without being unoriginal, then why dont you play this.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												This game is different in tone compared to the other games that I have played lately. The Cat Lady follows a woman named Susan who's recently, successfully, committed suicide. She makes a deal with "The Queen of Maggots" in which she has to kill these people called "Parasites". They're horrendous people who purposely intend to harm others without regret.The game has a good atmosphere, and an interesting plot (although I have noticed there are some mistakes in time/plotholes while playing it). The voice acting, I'll be honest, is bad. The best character, in my opinion, was probably the Pest Control Man, and he was only temporarily introduced in the game. I may be making an issue out of nothing, but when the characters don't sound genuine, it almost takes you out of it a little bit. Mitzi sounds like Lindsey Lohan as the British twin from The Parent Trap.The atmosphere is nice, the puzzles are challenging, and the overall message of the game is worth getting to know. I would recommend it, but with this tip in mind: Once you're done reading the subtitles of the character's dialogue, press the space bar. It skips the actual voice part.

												Well written. Very sad. Very, very sad. The engine it runs on is a little buggy, dated, nonresponsive, etc. But if you can get past the technical flaws (that isn't hard) and the somewhat sub-par voice acting (Also, surprisingly not hard) you're in for an emotional rollercoaster you probably won't necessarily enjoy, but you'll be glad you rode. Posted: February 23
												This game was mediocre for me. The game got a bit boring at times, too. There is no sprinting, so movement can become monotonous. The voice acting can be a bit stiff and hamfisted at times, too. Plus, the characters and their interactions can feel inorganic at times, too. Finally, some of the twists and surprises in this game did not get enough foreshadowing. However, some of the ideas in this game were very brilliant. If you like analyzing games on a literary level, then you will probably like this game. Generally, the game is good, so I guess I cant identify why I got bored. Maybe, because the play sessions were too long. Otherwise, I cant think of anymore faults this game has, and this review sucks so I should end it ASAP.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												What a miserable game. The entire tone is downbeat, depressing and pessimistic. But I don't mean that in a bad way. It's nice to have a game which isn't all sunshine and rainbows.People say that the topics this game presents are realistic and dealt with in a mature, helpful way. I really can't comment on that as it's not something I've been exposed to.The Cat Lady is refreshingly different and interesting to play through, but I do sometimes feel that the game is being gory and revolting just for the sake of it. The side characters are shallow, unlikeable and not very well developed, with the one exception of the companion you acquire part-way through.The controls are awkward and clunky, and could be grossly simplified.However, it is an interesting story and is worth having a look through. Just... don't play it if you're feeling a bit down or hopeless, as it will not give you a good outlook on life.

content:
Posted: April 22, 2015
												Play this game with headphones and in a dark room for full effect. I highly suggest playing it this way - it is literally like a different experience.The Cat Lady is a highly stylistic and atmospheric adventure game that is very dark and has some disturbing imagery and themes. It's not quite a horror game - I was never really scared - no jump scares - but rather, the game is creepy. Creepy music, creepy art, creepy story.Most of the game you sort of walk about environments as the 40-year-old-woman protagonist, Susan. She has tried to commit suicide and.... it sends her on quite the journey.Gameplay consists of walking around as Susan solving various puzzles and a lot of cutscenes/dialogue. The game is very much story-driven - I think of it more as a sort of interactive story than a "game" really. The game has multiple endings and your decisions and dialogue determine what happens and clocks in at around 8-10 hours.If you're into good, dark stories and can bear playing a game that isn't really "game-y", I really think The Cat Lady is quite the experience. The best adventure game I've ever played, by a long-shot. The story is a dark drama - there are dramatic moments to be had. Wouldn't be hard to shed a tear during the game in quite a few spots, but especially the end. Not a lot of games can make me feel that way.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
												Overall, I really enjoyed this game, despite its sometimes uneven pacing, tedious dialogue, and apparently random interactions.  It's dark and moody (which was one of its best features) but also has a hopeful message. Some of the scenes are cringe-inducing (yeah, torture) while others are inexplicable (the long interview with the psychologist), but ultimately this is a story worth experiencing for yourself.  The characters keep things interesting, the voice acting is good, and the puzzles are fun.It's also a visually appealing game (not beautiful, but very nice) that has an interesting graphical style. The interface is clunky at times (mainly when trying to manipulate objects) but not so much that it's a distraction.  If you enjoy story-rich games, especially moody and atmospheric ones, you'll almost certainly enjoying experiencing this one. It's probably worth it at $9.99, but it would definitely be a bargain at any less than that.

Posted: March 8, 2016
												First of all, this game is pretty weird. It deals with the subject of suicide and depression. Even though I played the entire game, it really was not a great game. I mainly played it because I paid for it! I purchased it after reading some of the reviews because many people seemed to like this game. I guess the best part of it is that it is a unsual, different game with a lot of symbolism and creepy images and I suppose there is some type of real meaning the developers had in mind, but I stopped trying to figure it out after a while because the game went in so many weird directions it became sort of non-sensical.  Cons1.The game crashed a number of times when I first started playing. I had to keep restarting (but at least the game saves where you leave off) so eventually I was able to play without too many problems after the intitial crashes.2. The graphics are pretty shoddy ..although since the game theme is suicide and depression, I guess the graphics worked to some degree.   3. Moving is EXTREMELY SLOW. This was the worst part of this game for me. It takes forever to move ..which makes the game verrrrrry long and draggy.Beware, if you haven't already contemplated killing yourself, you will after this game!  YES, REALLY.

												An unexpectedly wonderful adventure game.The first thing that stands out at you is the offbeat art style. Initially it put me off the game, however as I continued playing I started accepting it for what it was and seeing that there is real depth here with how it can convey a character's emotional state on such a basic level.What is most assuredly the high point of the game is story, that is what will keep you interested. The puzzle solving is most of the time quite basic and is there to provide some simple obstacles so the game doesn't turn into a virtual novel.And for an adventure game there is some surprising amount of choice involved, while there isn't anything which would completely alter your story, there are some significant choices which keep the game from being on rails the way most adventure games are.8 ½ / 10

number of helpful: 10 of 23 people (43%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
												When I saw the first comparison to Planescape, I was surprised. When I saw 5 more, I nearly vomited blood. Compounded with all the 5-star reviews, I could only wonder if I played an entirely different game that also happened to be called The Cat Lady.Like 99% of people who buy this, I was attracted by the visual and thematic grittiness. Unlike 99% of people who then reviewed it, I was unimpressed after seeing that the grit was nothing more than a veneer, obscuring unconvincingly delivered acting and an utterly shallow treatment of the themes of depression and suicide, which act as little more than vehicles for plot progression rather than subjects explored in ANY depth or commented upon meaningfully.Even the plodding monotone in which the protagonist speaks screams shallowness. Depressed people aren't husks, incapable of voice modulation. The monotone should have been used where it made sense and not as a constant and incredibly tactless means of perpetuating some half-baked atmosphere.The writing was barely serviceable in some parts and immersion-breakingly full of exposition in others. Susan's evolution as a character is definitely told and not shown, making changes feel forced and unexpected. Showing without telling is one of the top things that distinguishes good writing from bad.The puzzles were, for the most part, so straight forward, they may as well have prompted you to "click around on the screen while we artificially and meaninglessly extend your play time".The art style was reminiscent of that found in Scary Stories to Tell in the Dark. The individual pieces were, for the most part, well done, but often assembled somewhat thoughtlessly.Clearly the majority is content to just be fed "dark subject matter" even if it's at the most superficial level. If you're looking for some depth, there isn't any to plumb here.

number of helpful: 9 of 21 people (43%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 18, 2014
												The Cat Lady is an adventure game where you take on the role of Susan Ashworth, an old demented lady right after her life being saved from attempting suicide by downing sleeping pills. While the paramedics are fighting to keep her alive, she meets "The Queen of Maggots" on another world, who prevents her from dying and tasks her with killing "parasites" who would try to harm her. To help her with this endeavor, The Queen of Maggots grants her the power of immortality, much to the suicidal lady's dismay.The art style initially threw me off. I realize that it is by design that the game tries to keep you uncomfortable, but it's off-putting nonetheless especially since the game doesn't even run on 1080p. The sound design is also noticeably cheap as you hear the static when voice actors talk. I'm not going to lie, this is a terrible game when judging on technical merits.Once you get to the end of the first chapter, however, you will understand that this is not your regular point-and-click adventure game and why you need to forgive it for its shortcomings.It focuses on dark themes that is very rarely explored in other media. Video games, movies and books included. Themes on suicide, depression, dementia,♥♥♥♥♥♥ and cannibalism are prevalent and it's all wrapped under the most unsuspecting game name ever. Would you expect any of that when you first hear the title "The Cat Lady"?The gameplay is your standard point-and-click, except you're actually controlling a person's movements. There are puzzles that are basically "think-like-the-developer" puzzles where you "bang two sticks together and hope something happens" but none of them are too out of this world that it would take you more than a few seconds. That's one of the major problems I have with adventure game "puzzles", but I didn't find that while playing this game. If you do get stuck, I'd encourage the use of a spoiler-free walkthrough. You'd understand while you're playing it that the game is worth seeing through the very end anyway.Oh, and you play as a cat for a few minutes. YOU PLAY AS A CAT!This is a game you NEED to play if you love a good story. It resonated with me almost closely to the way To The Moon did. I've always been more of a fan of story in video games. I'd forgive gameplay as long as the story is up to par. The story of this game, however, is not just up to par. It's a hole-in-one.The Cat Lady is beautiful. The Cat Lady is art.

												I cannot figure out what people see in this game. It has favorable reviews, but I cannot think of a single part that made me happy I was playing this game. The characters are absolutely boring, the story never follows a path, never truly resolves, and seems to be a platter of random events haphazardly stitched together to give the illusion of a narrative. There is simply no pacing to be had. The exposition you're given makes no sense, has no purpose, and never goes anywhere. Things happen for no reason at all. An overwhelmingly poor stab at the subject matter.The voice acting is awful, the music only fits half of the time, and the random rock songs forced into the game are cringy at best. The only real redeemer this game has is the settings and backgrounds. The animations seem to follow a specific style, but it's far from pleasant. The "jump scares" are dreadful and poorly placed. Things simply take way too long to happen and the majority of the "gameplay" is just waiting for scenes to happen, whether it be useless and boring dialogue that doesn't pertain to the plot, needless animations, or pauses in scenes that were added to produce tension but end up falling flat on their face. I should at least mention the controls. The menu system is irritating. You have to press down to access your inventory on the bottom, enter to select an item, then up and down to browse actions with enter confirming the action. It sounds standard, but when you combine it with pressing up to interact, left and right to move, and enter to progress dialogue, it becomes a mess when you're doing multiple things at once. You end up having to stop everything and just take it one keystroke at a time. It should have had separate controls (like ACTUAL POINT AND CLICK), but I guess it's bearable. It doesn't ruin the experience like everything else does, but it definitely bothered me enough to physically sigh more times than I care to admit.Apparently there are multiple endings, but when I'm never given a reason to care about the characters and the story hardly exists, there's just zero replayability and I had to force myself to finish. I thought, "Maybe there's more to it, maybe it will all make sense when I finish." Not at all. People keep saying that it has genuine feeling and portrays human nature pretty well, but that could not be farther from the truth. Character emotions are like a lottery, and people will randomly change their entire demeanor without cause just for the sake of moving the story along. The only parts that were remotely enjoyable were the "action sequences" that I don't want to spoil, but they did a good job of displaying what this point and click game SHOULD have been. Only 15% of this game is even worth playing, and if the developers had actually sat down to think about how they should make a game, they could have easily rewrote it all to be just as good all the way through. It feels like an odd combination of lazy, uninformed, and "let's try to be edgy" writing. I am extremely disappointed in this purchase, and I cannot express my displeasure accurately.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
												While undeniably atmospheric and thought-provoking - in many ways more than almost any other game in recent years - The Cat Lady just isn't functional enough for me to recommend it. The gameplay is ponderous, the interface is unwieldy, and I too often had to fall back to the community forums to learn just what obscure trick I was supposed to employ in order to progress. I should note here that I did not bother to finish the game, as I didn't find it worth the frustration. That said, if you prioritize story, atmosphere, and/or philosophical engagement over all else, you may find it a valuable buy.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												I hate it when I follow seemingly spectacular reviews from many people, but then end up with a lackluster mess of an experience when I actually end up playing the game. TLDR at the end.PROS:Gritty and atmospheric at times (Con - one note in others)Some of the characters are voiced really well, and lend some much needed life to the drab and mostly colorless world.Some of the writing in the game is excellent, and evokes a sense of understanding and connectivity to humanity itself.CONS:The other characters that are voiced range from uninteresting to downright jarring and hideous (especially when it's in the case of one of the main characters in the story arch).The rest of the writing ranges from uninspired filler to something you might receive at the end of a fourth grade literacy examination.Terrible save system. Often you have no option to save (during cutscenes and conversations, which run through the majority of the game). At one point (luckily early in the game) I quit because I thought it would autosave, based on seeing no hint of a save menu. Only I found upon rebooting the game, that I had to restart from the beginning. For reference, in case you choose to get this game despite my warnings, it's the esc key. You can only use it during sections where you can move your character around.No skipping cutscenes/conversations. You must (space key) skip through the dialogue one piece at a time. For other things, such as scripted character movements, you must simply wait. Issues like these simply should not exist within games these days. There's no excuse.TLDR:The more I played, the more I realized I was wasting my time with something that would inevitably just continue to dissapoint me even further. If you're into self-pity and adolescent tantrum states, as well as a system which does not allow for adaptability to real-life eventualities (such as having to stop playing without advance notice) play this game. As someone who values his time, and wishes to save the time of other gamers, I cannot recommend this title.

number of helpful: 1 of 6 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												The Cat Lady - 9/10 I have over 200 games on Steam but none seem to keep my interest for that long, but The Cat Lady has!Every night I've been making myself a nice cup of coffee, sitting down then progressing further into the dark story. Voice acting is fantastic, especially between our main character and her room mate (Mitsi) It feels like I'm watching a really good thriller but I'm controlling the actions. The art direction is really good, the music is great (I especially like the main menu music when you first boot up the game) The story is really what grabs you, whilst most games revolve around the gameplay whilst there story is lacking, The Cat Lady is the opposite in that it is the story that takes the front seat, This isn't to say the gameplay is bad, the gameplay is similiar to a point and click although you use the keyboard keys to move your character in a 2d fashion (WASD being the main keys) This is where my one complaint comes in, and the reason I scored this Masterpiece a 9 rather than a straight up 10. The controls do feel clunky, pressing down (or S) brings up your inventory, this feels sluggish and not as snappy as it should be.I really wanted to sit back in my chair with my nice hot coffee and play this using my pad... The game should be perfectly suited to a pad, move left and right, select objects, open inventory, but whats this? No controller support?I'm sure it would of been a simple thing to implement partial controller support, even a slight vibration feature on the pad when something jumps out (or even to reflect your characters heartbeat in the more tense sections) I know there is 3rd party software out there to be able to map keys to the pad but this would of been a nice inclusion from the start.But enough of my grumbling because that minor complaint is the only thing I can think of, This is one of the finest adventure games I have had the joy of playing since Grim Fandango & I look forward to future releases from this developer+ Fantastic Story + Dark moody atmosphere+ Great Voice acting & music- Lack of controller support- Slightly clunky Keyboard controllsOverall9/10

content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												he Cat Lady follows Susan Ashworth, a lonely 40-year old on the verge of suicide. She has no family, no friends and no hope for a better future. One day she discovers that five strangers will come along and change everything... By author Remigiusz Michalski (Harvester Games) this suspenseful psychological horror game features stylized artwork, a simple keyboard control method and English voice acting, plus a compelling, atmospheric 70 minute soundtrack by micAmic and featured artists Warmer, 5iah and Tears Of Mars. The Cat Lady contains strong adult themes and is recommended only for players over 18.

content:
Posted: June 2, 2014
												The Cat Lady is a psychological horror game developed by Harvester Games, placing you in the role of a 40 year old woman named Susan Ashworth. Susan is suicidal, and succeeded in killing herself by taking too many pills. She soon discovers that she has a special gift, which must be used to confront five specific people who will change her life. I won’t go into too much more detail, as it will spoil the game, but it’s a very compelling story. The way it is presented to you through the extensive dialogue in-game just draws you deeper and deeper into it. Buckle up for a dark and gory experience.Gameplay is extremely simple: you can only move Susan left or right, and interact with various objects and people in her environment. Often times, you can pick up and use items throughout each chapter at certain points. Many of these items are required to progress within the narrative and the story. There are many characters to meet and interact with, and depending on your choices, different outcomes and dialogue options.Every single line of dialogue is fully voiced, and very well done. You can actually feel the emotions of each character through their voices, adding to the immersion factor and connecting the player to Susan on an empathetic level.The music is very engaging as well, always setting the right mood and tone for each scene. The game is filled with chilling atmospheric tracks done by featured artists such as micAmic, Warmer, 5iah, and Tears of Mars. The soundtrack really fits the game well in every single scene. The developers did a wonderful job with this title, and you will find yourself even more drawn in thanks to the fantastic music and atmospheric sound effects.The game is of decent length, requiring only about 7-10 hours of play to complete, but oh…what an experience that 7-10 hours is! If you ever get the opportunity to purchase this game, give it a try.Recommended

content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												This is interactive fiction for clinically depressed teenagers and the occasional nu-metal soundtrack hints to the real demographics of this game.There's not much of an adventure game, the mechanics and UI are quite basic and so are the few puzzles. The storyline that should in theory hold this up is, while captivating for a couple of chapters, gets quite cliché and silly towards the end. It's a story that would very much like you to think it has a deeper meaning, but comes out as quite banal reflections on regret and redemtion.I would have loved it if it went further in it's narrative concept, but as it is we are left with a brooding protagonist without much at all to say.From the glowing reviews here, I had expected more.

number of helpful: 98 of 211 people (46%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												Well, this is difficult. I would like to recommend Cat Lady, I really would. I appreciate what the game is trying to accomplish and tell; A story that takes you into the mindset of a depressive, suicidal woman with nothing keeping her in this world. Something different, mature and hard to behold. And that part of the game is  really good....but the gameplay is so horrible. The arrow keys are used to move in the one-dimensional world and use stuff in the game, but it is clunky and does not work well. The UI feels like it was modelled after an old adventure game and still screwed up.The gameplay fluctuates. Most of the time it is a traditional "use key with lock"-adventuring, but sometimes the game introduces new features... and immidiately drops them after the chapter.All in all, The Cat Lady would have probably functioned better as a comic or an animation than a game. The art style is neat (even though the graphics feel a bit amateurish at some points), and the story is good, but there is no reason for the game to have a player playing it, apart from some bits of choice. But if you don't fear bad gameplay and are enamoured by the thematics of the game, go ahead and play it.

content:
Posted: October 7, 2015
												Pacing is very slow in between the bits of actual puzzle solving. Story is eh. Kinda all over the place and it feels like a bunch of traumatic experiences were thrown together to try and force some sort of empathy for the main character. The slow pacing makes some puzzles tedious. Also the fog area lagged my computer so terribly. There seems to be no fix for it except turning up the settings just to pass that one section.The mechanic for using items is a bit cumbersome. I wouldn't recommend this game if you do not have patience.If you like creepy gorey serial killer drama then it's worth a play. Otherwise for the average gamer I don't see this one being much of a hit.Also having a mental break down from microwaving a hamburger too long was pretty funny.EDIT: Finally finished the game and got the good ending. I think cutting down some of the repetitive dialog, speeding up the game play with a smoother item system, possibly making the walk cycle faster would really streamline the game to a point I'd recommend this to my friends.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
												Wow, was I ever misled by reviews on this one. The Cat Lady is so bland, slow, and uneventful that 90% of it feels like a walking simulator, the plot is so utterly random and often silly, and frankly it's ugly as hell. There's really nothing to solve, either, you just wander around and eventually bad things happen to you. Over and over.The story is actually kind of funny if you're really, really high, but then the rest of the game is even more insufferable. Just because it's indie and it's about angst doesn't mean it's any good.Everyone says that if you've been suicidal and depressed it'll hit home, but I've been there and it was still a total farce to me. If the main character didn't just shuffle everywhere, and if the writing didn't sound like it came out of a choose your own adventure book, maybe I could enjoy it. As it is, I don't know what everyone is smoking, but this game is terrible.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												I really tried to like this game, I was expecting a really good indie horror/psyche study experience. I know it's more of an interactive novel than a game, so I won't really mention any of the gameplay other than the fact that it sometimes is clunky and that can detract heavily from the game. It's not very well optimized. Other than that, the game does what it is supposed to do very well, which is give you a solid mindset from the point of veiw of a depressed 40-something woman. The main character and her writing are very well done, and the rest of the story reflects that. The only problem with the spectacular writing for story and the main character is that it really points out the flaws and lackluster writing/voice acting in every other character. It really seems like all the characters are secondary thoughts, plot devices to only move the story further. Other than that, it's just a slow moving bummer. The story, like I said, does what it sets out to do very well, which is to show a clear and accurate look at depression. The story moves slow enough that it feels like time is meaningless because you will always have to deal with the troubles in the game. I opted to kill myself (by stopping playing the game) early, so I honestly can't say whether I know if the ending is better than the story and pacing. I can appreciate art, but theater of pain can only hold me for so long, and this game tried to hold me for longer than it was worth.

												Very creative concept with excellent voice acting and atmosphere. Many will like it for that artistic value alone. I did. But on the gameplay side, the 2D view and the really simplistic controls just made the game too boring for me. There didn't seem to be any skill involved except for deductions involving the use of objects collected in the scenes. It was just too boring and linear for me. I leave it to others who have more patience, no thanks.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												I'm frankly insulted to see how many awards this game won. The writing is terrible. The controls are hideous. The characters are shallow. (It seems pretty obvious to me, a woman in my 30s, that the female protagonist was written by men - and men with only the most simplistic understanding of women, at that. A quick look at their web site and the list of game creators confirms my suspicion that the team was almost entirely male.) The only thing about this game that is "mature" is the endless gratuitous gore - the adolescent's definition of maturity, really. There is no deeper meaning or insight to be found here. It's just violence, sadism, and long, long, loooooong dialogues with no depth or substance.This game feels mysogynistic and I recommend that you steer well away from it if you want a quality game experience. Whether you're looking for horror, adventure, good story, interesting characters, or female protagonists, you would do better with almost anything else.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
												    My acquaintance with this game began when Steam recommended it for me after I bought Fran Bow. The game's summary was very intriguing. It said the game is about a woman who decided to end her life and about her afterlife experience, or something like that, doesn't really matter. I personally enjoy games like that. Drawn-like 2d environment was very nice too, positive reviews were very promising, so I decided to buy this game too.    When I played a game for a while, I felt, that I was fooled, so to speak. The first reason for that feeling is this. When you see an intro scene which lasts for 5 minutes, it's OK, but when you see such a scene or even a scene twice as long as an intro after every minute you were in controll of your character, this is really annoying. Also there might be a dialog followed by a cutscene, again followed by a dialog (like half an hour overall). This is really boring.   Susan Ashworth, a character controlled by player, is extremely slow. It might seem that she is not only mentally ill, but also ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. I do not mean that scene when she took her medication. No, it's her ordinary behaviour to act and move slowly. So gameplay is reduced to this: move from one side of a room to another with speed of a turtle, have a long and boring conversation, watch a long cutscene, repeat again.    Actually, there are some tough puzzles in the game, but they are not logical, you just need what they call "non-standard thinking" to solve them. There are also plenty of gameplay elements and puzzles which do not affect the game at all. Like the one with two rooms guarded by dolls or red and blue bars. Sometimes there is a red bar in a corner of the screen, which indicates Susan's mental state. When it overflows, Susan experiences mental breakdown, but no matter if she had a breakdown or not, the game just passes to a new chapter (after 30 min cutscene, of course).   So I was hoping it's over when the game said "You died" or something like that when Susan shot herself. But, alas, not a chance! After another 5 minutes Susan returned from death, she was "granted with a gift of immortality" at the beginning of the game.  So I thought: this is enough for me and closed the game.Unless there are some plot twists, it is extremely simple: kill five bad men. That's it.So if you do not want to be bored to death, never ever waste your money for this. The game took half a day and I was controlling my character for half an hour or maybe less, so I wanted to spend another half to write this review as a warning to other players. Do not be confused. Do not buy this game.

number of helpful: 19 of 56 people (34%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												A visually oriented psychological horror adventure game with rather shallow and unrealistic characters, poor dialogue, contrived and easy puzzles, crippled interface and finally; good art, atmosphere and at times sound. As an adventure game this game doesn't cut it. As psychological horror it falls flat on its face due to reasons laid out in more detail below.I can't recommend this game mainly because it fails at what it seems to strive for: psychological horror and meaningful dialogue. The dialogues are extensive, and they consist mostly of filler back-and-forth bickering and unimaginative small-talk, sometimes attempting to be humorous despite the bleak circumstances and surroundings but practically just managing to break the immersion. There are lengthy pauses in the dialogue that you can't skip, and while I understand they were put there to put emphasis on lines and allow for a few seconds of contemplation, after you realize the dialogue is thoroughly shallow and void of depth they just become an annoying, arbitrary speed bump for advancing in the game. It is of course even more annoying if you go back just to get achievements.Cursing is used with good taste for the most part, i.e. there's not too much of it, and the voice actors mostly manage not to sound ridiculous dropping the F-bombs here and there.The interface is terrible. You play the game using WASD (up left down right) and enter. Space (and enter) skips a line of dialogue. Movement is in one dimension; you can either walk left or right. When you come across a hotspot, its name is displayed and you can interact with it by pressing up. This opens a list of possible actions such as "examine", "push", "open" etc., and you use up and down to select your action. To open inventory you press down, then left and right to choose item. Pressing enter on the item brings up an action list again, and you press up and down to select action "examine", "use" etc.. The problem arises from the context-sensitivity of the direction keys: To interact, you press up. To select action, you move up or down in the menu, and to exit you press left or right. But you enter the inventory by pressing down, and then left or right to select item, then enter, then again up or down to choose action. To exit from this menu and go back to inventory, you again press left or right. To exit from the inventory, you press up or down (left and right are for choosing item now). Then left and right are again for moving [the character] sideways and up and down for interacting and opening inventory. This all makes the interface very unintuitive and inconsistent. I wish they'd just gone with point'n'clicking instead.The visuals in this game are very good. I liked the graphics throughout the game and they manage to create a nice atmosphere. All the characters seem to be the same height, which seems a bit strange. Animation is simplistic and a bit jerky but it didn't bother me.The sound is up to par for the most part, although I thought some of the music (my apologies to the developer for using this word, but...), namely the "emo rock" sounded a bit out of place for this game. I would much have preferred something more reminiscient of Alexander Scriabin or - if you want to go modern - industrial or aggrotech. Teenage angst rock just doesn't quite cut it for a game revolving around the life and psyche of a suicidal woman in her forties. Voice actors are, in my opinion, surprisingly good and where they fall flat I would blame the director responsible or the dialogue.Puzzles are few in this game, and didn't really require much thinking. Some of it is very, very contrived. For example, you have to make coffee one step at a time and then it gets spoiled and you start over again. Didn't help me "get into the character" but made me frustrated that the game would bother wasting my time to supposedly make a poor attempt at that.The game presents itself as dealing with mature and dark themes, but turns out there's not much dealing here, just putting nasty stuff on the table as a freakshow. There is not much analytical nor deep thought present in the dialogue, and the characters react to events in strikingly unrealistic ways, which is only indicative of poor writing considering how much effort the game puts into being taken seriously on other fronts. The content of the game is more juvenile, feigning maturity, and gets constantly caught for it through the aforementioned poor and unrealistic writing, for example; a 40yo woman who has just attempted suicide, concerned about letting a girl in her 20's see her♥♥♥♥♥♥and only lets her in the bathroom while she's taking a bath if "she promises she's not a lesbian". There's also a lot of arbitrary sadism in this game that is only mature for its violence. Nothing is really explained in more depth - the sadism, perversion and brutality just are there for people to "enjoy."I tried to like this game, but entering chapter 4 or 5 I found myself speedstepping through dialogues because they just weren't interesting and felt like filler content purposely slowing me down, and there is a lot of filler dialogue in this game. In the very end I would just skip the dialogue because the character weren't saying anything substantial at all, i.e. there's a lot of "yes", "no", "please", "no" verbal ping-pong that serves no purpose but to supposedly make everything more theatrical - if bad movie cliches are presumed as a good example of theatrics. I didn't find myself growing attached to the shallow characters and when the game ended I just said to myself; "Finally." There are a few OK scares, and I did enjoy the atmosphere briefly in some parts, but I feel the game didn't shine in the areas where it could and in my opinion should have, and deteriorated into a boring interactive gore fest. There are also a few bugs and oddities: At least at one point the character seems to comment on something she shouldn't had known yet. A few times the game got stuck during or between cutscenes so that the only way out was to kill the game process. The dialogue options don't show the full text if the line is too long, so you're forced to respond with lines you can't even read before selecting them. Sometimes a character would skip her first line by herself after a pause or a cutscene. Nothing gamebreaking though as far as I can tell.If you don't care about the quality of writing, think you can handle the bad interface and contrived puzzles, and just want some nice audio-visual gore and scares, then you might still be enjoying this game. If you're looking for mature handling of heavy subjects or true psychological horror with meaning behind it, or a satisfying adventure gaming experience, I'm afraid this game can't deliver.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
												This game was flaming dreadful. But i was intrigued to keep playing. An awful, awful first impression. Holy cow it was ugly. I stuck at it, through the walking from one end of the screen, and back again, 100 times. I just stuck at it. It got worse, but i stuck at it. I couldn't get past it's ugliness. It was just terrible. The music fell flat on so many occasions and made me cringe at some points, it felt very amateur and it just didn't fit right at certain scenes. Some of the voice acting was hilariously bad. Susan's voice wasn't badly acted, but sometimes it didn't quite 'fit'. It felt as though she was trying a little too hard on the sounding dreary and depressed tone that it became very monotone as the game went on. Even when faced with grosteque and terrifying situations, she was sarcastic and dreary. I liked Mitzi, she was belivable and she was sweet. She was a well rounded character in a game that was otherwise devoid of them (think Pest Control dude, seriously...). Her voice actress was really great.I was moved on a couple of occasions, (without spoiling anything) one involving Liz, and one involving Zoe. The scenes lingered for just the right amount of time for it to sink in, and it was touching. I thought it a huge shame that i felt unable to truly believe in Susan's depression and sadness. I felt that it was just textbook - bad things have happened to this woman, she's ended up miserable and depressed. Why not have it so that she's a woman with good prospects, a nice family life, living in a nice area, and yet she's burderned with depression? A story centered around her struggles with it despite her 'have-it-all' life could have been really interesting. People say 'what have you got to be depressed about?', unknowing that's not how depression works. It seems though that Susan Ashworth has a million and one things to be depressed about, and it's just too easy. Depression is much much deeper than what this game portrays it as. Mitzi asks Susan at one point 'What is depression like?' and Susan answers 'It's feeling as though all i want to do is die...but instead i have to live'. Simple as that apparently. And that is what the entire game is based on, Susan Ashworth being miserable because she is alive.I wanted so much more from a game that looked so gritty and strangely dark. I wasn't expecting the gore and grotesque nature of it. I didn't feel it was justified, it was a little random if anything. It was a game full of bad guys, with Susan being a misery to play, i didn't connect with her as she took on a bunch of fairytale weirdos. Weirdos that i've seen a thousand times before in games and films. There was nothing unique or new about them, some even coming across as silly, rather than frightening. Mitzi was a small ray of light in a really really bleak setting, she brought a feeling of real life to the game (although i must admit her own story and motives were far fetched and not entirely realistic). The ending let me down - it summarised depression as something you just shutup and get on with. Something it seemed Susan HAD been doing up until she killed herself at the very beginning of the game! It was an ending without feeling, without real care for what happened next. You wrapped things up (kinda, i mean, half of it made no sense) and yet despite all of the disturbing and terrible things Susan had experienced, she spoke as though she'd just had a lousy week.I was left with the question of 'what the hell did i just play?'. I wish it would have been a game based on my original assumptions - Playing as a lady who lives with and looks after a bunch of cats. At least that would have had a deeper storyline.

number of helpful: 9 of 35 people (26%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
												The main problem with this game is that it is story driven and it has the absolute worst story. It's like it was written by a "misunderstood 2deep4u 14 year-old" and I'm not joking when I say that. Further problems include: What the hell is that resolution?? 800x600 and you cannot change it? I thought we were living in 2015. Every voice actor used their best potato to record their lines. Toaster mics in a dialogue driven game. Nice. The art style is simply ugly. It may look OK on pictures, but when you actually move it's just painful to look at the screen. The dialogue is simply badly written. And slow paced. Even if you hold down space to skip everything there is SO MUCH time between each line, you will still end up waiting WHOLE MINUTES for a scene to end. There are so many things that just don't make sense in the game; this ties back up to the whole "#2deep4u"super tryhard style of the whole game.  Suddenly a murderer appears at your door and he hits you with a hammer? Yeah sure. The pest control guy kidnaps you after he's finished with his job? Yeah sure. Wait, him and his wife are also cannibals and are gonna eat you? Yeah sure.  Seriously these things simply don't make sense and I'm facepalming so much over the fact that a game with SUCH A WEAK STORY could make it to steam and people are actually playing it and some are even enjoying it (???).Now you may ask why I have 12 hours in the game and why I have all the achievements. Let me explain it this way: you know when you ragequit a game when it pisses you off so much, right? Well with me, this was the opposite. I was so angry with myself at the fact that I paid actual money for the game that I thought "god damn everything, if I actually spent my hard earned money on this piece of feces then it may as well contribute to my game completion percentage."But still, with having played so much of the game, I still cannot list any positive things about it. I guess some lines between Mitzi and Susan were OK? Maybe even well written? Sadly, the rest of the game was so bad that I still would not under any circumstances recommend this game to anyone ever.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												Like you see with a lot of games these days The Cat Lady is about telling a story instead of about playing a game. The gameplay is just slapped on to it to make it a game instead of an animation. The reason for this is probably that there is more money to make as game than as animation or as ebook and cheaper to produce than as movie. While all these other mediums would be much better suited for it. Because you can just watch the story unfold instead of having to go through the tedious gameplay.The controls make the gameplay even more annoying and would be much better as point and click instead of using the arrow keys. It's maybe designed this way too feel the a bit like Susan, but it just pisses you off. The artstyle isn't the best looking, but really fits the mood the game tries to set. The resolution of the game is really low and you can't change it too your native resolution which is always annoying.It's just too bad it isn't on a other medium, because the world and the story look interesting. But if you really want to see the story you better of watching a let's play than actually playing the game.

number of helpful: 22 of 65 people (34%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
												A perplexing adventure game... is all I can really say about this.It starts off promising; terrible graphics aside, the protagonist is a 40-year old woman, a demographic rarely seen in games, and one I appreciate being there. She tries to kill herself and this sends her into a fantasy world, at which point the game starts.Cat lady is a supremely boring game. You may say that I think that due to the type of content alone, but no, the game is just dull. It's completely one dimensional, you can only move left and right. King's quest for DOS allowed for more exploration than this game. Movement is slow as balls, which is very noticable when you're plodding from left to right with nothing much to do. The puzzles are almost non-existant; the game merely tells you to tick off every option on the few interactive objects you come across until you progress, and any time the game does force you to think, the games pace makes it unbearable.I assume the game was made like this so you could appreciate the backgrounds and environment, which are... relatively good, I suppose. A lot of love has gone into them, but they are nothing extraordinary.Cat Lady gets no reccomendation from me, I'm afraid, there are thousands of other, better adventure games out there. Does it work as an exploratory journey, rather than as a game? I dont really think so, but hey, that's just my opinion.

Posted: January 7, 2015
												I get what the game is trying to do, but it's not succeeding in any way. I like the premise of the game, 40-something year old, suicidal woman as a protagonist, you don't see that very often. But that's pretty much where all the good things end in this game. The artstyle is pretentious, choppy and ugly. Some might think it's artistic and retro, but it really isn't, it's just plain old ugly. Dialogue is horrible, both voice acting and writing. Every character sounds the same, and every character is very monotone and single-minded. I get that they were going for grim, dark, depressed style of feeling, but it just comes off as boring.As for boring, that's what the gameplay is, among other things. All the puzzles are incredibly easy, but at the same time take a lot of work, walking around, looking for arbitrary hints that might be objects you can interact with, or just part of the backround, you can never tell. It's a point and click adventure, without the point, the click or the adventure.To top it all off, controls are horrible and clunky, the whole game is unresponsive and unstable, the settings don't seem to do anything and if you try to put it on fullscreen, it just freezes on startup. (Even when run in a window, it took several minutes to go from "is it frozen?" to "Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥ it took that long to launch?!")All in all, I can't recommend the game in any way. It had potential, but nothing came of it.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												This game should be called "Patience Quest". It felt like at least 50% of my play time was spent sitting through slow, slow cut-scenes. It's useful to note that you CAN skip through dialogue by pressing the space bar, but even so, these scenes are long. And for the most part these aren't even  exciting animated cut-away scenes or anything like that. It's just watching two characters in profile, sitting perfectly still, uttering their lines, with the occasional dialogue choice. You also can't save during these cut scenes, nor can you pause (unless you're running the game in a window, in which case it will pause if you click away to another application). Sometimes you'll go 10 or 15 minutes before the game goes back into interactive mode, allowing you to save.The game's interface is quite rough and unpolished, which would be forgiveable if it weren't for those dang cut scenes. The art style is similarly rough, but it reminded me pleasantly of the TV show "Metalocalypse", so I can forgive that.The subject matter, storyline, and characterization, were all quite interesting. But for me, the slow pace and the interminable cut-scenes made the game almost unplayable, so I can't recommend it.

Posted: January 2, 2015
												The art style isn't charmingly dark and edgy, it's ugly and amateurish.  The voice actress sounds like she is a bit "slow", and has cotton stuffed into her cheeks and nasal cavity.  (I'm not saying the voice actress IS slow, I'm just saying that's how she's portrayed a character who, I think we should assume, wasn't meant to sound that way.)  But worst of all, if you make the "wrong" choice, you're screwed.  You can't go back in this game if you missed something vital, which means you have to completely restart from the beginning of a chapter, and chapters can be quite long.  No save function, either. We got backtracking in Super Mario Bros 2.  That was in 1988.  Catch up with the times, and hire someone with skills better than a 13 year old to make your game art.  2/10, story and game has potential, but doesn't live up to any of it, in any way.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												I was looking forward to playing this game, as there seems to be a lot of people praising its "maturity" and "emotional connection", and the way it handles depression as an issue.Unfortunately, the game dives head-first into the supernatural horror genre within the first few minutes. The Cat Lady's main questline, and the antagonists which it is tied up in, are painted using such broad stereotypes and cliches that, for me, it overshadowed any delicate handling of the main character's psyche. This would probably have been less jarring if I was a fan of the horror genre.I stopped playing the game part-way through; the nail in this game's coffin is ultimately its user interface and art style. If the user interface was any better than tolerable, or the art style was any less dreary, it might have been easier to push through and experience the rest of the game.It's ironic the game's subdued and depressed feel - clearly a deliberate choice to support the game's atmosphere - are part of the reason it's so hard to enjoy.
