Posted: October 28, 2014
												From what I've played this game doesn't really appeal to me, it has been so far very linear to a point where I'm not sure why they give you the option to choose what you say to people, because I always find myself having to speak all of the options eventually. The whole thing so far seems to be trying too hard to be dark, scary and artistic but it comes across more as bland, slow and boring.The gameplay is not up to the standard of even the oldest point and click adventures as you can't use the mouse, you simply press the left and right buttons on the keyboard to walk around and press up to interact with things, which makes the puzzles and general gameplay feel tedious.Perhaps my distaste for the game stems from the fact I am not sympathetic towards the protagonist, in the time I've played it is not explained why she is depressed and wants to commit suicide, for all I know one of her cats died. I'm all in favour for artistic and surreal story telling but in this game a lot of it feels cliche, as though I was inside a highschool kid's art project.The music however has been alright, I don't want to say good because I haven't really heard enough of it, but it is definitely carrying the game for me at this point. I will continue to play the game for at least another hour when I can be bothered to sit through it and if there are any improvements I will update this review, but I am not confident that the game will have any significant improvement. This game cost me $3.39 and even that feels like a lot for this game, very glad I did not have to pay the original $10.00

number of helpful: 8 of 34 people (24%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												The Cat Lady is a solid horror point-and-click adventure, but I can't say it's something I'll recommend.The story focuses on Susan Ashworth, a suicide victim struggling with depression. The game tries to wrap an odd mix of metaphorical demons with real life psychotic criminals and murders. The aspect of the real life nemeses who were out to get Susan were far from realistic or down to Earth. Other than her neighbor, these colorful villians seems like they could have been torn out of a comic book. This strong contrast with what is believable and what is fat'fetched didn't sit well with me.The puzzles in the game started to feel less refined as the game went on, and more like they were just placed in there to give the player something to do. Additionally, certain odd choices of background ambience and sound effect also brought me out of the experience;Such as shouting out loud while trying to sneak around, or having background ambience of doors opening and closing when you know there's no one else moving in the entire house. I could go on with a laundry list of events in game, but the larger problem is how the game portrays itself as whole.While these mismatched events would seem to be purposefully comical, it doesn't seem to be done with such intent.Such as that one long drawn out scene being that phone call with an incompetent emegency call handler. Which would have be hilarious if it was framed ever so differently.Even the multitude of misfortune that Susan Ashworth runs into seems oddly comical, but yet the game doesn't seem to acknowledge it.I do have one point where the game stood out for me, it's Chapter 2. It had one scene to establish some missing background of your version of Susan Ashworth while in a session with the psychiatrist Doctor Xaiver. The player has to pick rather personal information Susan would share, from her relationship with her parents and her daily routines. There weren't any options to omit a reply, so it felt much more intimate for to me as the player answering for Susan. It was blurring the lines where I was trying to keep Susan faithful with what has already been established with her character while projecting myself onto her as well.Ultimately, I felt it could have been better polished. It's an okay game but not a memoriable one.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												Whenever I consider buying a new horror game or "atmospheric" minimalist game, I think "will it be as bad as The Cat Lady?"The Cat Lady tries to sell itself as having bad graphics that hide a great story and/or gameplay, but that's just not true.The story is tired and overdone. Anyone that's watched horror movies or played any number of videogames won't find the "life after death" tropes interesting or new, and the dialogue and character development sounds like it was written by someone with the emotional depth of a high schooler. A main part of the plot is literally "you didn't do enough to enjoy life and then you killed yourself so now you're being punished." It's like a really longwinded "YOLO."The gameplay is basically what you would expect from a free online flash game. There are a lot of online flash games that are more recommendable than this one.In the end, it's not that the creators did a terrible job, but this quality of game (in terms of graphics, gameplay, story, etc.) is something you aren't normally expected to pay money for. Don't believe the hype.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												This is the most boring game what I have ever played by far. The sounds are very low quality and the acting is BAD. Graphics and animations all the way through the game looked like somebody doesn't know anything about well done visuals or was just "too busy" to make them look good. Maybe some people like this game, but for me it's just a big NO. Why?When I started this game, I was really looking forward and I was also really thinking positively about this game. At the beginning I saw really massive (kinda hidden?) promise that there will be a LOT of Jumpscares and a LOT of tight moments and I WILL come to the point where I don't wan't to go any further, because I will be so scared... or so I thought what The Queen Of Maggots wanted to say between the lines in her very long lasting, almost monolog dialog at the beginning of the game. The promise was never redeemed. There was too many forever lasting, useless dialogs and I had to choose all the little things what I wanted Susan to say. There was too much over detailing dialogs and hardly any action. The whole game was literally like this: "Slowly walk from place to place and have another over detailed or longlasting boring dialog". If you watch all the dialogs and eximine everything (not worth it), it will be over ten hours before the game is finished. But if you decide to skip as much as you can which I think is much better idea, the game will maybe over after one or two hours. It almost feels like they started good and after short of time they forgot what they were doing, and made just bunch of dialogs and nothing else.That's why!Maybe the positive thing is that if you have never played any horror or "horror game" and want to start that experience easily, then this is for you. This is really easy way to start in my opinion. Too easy. But to be honest, I don't recommend this to anybody. Save your money to something better.Final ThingI almost forgot: Didn't get my jumpscares!

content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												Very overrated game. In my opinion it is the worst game I have ever paid for.It's meant to be some kind of story-driven adventure point and click, but the story is very boring, the characters are ugly and you can't possibly like anything in it. The atmosphere sucks, everything feels so pessimistic, sad, like the worst B-movie you've ever watched. There's simply nothing atractive in this game, and neither the gameplay nor the story keep you engaged. The point and click is also bad, often you point, click, nothing happens and you think that area can't be interacted with, but at a second glance (if it happens) you find that it actually works but for some reason the game ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ts you more often than you'd like to so you lose precious time by doing things you were supposed to do but with no result (at first), to only realize you have to click harder or insist in order for it to work.From the reviews:“Amazing story that maturely delves into raw human emotion” 4.5/5 – Adventure Gamers My opinion: There's no amazing story. It's just a cheap horror story with lots of clichees. And the only human emotion you feel is disgust.“The Cat Lady is the finest horror adventure I've ever played. In fact, it's one of the finest adventure games I've ever played, period.” A+ – Just Adventure My opinion: The person who wrote that most likely didn't play any adventure game.“The Cat Lady is a refreshing, intelligent and intriguing game and one of the best I have played this year” 9/10 – Bloody Disgusting My opinion: *in robot voice* INSUFFICIENT INTELLIGENCE DETECTED! *drops robot voice* It's as refreshing as a fresh piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥ as intelligent as a brick and the only intriguing thing about this game is why the hell it exists. If it's the best the reviewer had played that year, it's either the first game he played that year or the only one. Also, I appologise for insulting all the bricks in the world, they are far more intelligent than this game.How so many people can like this piece of crap is beyond me, but everybody has different tastes so I guess why not?Anyway, in my opinion this game is only worth buying if you somehow find an activation key for it or receive it as a gift - and you want the free trading cards that you get while playing. Otherwise don't even think about getting it.-10/10 (yeah, it's that bad!)

number of helpful: 2 of 23 people (9%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												The Cat Lady is a game about punishment and torture. That is, the game is punishment for your purchase and the torture is trying to play through the entire thing. This "game" is simply horrible. I knew things did not bode well when I saw a cat blinking its eyes -- CATS DO NOT BLINK. The graphic style seems to be created by a 6th grader (my apologies to talented 6th graders). The characters are created with ugly bit-mapped graphics, while the backgrounds seem to have been rendered. Rather than looking "stylized", it simple makes the character graphics look childish and out of place.The writing style seems to be created by an 8th grader (my apologies to talented 8th graders). Apparently, constant head bobbing is considered an adequate animation for spoken dialogue. The characters blather on incessantly about trivial things and often repeat the same thing over and over. It is as if the game was so hollow and short that the creators filled with the drivel to pad it out. It is unfortunate that amount of dialogue was not devoted to story exposition. I might have actually cared about why the depressing main character wanted to kill herself.Amazingly, this is a Point-and-Click adventure game that does not support pointing or clicking. You have to use arrow keys and the Enter key to select action and dialogue options. This awkward control scheme coupled with the endless useless dialogue back-and-forth between characters is incredibly annoying. No wonder you get an achievement for suffering through each "Chapter".This is a side-scrolling adventure game. That is, you can only move left or right. Somehow, moving back the way you came results in your character finding new locations. Not only is this illogical, it is tedious and annoying.The voice acting is rather average. Some actors actually try, while others simply phone in their performance. Speaking of which, sometimes it sounds as though a voice has been phoned in. The quality of the voice recording is very inconsistent. Sometimes you can barely hear the voice over the music. Other times, the voice is clipping. Is is as if the voice actor was moving around rather than staying put in front of the microphone.I can only recommend this game to the most dedicated masochists. Simple horrible.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2014
												Many other reviews have pointed out reasons why you should buy the game, so I am using this review to give a couple of reasons why you probably shouldn't.I am a massive adventure game and horror game fan, this product promises to be a mixture of both but I don't think it does particularly well at either. The main thing that made me lose interest more than others is how inconsequential the plot is. I can't really find the narrative to be abstract or artistic, it's just really hard to buy into with really unexplicable things happening to the character (SPOILER START like dying and then living again and then being murdered and then being alive again, then being disfigured and then being back to normal again.... what?!? SPOILER END). The violence in it is very gratuitous and excessive if you ask me and the dialogs they often drag on for way longer than they should making it quite boring to sit through them. The concepts in them could be delivered in far fewer lines to keep the flow of the game going.The environment art is really beautiful but the character art is very very minimalistic and rushed, so that it feels like it doesn't even belong in those scenaries. The character aniamtions are so rudementary and bare bone that they are often painful to watch.I feel like there was a lot of potential and really interesting themes that were tackled but the plot and the events just felt too inconsequental and bizarre for me to care about how it ended.  There are some interesting (but never too challenging) puzzles and some good voice performances in some moments but I can't help but feeling that the game could have used more polishing and work.

Are the developer paying people to downvote negative reviews and write positive ones?I gave this game a try, and right off the bat the game is extemely obnoxious and unoriginal. It's just a cavalcade of "hold left, and waaaaaiit..", "pick up key", "hold right, and waaaaaaaait..", "use key" and "open door", on and on and on. This game really fails at this aspect, and really is just simply horrible.To top that off there are no display options AT ALL, and you are forced to play in full screen with a set 4:3 resolution.. WHAT IS THIS? 1996? FIX the options menu. A 1 month game developer intern could make the changes needed for a better options menu. This is NOT OK in 2014, and not in 2012 when this game was released either. The praise this game is recieving is FAR from deserved.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 5
												The Cat Lady Review - Raymond KTedited on 2017-03-11The first of seven chapters effectively simulates Susan's confusion as she awakes in the hospital to find a sweet nurse at her side. But Susan is not inclined to share much about herself, and so early events, such as her reaction to a bouquet of flowers, are subtle mysteries that later become enlightened. Progressing is a matter of wandering from left to right with the arrow keys, accumulating objects, speaking with others, and solving puzzles by using those objects in particular ways. I was never stumped, but nor was The Cat Lady a complete cakewalk, though it isn't the challenge that the puzzles present so much as the atmosphere they create that makes them so interesting. To solve one early puzzle, for example, you must allow a psychiatric nurse to inject you with God knows what. You then find yourself in a foggy mental purgatory you must explore to move the story forward.I know this haze. I've survived a suicide attempt, and I spent years in and out of hospitals as I traveled the road to recovery. The Cat Lady deftly depicts events and emotions I've experienced--the defiance toward doctors, the feelings of worthlessness, the mistrust of anyone attempting to get too close. More importantly, however, it also depicts the long road to recovery, and does so without sugar-coating the painful realities of life. For Susan, true hope first arrives in the form of a young woman named Mitzi. Mitzi's life is no less troubled than Susan's, but her manner of dealing with her hardships is far different, though not necessarily any less violent - Kevin VanOrdThere is no better way to recommend a game than that.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
												I initially found out about this game by watching a Let's Play of it and loved it to buy it and experience it myself. The Cat Lady is a beautifully told story that meaningfully digs deep into some dark places. While there are many rich and theatrical scenes that deal with depression, death, and suicide, it isn't pretentious. There are touches of some dry and dark humor that accompany a compelling storyline as Susan Ashworth tries to cope with life after her attempted suicide and the unique consequences of it thereafter. If you love rich storylines with dark, and at times, distubing imagery and themes, get this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												*The Cat lady* is a dark, creepy and quite gory adventure game, that centers around a depressed woman named Susan who, after an attempted suicide, meets “The Queen of Maggots” (basically Death). The queen gives her a mission to rid the world of evil and dangerous people, who hurt and kill others for their own personal gain or amusement . As Susan wakes up from the incident, we get to know her as a person and learn to understand why she've made the choices she made during her life, as well as experience with her the atrocious events the occur afterworlds. She also gets to meet a young woman named Mitzi, who seems to be on a mission of her own... The game plays quite similarly to a point and click adventure game, but you actually don't “point and click” so to speak, but use the arrow keys to move the character around. During the game, you'll also have to make a few choices, which influence how the game ends. I personally found this to be a very interesting and nice touch. The game has a wonderful soundtrack, if you like this kind of music. It includes some creepy and atmospheric tracks, but also some great punk and metal songs, that really fits the feel of the game.As for the graphics and style of the game... well, I think the art style is what will put some people off. You might find it a bit grotesque, but as you play you'll come to realize that style fits very well with the rest of the game, as it conveys the trauma and the emotions of the characters extremely well. There are a few instances where they could have done a better job graphically though, as at times characters or things can look disproportionate. The game also has voice acting, which is a bit of a hit and miss. Sometimes the acting is quite alright, but other times it's extremely flat, over the top or simply to obvious and stereotypical. Even so I actually enjoyed the voice acting quite a bit, and I don't think I'd enjoy the game as much if it wasn't included. So yeah... Even though the game has it's flaws (like most games) I totally recommend this game! At least to people who like dark adventure games. It has great music, great sympathetic female lead characters (well I've gone through a depression of my own, so maybe that makes it easier for me to sympathize), great character development, some really dark and twisted scenarios as well as an amazingly creepy atmosphere. To be honest, it's one of my favorite adventure games of all time.9/10

												It took me a bit to warm up to this game, given the fairly low production values and the controls. Once I got used to it though, and past the intro, I became compelled to complete this odd game. I'm not into violence and don't watch horror films, so, I guess maybe I found some of the graphic things described in the game more disturbing than people who actually enjoy the horror genre would. (Which is to say, I enjoyed it, but horror-buffs might find it all a bit tame for their liking, maybe?) I found the ending (or at least the one I achieved) really cheesy. Also, there's one part that that I found waaaay too predictable, which completely ruined "the feels" I was probably meant to have. But don't get me wrong! This game had some absolutely fantastic moments which made it all very much worth it. It's the kind of thing I would buy again, and play again, if it were re-released on a bigger budget. It's not the art or music - it's the controls and gameplay itself that I'd like to see enhanced.Overall, I'd recommend this game, even though it doesn't have many "game" elements. It's a peaceful, interesting time killer, that I reckon will take a good 5 - 8 hours to get through.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												I don't typically write reviews about anything unless it is something REALLY amazing.First off, I got this on sale for 2.50 and it is worth so much more than that. If you like surreal themes, horror, and adventure, this is for you. I don't become scared or disturbed easily, but at times this game deeply disturbed and moved me. However, if subjects like death, suicide, and illness are currently too much for you, you may not want to play this. After a while I was afraid it may be too dark for me, it touched home too many times to count and made me a little uncomfortable. But, I felt compelled to push through the game because…well, I was enjoying it too much for the discomfort I was experiencing to stop me. It actually became a deeply personal thing to finish the game.It is a work of art, both grotesque and profoundly beautiful in meaning. It became so much more than a game, even by the end of the first chapter. You will find yourself sucked into this world and embracing it in no time at all. I only hope for more like it in the future.From what I can tell, there are different outcomes for the actions you choose, so no doubt I can play this again with different results, which is a huge plus. The controls are easy. Visually it is both simplistic and complex, you have to pay attention to your surroundings and really think. I love that this game challenges the player in so many ways. For the price it is well worth it, I say give it a shot! You may be as surprised as I was.

												An incredibly beautiful game, the only thing I'd fault it for is the voice acting being a little off at times but other than that, this game is a haunting experience. content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
												first of all, i should state that this is not a game, the results of every choice are pretty obvious, and there's no skill or strategy required, but that doesn't mean The Cat Lady isn't worth your money.The writing is pretentious, dark, emotional, and often times over the top... and I love every second of it.I'd argue its a visual novel and the story is the only reason anyone should buy it.the art work isn't stellar, but its theme is good, and genuinely creepy. the music feels out of place in the montages, rock just does not meld with macabre horror.without giving any spoilers, its a dark tale of facing through real life, dealing with depression, suicide, guilt, hate, jealousy, revenge, and a cornicopia of negative human emotions. The story at times can be a real tear jerker, and the characters (for the most part) are very relateble, or at the very least feel human (parasites not included). There's potential for multiple endings, but seeing as I got the best ending on my first try, i'm not really inclined to go through it again. If you'd like a piece of work that may make you cry, i'd strongly suggest picking up a copy of the cat lady.i give this "game" a 7/10

The creepy factor is through the roof, the story is brilliant and disturbing, and the music and art style are perfectly suited to the material. I didn't once feel that I needed to use a walkthrough. The game is completely logical (except for the one WTF? moment in the story). If you enjoy psychological and visceral horror, this game is worth the purchase price.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												So, I was a bit torn on recommending this game, as there are some things which really reflect a bit of a lack of polish. As such, I'll start with the technical bits of the game, as that's where it is the most lacking. I'll finish with the story, since that's the best (no spoilers).There are bugs which cause dialogue to repeat, minor graphical glitches, and the only option in the game is changing the level of SSAA. The bugs are rediculous when they happen (but can be kinda funny. Though this does kinda defeat the purpose of the depressing atmosphere), especially at one point when a character will have subtitles that say one thing, and their voice acting doesn't fit those subtitles, nor are they in any order that makes sense. SUBTITLES ARE A MUST HAVE, THEY MAKE MUCH MORE SENSE THAN SOME OF THE RECORDED DIALOGUE. The whole game is in 800x600 resolution, but it does have the ability to render at something like 5K and downsample, so the somewhat pixelated style doesn't alias much, which is nice. Even so, it's incredibly annoying that the game is only 800x600, since that means that the aspect ratio is 4:3, resulting in interpolation on 16:9 monitors. The game also has a locked framerate of 40 FPS, which is absolutely annoying to someone who notices that sort of thing. If the screen pans while you're walking (and you're used to 60 FPS) the whole thing feels stuttery because of the low framerate. However, this game isn't supposed to be technically impressive, so that's just nitpicking. Technical tl;dr - The game has some bugs,  but they're mostly overlookable with subtitles on. The framerate is locked at 40FPS. The video settings are awful, but no one expected them to be very deep. So now I've got the middle-child of the bad vs good. The meh gameplay. This is short, because while this game uses no cursor, it's a point-and-click adventure game. No one expects good gameplay in a point-and-click adventure. However, some animations on the protagonist are a bit jittery, and that would be in the technical portion of this review, but the game has the protagonist act as a sort of cursor, so it's more of a gameplay thing, since it's not really broken so much as it just slows down the gameplay even more in a way that just doesn't feel right. It'd be fine if she flowed slowly all the time.And finally the story. "It's absolutely amazing" is the best I can do without spoilers, as I haven't quite finished the game yet. The atmosphere fits perfectly with the whole theme of depression so well, that I can only play the game for a short time before I have to stop for a day or two just to cheer back up, which is quite the achievement for a game. I connected with the protagonist in a way that I find rather rare in modern games.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												Agh! Loved it. A couple of bugs here and there where it seemed I was playing through treacle when trying to move around, and also a couple of crashes (which lost me a huge chunk of save data) - however this didn't at all stop me from taking a big old deep breath and cracking back on with it, simply because I enjoyed it so much!I'm also a big fan of text based and point and click adventure games (I blame Monkey Island for the obsession), and psycological horror titles (more blame? Silent Hill...) - so mixing up the two themes made The Cat Lady sound really appealing to me. The story is incredibly dark, the art style is incredibly complementative of that darkness, and as is the audio score. It all gels so well! The voice acting is pretty good too! I even got totally suckered into a handful of jump scares aswell - generally didn't want to put it down. It kept me thinking when I wasn't playing it, which is also a sure sign it's a winner for me. I'm terrible when it comes to adventure games, I forget it isn't real! Haha!The game is a lovely length too. I was expecting it to be quite short actually, and it may well be if you know what you're doing from having played it already, but the puzzles are freaking taxing (not a bad thing!! A great thing!!).If you're a fan of point and click, with a huge dollop of psycolocial horror in the mix, please give this a go. Tryin to scour more of the same now I'm all out of my daily dose of grumbling Susan!

												Ok, I originally had a thumbs down on this, but I've now fully finished the game, and the story was so good, I'll give it a thumbs up, but with some MASSIVE caveats, which are:-The controls are simple, yet so annoying. It took me longer than it should have to get used to them. (I'm aware that it just might be me, but bleh). -The voice acting was great but there was some mic feedback in some of the recordings.-there were a few storyline errors: the spelling of the street was inconsistent, the main character's title began flipping back and forth before it made sense in the plot, etc. -the game would often choke on its own animations when there was a lot going on. At one point I'd even thought the game had jammed entirely, and needlessly reloaded.-On that note, I found it annoying that a couple of (minor) plot devices had been invented just to excuse the lack of animations at time. The double whammy of choking animations and leaving animations out was a bit much.-I really dislike not being able to Alt+Tab out of the game if I need to. I had to plug something into my PC at one point and it forced me out of the game. I then had no choice but to Crtl+Alt+Del and restart.-Not being able to save to the same save file was really annoying (did I miss something?), but when I realised how easy it is to make a choice that makes progressing in the plot impossible, I didn't mind so much. I did enjoy how you could save when not in dialogue, but there is a *lot* of dialogue...I know most of these things are minor, but they really started to pile up after a while.HAVING SAID THAT! the story was honestly so good that I sat here and essentially marathoned myself through this game. It's been years since I've felt so immersed in a game that I felt the need to finish it all at once, or otherwise as quickly as possible. Even beyond games, there's not much that I've been as engrossed in for a very long time. What a plot. The art style was something I actually disliked at first, but it quickly grew on me as well. I watched a friend play through part of it, however, and there were quite a few visual glitches.This game is definitely something I'd recommend to patient people who don't mind unpolished games and enjoy horrors, thrillers, or something with darker themes. For everyone else... well you can assess whether it's worth the gamble, but I'd say it is if you get it on sale. The game needs a lot more optimisation before I could recommend it for full price.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												The Cat Lady is a game that will stay with me for a very long time. I have never played a game that made me cry, laugh and feel so much fondness and empathy for the characters.If you can excuse the the lack of mouse interface and the 2D gameplay, this game is outstanding. I loved the graphics, which reminded me of a Neil Gaiman graphic novel, and the voice acting was engaging and never got annoying.I recommend this game to anyone who wants an experience beyond an actual game. For anyone who understands, or wants to understand depression, loneliness and the darker side of human nature, this game will touch many chords. For anyone who enjoys horror, you will like the bleakness, macarbe plot twists and psycopaths.Lastly, the soundtrack is incredible. It suits every peak and lull in the game and I intend to track down the band responsible for the rock/metal music.Do I recommend this game? Yes, a thousand times over.

												Surreal psychodrama that stays firmly in the dank underbelly of the human experience.  The Cat Lady is very much a game that is defined by its story, and thankfully that story is excellent.  A few disjointed elements that seem to arrive and leave out of nowhere, but overall its a well crafted tale centered on an interesting protagonist.  As far as how dark it gets, I'd say it treads that line of being deliberately provocitive but never quite goes over it, which is hard to pull off.Gameplay is classic point and click adventuring with some puzzles that were quite tricky, however because everything is on a 2d plane and its always very clear what you can interact with I was never that fustrated (no pixel hunting here).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 23, 2015
												This is my first review. My 4th steam game, and the only one I'm happy about buying from steam. I hate steam. I still hate steam...but if I get more experiences like this then maybe I will like steam someday. Maybe..It took 20 minutes to download....compared to the usual 4-6 hours.It was actually playable and working after it downloaded...first game on steam where i just press play and the game works.Its the first single player game I've played in a LONGGG TIME where I wasn't bored out of my mind. I got drawn in after about 10 minutes of playing....which is unheard of for me. I always play multiplayer games cause im always lonely for company. I always feel like im not really playing until I play with other people...so i always avoid single player games. and often am bored of single player experiences right at the start to the end.THis game gives me hope for future single player experiences. It's got a lower fixed resolution but it makes some truly gorgeous environments and scenery. There are plenty of times you don't'even notice the low resolution which is amazing. I'm not gonnna recommend something that looks ugly or is hard on the eyes. infact i hate low rez indie games that use giant blocky pixels....its too hard to see anyhting other than basic objects. This is game tho, is easy  on the eyes and pretty to look at. If you are put off by some of the screenshots, don't be. It only takes a few minutes to get used to. its one of the few games where many of the environments are interesting to just sit back and look at. You can see all the detail put into these environment....and i spent quite a bit of time admiring some of the objects and detailed stuff in many areas.Bad stuff? no options menu really, can't rebind keys....which is annoying given you are pressing enter and using the arrow keys all the time...its also weird cause other keys will copy some keys....but it never tells u this in teh tutorial. it just says arrow keys and enter...but you can also use space bar to skip scenes or asdw as well but these werent mentioned in the brief tutorial as i said. Also:  The first thing you see after pressing play is a really choppy ugly video showing the company/developer logo.I'm just having a blast with this game, not done yet and hope it keeps on going forever. I'm ready to buy more of this and i've only just played today. I wanna get back to playing it soon.....rly rly fun and full of surprises.  I'm just so happy and amazed by the amount of depth put into the environments and story so far. I feel like my choices in the dialogue, environments, and story in general really matter and are making a considerable difference in how the story goes.  The puzzles are also very challenging, and it is a welcomed challenege. I'll admit I had to go to a guide to figure out 2 of the puzzle components which happened to be back to back (spent alot of time trying to figure out on my own but failed). I figured out many difficult ones though and I'm always proud of myself afterwards. It doesn't hold your hand and explain how to do things....its very old school and makes you think really hard and outside the norm. even though i had to resort to a guide for a puzzle i got completely stumped by, its a totally welcomed challenge. I hope all the future puzzles are just as if not more challenging. I'm just having so much fun. SUpport these types of games and give me recommendations for more like this! The telltale games....the ones I've played..... pale in comparison to this game. They are just on totally different levels.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
												Oh boy. This game.Okay, I have marked that I recommend it, but it has some minor flaws that ruin what could have been a truly great game.It's SLOW. Slow slow slow slow slow. My god is it slow. After Chapter 2 it's forgivable, but before that it's ridiculous.  So much text, so much voice-acting (which, don't get me wrong, is well done and sounds good), you'll forget you're playing a game sometimes and think you're watching a movie. It's like come on, when do I get to start the ♥♥♥♥ing game?! This IS a game, right?! I was like an hour and a half into the game-ahem, movie, before I finally got to do some puzzle-solving.The controls. Okay, there's only like two keys in addition to the movement keys anyway, but cut me a break, it's 2015, we should be able to remap keys to wherever we want, in any game. To not have this feature is silly.I'm not sure how to delete save files, which is a problem, because even if you name a save file the same name as one that already exists, it won't ask you to replace the old one, it'll just create another with the same exact name. Figure that one out. Moreover, where the hell is autosave? I know you can save whenever you want to, but I lost the first hour of progress the first time I tried playing because the game crashed. I was expecting there to be an autosave feature, like almost every other game these days.You can skip individual lines that people say by hitting spacebar (which took me a little while to figure out, usually it's the esc. key or something), but you still have to wait through the pauses in conversation, and if you're trying to do another playthrough to get that Golden Ending, 99.9% of the dialogue you've seen already.When you do get to do a bit of actual gameplay, the game is fun and not too heavy on the logic and moon-physics typical of these sorts of games. Immortality notwithstanding, Susan is bound by the same rules as anyone else. It's a little easy, but not TOO easy.Now, the story itself. The Cat Lady is about a woman who tries to kill herself. She is given a second chance at life, so to speak, by an old woman who identifies herself as the Queen of Maggots. She has to kill 5 "parasites", sick, depraved people whom you won't feel the least bit bad about offing after a bit of plot and character development. All the while Susan works through her own depression and flashbacks of her past life. You'll feel for her and genuinely want to see her through this to the end, and the first parasite you kill will make you feel empowered. This is where the game really shines: Susan and Mitzi are fleshed out, well developed characters, with believable motivations and fears. Anyone who has any experience with depression, their own or someone elses, will relate. A statement about pain, loss, death, the human condition.The images and settings often take on a psychedelic, surreal twist, and nothing is ever as it seems. There are some scary and creepy bits, but it's not a horror game in the normal sense of the term. There aren't really any jumpscares and that clearly wasn't the intent anyway, the game uses scary imagery as a means to an end, not the end itself.If you can get past the annoying, stupid game mechanics problems that make the game way more inaccessible than it needs to be, you'll find a game that will keep you thinking long after you've shut it off.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 11, 2015
												Haha don't let the bad reviews fool you. You start to learn about the main character slowly, they do this on purpose. She is depressed, she doesn't trust anyone and this is apparent in the game. It is so effective this way. Which is why the story unfolds slowly. What good would it be for a character to not trust anyone, yet tell you her whole life story in the beginning of the game? Defeates the point. It is kind of like a song that mimics a heartbeat. You can tell the rhythm without the actual words of what is going on due to the pace and the changes in the song. This game is a lot like this. A real true gothic tale re minding you that all monsters are human. The killers in here are sick and depraved and the horror elements are just enough to know that it could be anyone, even the nice couple next door to you, now that is scary. You know I love survival horror games, I loved playing Silent Hill games, they were hard and at times provided a challenge but I didn't find it scary. I don't find Zombies scary and I haven't played a survival horror game that has scared me really. This game didn't scare me but it was effectively creepy and that is a hard thing to do in 2015 with all the 3D graphics and super overloaded gory stuff. For hat I adore this game and always will. When I first played this game I was at work. I was running on like 3 hours of sleep and didn't know what I was getting myself into. I forgot to choose certain dialogue options in the beginning so then towards the end of the intro something totally random happened. All of a sudden getting no sleep and having something totally random happen to this poor main character, it startled me so much I started laughing manically. Everyone at work must of thought I was nuts. I finally played through it again just to save it and went with the dialogue options I'd skip, later I understood what had happened. Anyways even though the game isn't funny, it is rather gothic, the rest of the game continued to surpise me. Ever since the manical laughter bit in the beginning (due to lack of sleep not that what actually happened was funny, it really wasn't) this game def. had me in its death grasp and wouldn't let go. Love it!

content:
Posted: August 25, 2015
												A very interesting story told in a point and click style game powered by the AGS engine. I enjoyed it. The puzzles ranged from easy to difficult. Some of them were very obvious while others were not but once you figured them out, you felt like you should have got it quicker. There is one part in Chapter 2 that is really hard, but once you get past it, you realize how easy it was. HINT: INTERACT WITH EVERYTHING. It made it fun to play.The voice acting was well done. The story was pretty good. I would like to replay parts of it and see what changes.Graphics 4/5. The word art style fits better then graphics imoSound 3/5 It was good not great. Does not take anything away and some of the voice capture was clearly done with a desktop mic. It added a certain quaintness to this indie title.The music was pretty good and fitting.Gameplay 3.5 /5 Using a keyboard was pretty easy and some of the mechanics I liked but it was annoying at times switching from  the inventory to using stuff on the screen. Kind of clunky but in no way terrible. Just difficult to master.Story 4/5 I enjoyed it and it told it very well. I would give it 5/5 but it did have some lackluster parts to it. This game does have some replay value in the story alone. It is solid and def. worth the $Overall: 4/5 taking away a point for some clunkyness in the controls and the sound being a bit poor at times, this is a solid game with a good story that is very much worth the $$. This is a indie game 100% through and it will be enjoyed by anyone who can watch the trailer and see something intriguing. That is what happened to me. Glad it did!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 20, 2015
												It took me a bit to warm up to this game, given the fairly low production values and the controls. Once I got used to it though, and past the intro, I became compelled to complete this odd game. I'm not into violence and don't watch horror films, so, I guess maybe I found some of the graphic things described in the game more disturbing than people who actually enjoy the horror genre would. (Which is to say, I enjoyed it, but horror-buffs might find it all a bit tame for their liking, maybe?) I found the ending (or at least the one I achieved) really cheesy. Also, there's one part that that I found waaaay too predictable, which completely ruined "the feels" I was probably meant to have. But don't get me wrong! This game had some absolutely fantastic moments which made it all very much worth it. It's the kind of thing I would buy again, and play again, if it were re-released on a bigger budget. It's not the art or music - it's the controls and gameplay itself that I'd like to see enhanced.Overall, I'd recommend this game, even though it doesn't have many "game" elements. It's a peaceful, interesting time killer, that I reckon will take a good 5 - 8 hours to get through.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 20, 2015
												A beautifully dark and accurate portrayal of depression. You play as Susan, aka the Cat Lady, who is depressed and no longer wants to be here in this world. However her suicide does not go as planned; instead she is now “immortal”. You get to choose why you make the choices you do throughout the game as you serve justice to bad people. You can lead Susan down different paths; redemptions, revenge, love, hate, sadness. It’s up to you. Please know that this IS a disturbing game. Controls are pretty straight forward, EXCEPT that I did not know you could skip dialogue using the space button until my second playthrough. The achievements are also not difficult but will require 2 playthroughs as some are based on decisions.9/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 20, 2015
												The Cat Lady does not require fast reflexes, complicated analysis of tactics, or grand sets of downloaded macros and addons to play. What it does require is a willingness to immerse yourself into a story that tackles the themes of suicide, death, friendship, and betrayal, just to name a few. If you want a fast action game experience, The Cat Lady is not for you. If you want to play a game where you spend almost as much time playing the game as having a cigarette and a cup of coffee contemplating the characters, their choices, and the very real moral and emotional issues brought up in a fictional game, you will not be disappointed. This is a hidden gem in indie games!

content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
												first of all, i should state that this is not a game, the results of every choice are pretty obvious, and there's no skill or strategy required, but that doesn't mean The Cat Lady isn't worth your money.The writing is pretentious, dark, emotional, and often times over the top... and I love every second of it.I'd argue its a visual novel and the story is the only reason anyone should buy it.the art work isn't stellar, but its theme is good, and genuinely creepy. the music feels out of place in the montages, rock just does not meld with macabre horror.without giving any spoilers, its a dark tale of facing through real life, dealing with depression, suicide, guilt, hate, jealousy, revenge, and a cornicopia of negative human emotions. The story at times can be a real tear jerker, and the characters (for the most part) are very relateble, or at the very least feel human (parasites not included). There's potential for multiple endings, but seeing as I got the best ending on my first try, i'm not really inclined to go through it again. If you'd like a piece of work that may make you cry, i'd strongly suggest picking up a copy of the cat lady.i give this "game" a 7/10

As Susan's story is gradually revealed, it really draws you in, and before you know it, you're up late at night trying to solve the chapters just so you could find out what happens next!The graphics might strike you as being crude at first, but stick with it. In fact the game is highly stylised, and you'll definitely appreciate some of the clever things they do with the artwork as the game goes on. My favourite involved distorted typography that reponds to... hmm... don't want to give that away. Just play it. You'll see.

content:
Posted: July 31, 2014
												This game is dark...VERY dark.  I made the wise choice of playing this at night with little sleep...which turned out to add a lot to the game itself.  The interface is very different than many adventures.  You can do everything with arrow keys.  However, the story is what makes this game shine, as countless other reviewers have stated.  I bought this game on sale...and it was a steal.  I understand why the game is $10, and it makes sense.  That's a prefect price point for the game.  Be prepared for a bit of a confusing beginning, as there is little direction on how to begin.  However, once everything gets going, the game plays itself.  There is a small amount of challenge in my opinion, but it complimented the game well.  There was never a moment that made me feel like I needed to take a breather because I was stuck, since the game wanted you to continue playing.  I would consider this a CASUAL adventure game for the simple fact that you're not spending 20 minutes trying to play with your inventory.  However, this game is far from a casual game.  It will have you interested from Chapter 2 til the end.  (Sorry, not a huge fan of chapter 1).  Great voice acting, great sprite work, and a great interface with ZERO bugs made for one hell of an indie game.  HIGHLY recommend.  10/10.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												9/10. An amazing game, only let down slightly by some poor voice acting and slightly rugged animation. However, the animation style does in some ways add to the unease and aesthetic of the game. It's a perfect, narratively beautiful, and metaphorically rich adventure puzzler, and provides a wealth of emotional responses, from disgust and horror to relief and a great sense of ease. A perfectly disturbing and horrific game with characters who are easy to relate to for all those who have/do suffer(ed) from mental illnesses such as depression. I would recommend this to anyone, so long as they are comfortable with some bloody horror; an overwhelming theme of suicide, mental illness and depression; and a huge sense of unease. I only wish I could find another game of the same style as this!

												First of all, this game has a great atmosphere, it's fantastic building tension. Throughout the game there were a number of sections where I knew what I had to do, but I really didn't want to because I knew it was going to be scary! Although sometimes the story can get a bit 'out-there', the overall plot draws you in. Characterisation is fantastic, a great mix of disturbing and ordinary people with some good voice acting. I loved the orginal graphic style, which suited the atmosphere of the game, also making for some good use of colours. Even though it was a bit low-res there weren't too many "find the pixel" moments and the puzzles were fairly logical if you thought about them for a bit.Overall, if you don't mind a story and text heavy game, you will be pleasantly rewarded playing this dark twist on what depression can feel like. I loved it!

content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												I don't typically write reviews about anything unless it is something REALLY amazing.First off, I got this on sale for 2.50 and it is worth so much more than that. If you like surreal themes, horror, and adventure, this is for you. I don't become scared or disturbed easily, but at times this game deeply disturbed and moved me. However, if subjects like death, suicide, and illness are currently too much for you, you may not want to play this. After a while I was afraid it may be too dark for me, it touched home too many times to count and made me a little uncomfortable. But, I felt compelled to push through the game because…well, I was enjoying it too much for the discomfort I was experiencing to stop me. It actually became a deeply personal thing to finish the game.It is a work of art, both grotesque and profoundly beautiful in meaning. It became so much more than a game, even by the end of the first chapter. You will find yourself sucked into this world and embracing it in no time at all. I only hope for more like it in the future.From what I can tell, there are different outcomes for the actions you choose, so no doubt I can play this again with different results, which is a huge plus. The controls are easy. Visually it is both simplistic and complex, you have to pay attention to your surroundings and really think. I love that this game challenges the player in so many ways. For the price it is well worth it, I say give it a shot! You may be as surprised as I was.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												The Cat Lady's plot is best experienced alongside the atmosphere of the game so I won't write a long-drawn out review that glosses over it and I'll cut straight to the point:It's hard to find a game so atmospheric as this one and one that affected me so much. The disturbing aspects weren't played to hyperbole and still retained genuine shock value that very few other games can create. Alongside that, I found the most believable and human relationships in a video game from the friendship you see between the protagonists. The Cat Lady is best described as a psychological adventure/horror and while there is no actual pointing and clicking involved it comes very close to a point-and-click game. Though there are a few puzzles here and there, they're nothing too difficult or are they ones that require a good chunk of your time to sit and think about before solving. This creates a near-perfect set up for leaving you with minimal frustrations and distractions to take away your experience of this truly disturbing game that is character-driven and poignant to the very end. Pros:+Well-worth the price for the amount of hours a typical playthrough can take + the multiple endings and dialogue options +Artwork is unique and immersive when combined+Simple controls +Character-driven +Puzzle difficulty is varying but it never gets too hard or easy and presents a moderate challenge to players+Disturbing without having to delve into too many cliches of horror/thriller+When the voice acting is good, IT'S GOOD. All accents can be understood and are variedCons:-Backtracking in some areas can become particularly annoying and very few hints are given-Jump-scares, although in third-person and won't make anybody fly out of their seat, are frequent within the first few chapters and played with a chord that takes away from all subtlety to the point of annoyance-When the voice acting is bad, it becomes painful to listen to and cringe-worthy-Music is BAD and repetitive and the sounds are hollow and in low qualityI recommend this game for anyone who can take a bit of gore and disturbing element, and anyone who is tired of bad plots and unbelievable characters and wanting something /more/ from their indie adventure games.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 13, 2014
												Personally, I loved this game.  Once I started it and worked out the mechanics of playing it I got really into the story and found it had a lot to offer:  It's not the slickest-looking game out there (graphics-wise) and the mechanics are pretty simple, but nevertheless it appeals to my nostalgia for older games (think Sanitarium, Broken Sword etc.) and the artwork really appealed to me - if you play it you'll see what I mean.  It takes elements of pixel art, illustration and mashes in some collaged photographic elements to give the various scenes a broken and dream-like feeling.   It plays with often striking monotonal / limited colour palettes, making the occasional splash of a colour very striking.  (Sorry, art student talk coming in a little here)  Visually, despite not being hyperrealistic (which seems to be what games try to push at, at the moment) I found it had its own unique beauty and personality that sadly seems to be lacking in a lot of bigger games we see at the moment.  I loved its dark, melancholy atmosphere and felt connected to the characters, the game explores themes such as loss, depression, trust, betrayal, loneliness and friendship, along with it's variety of shocking bloody scenes and horror elements. However, I didn't find this game very scary (and I'm known for being terrible with horror games - so if you're like me give it a go!) and that shouldn't take anything away from how enjoyable it is to play - it made me enjoy it so much more because it was a very different kind of experience.  There are plenty of your average run-of-the-mill jump-scare horror games out there for you if you are looking for something else at this point. The story really made this for me, it's hard to find a game that can make you feel so many different emotions in such a short space of time.  This game is quite short, but I found it had excellent replay value as I wanted to see how different choices / actions might have affected the story.9/10 (more plz)

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												Every once in a while, I find a game so imersive that I have to get out of it and stare at the wall for a few hours. This isn't easy with games; their nature lures you along for the ride and its difficult to put them in the freezer. Of the games I've played on steam, two fit this description: Amnesia (which, admittedly, hasn't clocked even fifteen minutes from me) and The Cat Lady. In all honesty, there are many reviews better than this one, but many of the elements I could criticize add to the aura of this game. The gameplay and artform take a few minutes to grow accustomed to, but causes the entire experience to feel heavy and bleak. This greatly portrays a status of depression that few can get right.A few times, I caught myself mulling over the voice actors; some of their tones come across as forced and out of sync with the situation, but, looking back, this is understandable. Susan and Mitzy stray away from human contact. They don't want to converse with another, and in some cases don't want to be alive at all. For those of you looking for a fast-paced horror experience, this is not the game for you (go play dead space or something). The fog of this game isn't something you can simply eliminate. There are jump scares, but not the sort that leave you laughing after the threat lies dead at your feet. They hang over you as Susan walks down yet another dark alley.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 25, 2015
												The Cat Lady is about depression. Full stop.As a metaphor, it’s fairly effective. A world out to eat you up, an implacable day-by-day pain, a life full of untrustworthy strangers who’ll hurt you if you get close, so you maintain an edgy distance, hostile or fearful. I don’t personally think the crazy-surreal-violent plot is meant to be taken literally, but I suppose it doesn’t much matter if you do take it literal. The theme is the same. This is a long-form treatment of the disease, and at least one of the better video game ones. If the Cat Lady can be a little uneven (and that’s actually arguably a strength), it conveys mood descriptively, and allows for moments of triumph, hope, and humor.Don’t expect anything polished. Do expect some goofiness, a general low-budgetality, typos, dreamy unexplained nonsense. But I found Cat Lady to be more effective than its occasionally clumsy components promised, and not as cruel as I feared. It’s not like Actual Sunlight, a game about depression where the “winner” of the game is preordained.In fact, it reminded me a bit of Infinite Jest, another messy, uneven treatment, and one that’s messy and uneven perhaps precisely because if you’ve been there, if you’re in there, the way out isn’t clear and isn’t clean and isn’t sure. Sometimes it’s going to be dark for a while, because the lights just won’t work, no matter how desperately you try to turn them on. But you close your eyes, you take a deep breath, and you keep doing in the dark, because you have to. You feel out new patterns, because you have to.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2015
												Dark, depressing and beautiful. Whoever handled the writing truly knew what depression is. Atmospheric art design, soundtrack and very well written dialogues. Sure, there are some unrealistic parts here and there for example !!Spoiler alert!! "When Susan calls the police and after a long conversation they just completely ignore her. In real life I'm sure that police isn't that unprofessional. The whole conversation just sounds like something that a person with very low self esteem would imagine."But these parts grow insignificant when looking back at the game and the many great things it had.It scratches the topic of psychopaths, cowards, attention ♥♥♥♥♥s. We also meet with people that just simply live sad lifes and they all behave differently towards the world. Susan is clearly the purest of all these as she just bleeds and cries silently without anyone seeing her instead of ruining the life of those around her out of attention seeking or just cowardness. She is also the one that I can relate to the most.The gameplay and the puzzles are nice. They are not THAT challenging but challenging enough to make you feel good after solving them and there are always a change of pace to prevent the gameplay from becoming dull.To sum everything up: I would personally call this game a masterpiece^^ If you have an artistic side or had depression it can really touch you and make you care for the characters. I would not recommend this though to the average shooter type.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2016
												I just played this game for 7.5 hours straight.  Wow...  just... wow.Completely immersive storyline, great art, spooky sounds, killer soundtrack.  I was hooked instantly.  Now the sun's up and I need to get some sleep!If you're a fan of old school games like Maniac Mansion (which a section of this game gives a BIG nod to, BTW), I Have No Mouth And I Must Scream, and other classic PC adventure titles, don't even hesitate to pick this up.I did have the occasional glitch, mostly involving strange slowdown occurrances (which I read you can alleviate with increasing the buffer size in the setup), controls getting messed up temporarily (sometimes I'd just rapidly twitch or smash the directional keys and the game didn't like it...), etc., but they didn't discourage me at all.I only had a few ACTUAL complaints.  First off, the voice acting is VERY inconsistant.  Some actors obviously recorded their lines in COMPLETELY different setups.  You'll hear crystal clear dialogue one second, then another actor will sound super compressed, 3 dB lower in volume, and loaded with plosives due to a lack of a pop screen.  Then the next line it may sound different again.  I'm a recording engineer (and also did voice work for a little game called Space Quest IV.5, which was also filled with inconsistent dialogue), so I may notice it a lot more than the casual player.The other complaint?  There's no way to skip dialogue or cut scenes.  I face-palmed every time I accidentally examined the dress in the last chapter and had to hear the whole speech on what it needed... again, and again, and again...But I digress.  This is a HEAVY story line with some REAL emotional impact.  Serious stuff that makes you question life and  your choices.  That's what makes you keep going, and I ran through it in one sitting!  I unlocked almost half of the achievements and got the "good" ending, so now I have to go back and get the other endings :)

I live in England and have never known anyone to own one or be able to get hold of them that easily. It seemed too American, even though the lead actually states 'This isn't America' at one point.The good;As someone who suffers from mental illness, I found this game incredibly helpful and feel everyone needs to play it, especially those who haven't encountered them themselves to get some understanding of what it is like.-Gorgeous game.-Fascinating story-A lot of good voice acting, esp the lead.-Interesting ideas.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
												I don't know why I bought this, but I'm glad I did. This indie game provides a nice and solid story with interesting themes. It's dark, gruesome and mature. The puzzles are not too bad either. The best part of this game is for me the atmosphere. The soundtrack is pretty much perfect and lifts the entire experience to a whole new level. Probably my favorite horror game thus far. The Cat Lady doesn't try to scare you with jumpscares like todays horror games to the point that it becomes silly, but rather builds a scary atmosphere and screws with your senses. The Cat Lady's only weak parts were some of the animations and voice acting, but it does not ruin the experience at all. The way it handles it's themes and tells it's story is really impressive. And it's a indie game too so that makes everything even more impressive! A definite *thumbs up* from me. Cheers!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												It's been several weeks since I finished The Cat Lady, and I still find myself thinking about it. This is the type of game that will never leave you. It deals with a lot of dark, sensitive topics (depression and suicide only being the beginning), but it is all very well done and very thought-provoking. I started this game when I was feeling rather down myself, and I got so immersed in  the plights of Susan and others that I completely forgot about what was stressing me out and ended up actually feeling a bit better after each time I played. I felt as if I knew some of these characters personally as I listened to their own struggles and quickly found myself growing attached to a few of them. Parts of the game had me tearing up, other parts had me swearing vengeance, and other times I found myself smiling. It was very hard to put down, and at one point I had to force myself to stop so that I could eat dinner (which I had told myself I was going to do an hour and a half prior when I started feeling hungry). The thick atmosphere had me always wondering what was going to happen next. It was creepy and unsettling, but not so horrifying that I had to walk away, which I found perfect. While there were a few jumpscares, I found myself able to tolerate them, and I absolutely hate jumpscares.Something else I absolutely love is that the game features multiple endings. There are many choices during the game and can have a big effect on the final outcome, or change a conversation you are having with another character. I have yet to discover the other endings, but I am looking forward to choosing different paths.The soundtrack to this game is also amazing. Shortly after finishing the game, I went and purchased a physical copy of the lyrical album (there are two soundtracks to the game, one of which comes with the game on Steam, while the other one does not) and I cannot stop listening to it. In fact, it was when Inside started playing in-game during a particularly intense moment at the beginning that I knew I was going to love this game.In summary, I highly recommend this game to anybody looking for an immersive story and experience. It's an emotional journey that you will not forget and will leave a lasting impression.

												This is a great game!At the start of the game it does not seem all that great but over time the story just drags you in by presenting questions with sanity breaking answers.  There are multiple times where it gets gross and scary to some extent and this is where the game is at its peak potental as its not just a blind scare, its also a puzzle during these times where you have to solve the situation to progress, this works REALLY well!  The art style is also to be recognised as it sets the atmosphere perfectly, although the odd scene does not seem right in terms of the game structure for example the main character looks a lot more sharper in detail compared to another character for some odd reason this however, is a very minor problem and it does not ruin the experience.This game is a shining example of how indie games should be made, its fun, interesting and very well made.  You would be a fool to not experience this story for yourself.The good+ The game will take hours to complete.+ The story is amazing.+ Every dialogue is voice narrated!The bad- Sometimes certain in game objects/character resolution does not make sence to the rest of the current scene.- No controller support (Although there is no real need for it).- The voice acting is not brilliant, but not terrible.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												First of all, this game has a great atmosphere, it's fantastic building tension. Throughout the game there were a number of sections where I knew what I had to do, but I really didn't want to because I knew it was going to be scary! Although sometimes the story can get a bit 'out-there', the overall plot draws you in. Characterisation is fantastic, a great mix of disturbing and ordinary people with some good voice acting. In particular the two protaganists are really likable, despite their tragic stories.  Occasionally the voice recordings sound a little poor, but this doesn't pull you from the game. I loved the orginal graphic style, which suited the atmosphere of the game, also making for some good use of colours. Even though it was a bit low-res there weren't too many "find the pixel" moments and the puzzles were fairly logical if you thought about them for a bit.Overall, if you don't mind a story and text heavy game, you will be pleasantly rewarded playing this dark twist on what depression can feel like. I loved it!

												This game has one of the best storylines that I have ever come across, and considering that storyline is one of the main reasons I buy a game, that counts for a lot. The game isn't amazingly long and although that would normally make me hesitant to give a game an amazing review, I'm not sure that the game actually needed to be any longer than it was. The game is by no means perfect, sometimes animations become clunky and there was one section where I thought the game was glitching because it was so unresponsive (I now think that this was intentional). Please note that none of this detracted from my enjoyment of this game. If you're someone who only likes a game when it's full of action, explosives and looks like it's been produced by Michael bay, then this game is not for you; however if like me you appreciate a good plot, progressive character development that isn't flat and some genuinely creepy moments, then I can highly recommend this game. 9/10

content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
 A little polish, and this game would be a masterpiece Even though I saw a LP of this game before playing, I still thoroughly enjoyed playing it myself. The Cat Lady is a dark adventure game starring Susan Ashworth, a woman who committed suicide and is offered a second chance by a mysterious lady who calls herself the Queen of Maggots. She says that Susan must kill 5 people called the Parasites. What happens next...must be experienced for yourself. Of course this goes without saying, there is minimal gamplay here. It's just puzzle solving/fetch quests. The appeal of the game is the story and characters. The gem of this game is, in my opinion, the platonic chemistry between the protagonist and Mitzi, a woman who becomes Susan's roomate. She has a dark charm to her, and her views on the world along with her sense of humor works wonderfully with the dialogue between her and Susan. They are similar, and yet different enough such that I can emotionally invest in them (it doesn't sound like Susan is talking to a mirror). The other benefit of this relationship is that gives Susan a 3d personality. She likes to close herself to the world, but isn't willing to completely give up on it. She knows that there are good people  in the world, and, after some caution, decides to open herself up to Mitzi, leading to the root of Susan's despair (while the plot goes off the deep end, I might add). Be prepared for the story that goes to some dark, crazy, creepy places. I enjoyed the violent, disturbing imagery and symbolism because it matches the tone and atmosphere of the story. It gives me something to think about, for it is somewhat abstract and cryptic. The aesthetics are rudimentary, black/white graphics with selective coloring, which again, compliments the tone and atmosphere. What I believe could have been better is a more seamless transition with the animation. There are many spots where there's an awkward delay. For example, moving Susan to chair so she can sit and talk with Mitzi results in her being frozen in place for a few seconds before actually sitting down. A similar issue exists with the dialogue; there are awkward pauses throughout. In addition, this may be because of concerns with audio quality (the developer not wanting the voice actors/actresses blowing out the microphone), but the volume of the voice actors/actresses are inconsistent. What I mean is, the subtitles sometimes indicate yelling, but the actor/actress isn't really yelling. A very small thing, but I would like to be able to delete my save files and turn on/off subtitles during any point in the game.The one big fault I found with the game was its tie-in with the creator's previous game, Downfall. I don't mind an easter egg or eggs referring to the game. What I do mind is my encounter with Joe Davis, which felt out-of-place with the story as a whole. It came off as tacked-on with no real connection to the game other than more violent, disturbing imagery.All-in-all, this game, I believe, really nailed the characters, particularly the back-and-forth between Susan and Mitzi. It showed Susan as someone who is going through depression (not just the sadness and the morbid mindset, but the hope of trusting in people again). The story was enjoyably messed up, but never over-the-top violent, and had an emotional pay-off.

content:
Posted: April 27, 2015
												The Cat Lady has to be one of the most engaging pyschological mind-jobs I've played in a long time. There's an intense feeling of dread and despair right from the start, and it spirals into a nightmarish bombardment of pain, doubt, and madness.  The graphics compliment the mood quite well, and the voice acting is above reproach. Playing with headphones is highly recommended, as the musical score goes a long way towards directing the mood of the various scenes.   The only complaints I have with the Cat Lady is the control scheme (you only use the directional keys and the Enter key, no mouse support), and the repetitous nature of the game (common with the point and click genre). Overall, I'd give it a 8.5/10.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2014
												The Cat Lady: The grim and haunting tale  of Susan, a depressed 40 year old woman,fighting her way to her salvation facing her  inner demons and the demons our society hides!The Cat Lady is a 2D psychological horror adventure with a unique  story.It has great soundtrack,very nice voice acting (especialy for the main protagonist) and beautifuly wierd artstyle.The writing and character dialogue is  mature and believable. No video game cliches here.Even though the story cannot be altered in great degree,there are some nice choices throughout the game and even a secret ending.The graphics are 2D hand drawn characters in a enviroment made,as far as i can tell,from  manipulated photοgraphs.The game is mostly black and white ,with some colors used to highlight parts of the world.The animations are poor,but the clunky movements somehow add to the wierd eerie atmosphere of the game.All in all the looks of the game are unique and fit the game perfectly.But the game its not without some faults.First of all,it has been made using the Adventure Game Studio and the game feels clunky at times.It has some wierd slowdowns on perfomance,that can be annoying.Also you cannot save more than 50 times,or overwrite/erase saves.50 seem a lot but i reached that number trying to complete some achievements,or explore all dialogue choices.The controls are a bit unresponsive at times and using the mouse might have worked better instead of just the keyboard.The sound levels are not normalised in some instances .Some of the voice actors didnt use decent equipment and you can hear easily the difference,for example between Susan and Mitzi.On the story side,i thought that some parts needed better development,like for example ,the guy with the hammer.But overall was great.But we are talking for a small indie game here and if you get into the story, the game's atmosphere  will make you want to finish the game,to see how this wierd tale end and you will ignore most of these issues! I personaly cant wait to see what else Remigiusz Michalski ,the creator, can make in the future with more time and budge on his hands.

												"Would you recommend this game?"HELL YES.First off, the game is a phenominal experience. It mixes horror with mature and relatable themes in life, mixed with (what I would call) puzzle solving.The gameplay can be frustrating at first, but once you get the hang of it you just might figure out that it's fun and rewarding.The story is FANTASTIC. It mixes horror themes with real life problems and creates a really cool atmosphere for this adventure. Some scenarios seem over-the-top and insane, but the way the world is built makes it so that you're totally immersed and wanting to continue every step of the way.This game now ties another for my #1 game of all time.OF.ALL.TIME.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 11, 2016
												This is probably one of my all-time favourites. I think the playtime in contrast to the actual length of the game speaks for itself. It just keeps you interested so that you try to go through all the options and unlock all the endings (which will have you fuming at the mouth with rage sometimes. Took me over a year and several playthroughs to get them all). But it never gets boring, even if you know what to do by heart. Every scene seems perfectly captured by "its" music, the atmosphere is disturbing and great, the balance between beauty and ugliness/carnage is just right and the characters really grow on you (big plus: great voice acting.) There is really no reason not to play this - maybe if you're not willing to spend your free time on "deep♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; like this. But otherwise, there isn't really an excuse. What I found striking was that even though it is full of morbid and depressing themes, there's really a lot of hope in it. Not that it's any way of therapy or even a healthy way of coping with problems, but I would say that it is uplifting and feels somewhat positive. Towards the end, that is.
