content:
Posted: May 22, 2015
												I believe it's safe to say that The Cat Lady is the "Silent Hill" of adventure games. The story ain't overly long but very creepy and very well told. It's a trip into the deepest and darkest corners of the soul of Susan, the main character in this game. She's suffering from depression and decides to commit suicide. What happens next is a soul trip of surreal horrors where she faces and challenges the darkness that tortured her soul for years of her life.The game has got quite a few shocking and disturbing moments and with its elements of depression, suicide, murder, perversion and violence it's clearly not a story for children. And the visuals add to this. The graphics style is quite unique and hardly ever used in games. Have a look at the screenshots and videos. Long parts of the game are quite monochrome, others play with colors some, which greatly adds to the atmosphere. The quality of graphics is not topnotch. The whole execution of the game is not, but hey, it's an indie adventure and what really counts here is theart of story telling. I think lovers of classic adventure games can easily forgive the low native resolution of the graphics, the sometimes toenail-curling voice acting and the lack of mouse controls (you play entirely with keyboard only) as the game rewards you with a truely creepy story in a truely creepy setting. Fans of psycho horror stories should definitely give it a try.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
												I think that sentence actually sums up nicely what I want to say about this game. The Cat Lady is an adventure/horror/fantasy game about a suicidal 40-year-old Londoner with a rather extraordinary fate. Susan Ashworth begins the story by attempting to kill herself. She succeeds but appears in some not-quite-afterlife where a mysterious figure tells her that she will be returned to her life and cannot permanently die until she rids the world of some "parasites" (evil people); the figure goes on to tell her that she will encounter these people over the course of her normal activities. When Susan does return to the land of the living, it appears as though her suicide attempt failed and she is being kept in a hospital for treatment and psychiatric evaluation. And just as the sinister entity predicted, she begins to encounter embodiments of all manner of human evils. Meeting these people and seeing them for who they are usually results in Susan's temporary demise, after which she awakens and enacts a grim vengeance upon them. The story changes a bit after she meets a young woman who has a very specific reason for wanting to rent a room in her flat, and the penultimate chapter is almost like a kind of whodunit. It is only after a series of these devastating encounters that Susan finds a reason for living again.The Cat Lady is a fairly short game: my playtime clocked in at about 11 hours, and I'm not the world's fastest player (I also reloaded once to go back and change a dialog at a binary decision point). However, it's not an easy game to play for several reasons. One is the interface. The game is made in Adventure Game Studio and it appears that the control scheme is fairly limited. There is very little reason to have a mouse connected as you'll do most of your work in this game using the arrow keys, space bar, and ENTER key on your keyboard, which is a rather clunky way of going about things. The other big one is that it's one of the darker games that you'll play, all the more so for mostly taking place in a realistic setting. It's definitely not for kids, with themes such as suicide, depression, stalking, infidelity, alcoholism, drug abuse, murder, serial murder, cannibalism, sexual assault, and slaughter of domestic cats. It was a depressing experience just to play the game, and I'm a relatively well-adjusted person. I have a hard time picturing someone with psychiatric issues completing this game.Graphically, it's nothing fancy, although the music is interesting. Most of the puzzles are fairly straightforward but I'll concede that I had to consult a walkthrough on several occasions when I got stuck. The story itself is worth getting through, but I can't see myself ever really wanting to play the game again. As it was, I basically restricted myself to playing one of the game's seven chapters per session. On the other hand, it's the only game in which I've ever gotten an achievement entitled "Go ♥♥♥♥ Yourself" so that has to count for something.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 26, 2014
												             The cat lady is a grim psychological thriller that grips you very early into the game with its gritty, distinctive aesthetic and it's magnetic narrative. As always, horrors are best played on your own in the dark with headphones, and I still recomend it here as it heightens the atmosphere, something you really want to get the most out of as the player movement is quite sluggish. A delight of the game is how it shows the uncanny in an ordinary world, where the horror unsettles through it's distortion of the familiar. As an adventure game, this ticks all the boxes though doesnt do much to add to the genre, but it certainly stamps it's own mark, esspecially as the first two of it's 7 chapters that burn so easily into memory with it's garish visuals and unique circumstances.               However, it must be said, the pacing drops during the middle of the game and it's a huge letdown considering the games amazing introduction, and it's here where the charaters odd voice acting becomes less odd and creepy, but reveal to be flat and unengaging - and this is a major letdown as it then also reveals some cheesy dialogue amid the script. An exception is the horrible cast of villains, some voiced by david firth (no suprise, given the visual style) which always brings tension right back to the heights with it's toe-curling delivery and conviction - and the games ending does reward your invested interest the story.             If you are a fan of adventure games, david firth or psychological thrillers, this comes with a heavy recomendation, though I think some others would be put of by the mostly terrible acting and may possibly bore those who don't invest themselves in it's unrelenting atmosphere. PROS:Near perfect introductionSolid puzzles, satisfying yet not frustratingAtmosphere in abundance, through great art style and sound effects.CONS:Increasingly cringe-worthy voice actingpacing issues, esspeically mid-gameThe 'hot topic' rock music enhances and ruins the atmosphere in equal measure7/10

content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												The best thing about this game is story and how it shows how much life can be hard and cruel. It follows a person named Susan Ashworth a.k.a The Cat Lady. She attempts to kill herself because she lost pretty much everything in her life, but fails and this is where the story begins. Fighting her own demons and depression she's about to meet some new problems and people. It's a puzzle game with a good storyline. There are few choices on crucial parts of the game giving it option for second playthrough. You really get surprised in some parts of the game and makes you wonder how many sick and twisted people are lurking free in the real world. The story is not very long, with 7 chapters, you might struggle with some puzzles but most are not that hard. It's really worth playing it if you are fan of horror games. 7.5/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												This is not a game about depression or mental illness, it is a supernatural/atmospheric psychological horror done in a point and click game. For plot reasons you get immortality early on in the game, so there really is no fear of a fail state, and there is no action element. If this is not your thing, do NOT get this game. The supernatural element is also quite clear, so there is no "is she mad or isn't she" element to the story line. I get the itch to play a horror story about once a year, and this one scratched that itch for me.The horror element is conveyed through the artwork, the plot, and the the general ambience. While I like the artwork overall, many of the female characters ended up looking very similar. The voice actors would occasionally stand too close to their mic resulting in some distortion in scenes where there should be none, but overall it was well plotted and scripted and did not overstay its welcome. I found the game slightly buggy at times - the walking animation was realy slow and the interface did not respond - shutting down and opening the game again sorted that out.

												Never has a game ever given me such a range of different emotions, much less at the intensity The Cat Lady has. The story was well-crafted; I can't think of a more relatable or sympathetic protagonist to anyone who has ever suffered depression and social isolation. I found the gameplay simple yet rewarding, and it was structured in a way that forcing me to think, without pushing me to consult a guide.A few of the animations were a bit wonky, but it was easily overlooked by the overall stylish presentation. I could likewise say that the music for some portions of the game felt inappropriate for the situation, but by and large the ost is phenomial as wellIf you aren't squeamish about horror, then I can't recommend it enough.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												Honestly I believe this is one of my favourite games ever. I played The Cat Lady through one day after calling off sick from work because I had a mixture of actual sickness and some rather dark thoughts. The same day it'd been on sale and it seemed interesting, like something to take my mind off of my own sad feelings, and it did more than that. Not spoiling anything, but the game is truly a masterpiece in regards to the representation of depression in it and just all the emotions. Between the characters and story I just had all the feels. I ended up playing through the whole game in about eight hours without breaks because it captivated m so much. By the end everything the game was saying sunk in, and I can honestly say that it really helped me on that day.I really can't praise this game more. I highly suggest this if any of the subject matters affected you, or are affecting you, or if you simply enjoy a darker tale. If you enjoy some rather morbid humor this'll be right up your alley as well. Besides that, just look at the wonderful gritty and grungy art, not to mention the good voice acting and music. If that doesn't convince you then nothing will.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2015
												It took me a bit to warm up to this game, given the fairly low production values and the controls. Once I got used to it though, and past the intro, I became compelled to complete this odd game. I'm not into violence and don't watch horror films, so, I guess maybe I found some of the graphic things described in the game more disturbing than people who actually enjoy the horror genre would. (Which is to say, I enjoyed it, but horror-buffs might find it all a bit tame for their liking, maybe?) I found the ending (or at least the one I achieved) really cheesy. Also, there's one part that that I found waaaay too predictable, which completely ruined "the feels" I was probably meant to have. But don't get me wrong! This game had some absolutely fantastic moments which made it all very much worth it. It's the kind of thing I would buy again, and play again, if it were re-released on a bigger budget. It's not the art or music - it's the controls and gameplay itself that I'd like to see enhanced.Overall, I'd recommend this game, even though it doesn't have many "game" elements. It's a peaceful, interesting time killer, that I reckon will take a good 5 - 8 hours to get through.

Posted: January 10, 2015
												Dark, raw, grim, and twisted. Emotional and depressing at times.  Intersting concept, but feels slightly rushed at times. Graphics are a bit lacking, but only add to the very story they are trying to portray. Controls are a bit wierd (no mouse) but are easy to adapt to, as buttons are limited to up, down, left, right, esc, and enter. Saves are limited to 50 total, so be sure to make a new folder in your saves and move old saves there, as it doesn't notify you when saves are no longer possible. Overall, worth picking up and giving it a spin.7.5/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												The Cat Lady's plot is best experienced alongside the atmosphere of the game so I won't write a long-drawn out review that glosses over it and I'll cut straight to the point:It's hard to find a game so atmospheric as this one and one that affected me so much. The disturbing aspects weren't played to hyperbole and still retained genuine shock value that very few other games can create. Alongside that, I found the most believable and human relationships in a video game from the friendship you see between the protagonists. The Cat Lady is best described as a psychological adventure/horror and while there is no actual pointing and clicking involved it comes very close to a point-and-click game. Though there are a few puzzles here and there, they're nothing too difficult or are they ones that require a good chunk of your time to sit and think about before solving. This creates a near-perfect set up for leaving you with minimal frustrations and distractions to take away your experience of this truly disturbing game that is character-driven and poignant to the very end. Pros:+Well-worth the price for the amount of hours a typical playthrough can take + the multiple endings and dialogue options +Artwork is unique and immersive when combined+Simple controls +Character-driven +Puzzle difficulty is varying but it never gets too hard or easy and presents a moderate challenge to players+Disturbing without having to delve into too many cliches of horror/thriller+When the voice acting is good, IT'S GOOD. All accents can be understood and are variedCons:-Backtracking in some areas can become particularly annoying and very few hints are given-Jump-scares, although in third-person and won't make anybody fly out of their seat, are frequent within the first few chapters and played with a chord that takes away from all subtlety to the point of annoyance-When the voice acting is bad, it becomes painful to listen to and cringe-worthy-Music is BAD and repetitive and the sounds are hollow and in low qualityI recommend this game for anyone who can take a bit of gore and disturbing element, and anyone who is tired of bad plots and unbelievable characters and wanting something /more/ from their indie adventure games.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												A story about depression, loneliness and death shrouded in a cloak of surreal horror, The Cat Lady has been one of the best games ive played of 2014. I just beat it all of an hour ago. You play as Susan Ashworth, a woman who attempts suicide at the beginning of the game, only to find herself in a surreal purgatory where a 'Queen of Maggots' reigns, and will not allow her death until she returns to life and kills 5 'parasites', all of which are serial killers in some way or another. For this, she curses this suicidal woman with that which she desires least: Immortality. She cannot die permanently until the 5 parasites are eliminated. She will otherwise always come back.The Queens realm has shades of Silent Hill-Esque macabre, a sort of hellish parody of reality. The game can be chilling and gruesome, but also poignant and touching. Throughout its course, you will find out -why- Susan became suicidal, and potentially find salvation and the strength to overcome her demons, her depression.If you can stomach the horror, and can get used to the somewhat stiff artstyle and general feel of the games clearly low budget, it is absolutely worth playing from beginning to end.Press any key to live.

The Cat Lady is a beautifully told story that meaningfully digs deep into some dark places. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 25, 2015
												The Cat Lady is about depression. Full stop.As a metaphor, it’s fairly effective. A world out to eat you up, an implacable day-by-day pain, a life full of untrustworthy strangers who’ll hurt you if you get close, so you maintain an edgy distance, hostile or fearful. I don’t personally think the crazy-surreal-violent plot is meant to be taken literally, but I suppose it doesn’t much matter if you do take it literal. The theme is the same. This is a long-form treatment of the disease, and at least one of the better video game ones. If the Cat Lady can be a little uneven (and that’s actually arguably a strength), it conveys mood descriptively, and allows for moments of triumph, hope, and humor.Don’t expect anything polished. Do expect some goofiness, a general low-budgetality, typos, dreamy unexplained nonsense. But I found Cat Lady to be more effective than its occasionally clumsy components promised, and not as cruel as I feared. It’s not like Actual Sunlight, a game about depression where the “winner” of the game is preordained.In fact, it reminded me a bit of Infinite Jest, another messy, uneven treatment, and one that’s messy and uneven perhaps precisely because if you’ve been there, if you’re in there, the way out isn’t clear and isn’t clean and isn’t sure. Sometimes it’s going to be dark for a while, because the lights just won’t work, no matter how desperately you try to turn them on. But you close your eyes, you take a deep breath, and you keep doing in the dark, because you have to. You feel out new patterns, because you have to.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 21, 2015
												Dark, depressing and beautiful. Whoever handled the writing truly knew what depression is. Atmospheric art design, soundtrack and very well written dialogues. Sure, there are some unrealistic parts here and there for example !!Spoiler alert!! "When Susan calls the police and after a long conversation they just completely ignore her. In real life I'm sure that police isn't that unprofessional. The whole conversation just sounds like something that a person with very low self esteem would imagine."But these parts grow insignificant when looking back at the game and the many great things it had.It scratches the topic of psychopaths, cowards, attention ♥♥♥♥♥s. We also meet with people that just simply live sad lifes and they all behave differently towards the world. Susan is clearly the purest of all these as she just bleeds and cries silently without anyone seeing her instead of ruining the life of those around her out of attention seeking or just cowardness. She is also the one that I can relate to the most.The gameplay and the puzzles are nice. They are not THAT challenging but challenging enough to make you feel good after solving them and there are always a change of pace to prevent the gameplay from becoming dull.To sum everything up: I would personally call this game a masterpiece^^ If you have an artistic side or had depression it can really touch you and make you care for the characters. I would not recommend this though to the average shooter type.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												It's been several weeks since I finished The Cat Lady, and I still find myself thinking about it. This is the type of game that will never leave you. It deals with a lot of dark, sensitive topics (depression and suicide only being the beginning), but it is all very well done and very thought-provoking. I started this game when I was feeling rather down myself, and I got so immersed in  the plights of Susan and others that I completely forgot about what was stressing me out and ended up actually feeling a bit better after each time I played. I felt as if I knew some of these characters personally as I listened to their own struggles and quickly found myself growing attached to a few of them. Parts of the game had me tearing up, other parts had me swearing vengeance, and other times I found myself smiling. It was very hard to put down, and at one point I had to force myself to stop so that I could eat dinner (which I had told myself I was going to do an hour and a half prior when I started feeling hungry). The thick atmosphere had me always wondering what was going to happen next. It was creepy and unsettling, but not so horrifying that I had to walk away, which I found perfect. While there were a few jumpscares, I found myself able to tolerate them, and I absolutely hate jumpscares.Something else I absolutely love is that the game features multiple endings. There are many choices during the game and can have a big effect on the final outcome, or change a conversation you are having with another character. I have yet to discover the other endings, but I am looking forward to choosing different paths.The soundtrack to this game is also amazing. Shortly after finishing the game, I went and purchased a physical copy of the lyrical album (there are two soundtracks to the game, one of which comes with the game on Steam, while the other one does not) and I cannot stop listening to it. In fact, it was when Inside started playing in-game during a particularly intense moment at the beginning that I knew I was going to love this game.In summary, I highly recommend this game to anybody looking for an immersive story and experience. It's an emotional journey that you will not forget and will leave a lasting impression.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2014
												The Cat Lady is an interesting "point and click" game with a deliciously dark undertone. So lets start with whats not so good. Well, the voice recording is pretty poor, and whilst the vocal acting is acceptable it sounds like it was recorded on the cheapest mic that Maplins had for sale. Its also a bit annoying that the dialogue options don't actually show the whole sentence so theres a bit a pot luck that the response is the one you want. The graphics are "low quality" but I don't think that particularly detracts from the game. The plot is a bit illogical and there's a couple of unfinished questions but its quite original. Whats good about it is that the guys and girls at Harvester have made a really gritty horror game. There aren't any shocks in there, but its got that dark undertone that I really like. The puzzles are straightforward but enjoyable enough, and having done a couple of play throughs there's some moral choices which are quite interesting. Overall its an enjoyable enough little indie game that could've done with a touch more refinement. My score is a reasonable 7/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												The best thing about this game is story and how it shows how much life can be hard and cruel. It follows a person named Susan Ashworth a.k.a The Cat Lady. She attempts to kill herself because she lost pretty much everything in her life, but fails and this is where the story begins. Fighting her own demons and depression she's about to meet some new problems and people. It's a puzzle game with a good storyline. There are few choices on crucial parts of the game giving it option for second playthrough. You really get surprised in some parts of the game and makes you wonder how many sick and twisted people are lurking free in the real world. The story is not very long, with 7 chapters, you might struggle with some puzzles but most are not that hard. It's really worth playing it if you are fan of horror games. 7.5/10

content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												This is not a game about depression or mental illness, it is a supernatural/atmospheric psychological horror done in a point and click game. For plot reasons you get immortality early on in the game, so there really is no fear of a fail state, and there is no action element. If this is not your thing, do NOT get this game. The supernatural element is also quite clear, so there is no "is she mad or isn't she" element to the story line. I get the itch to play a horror story about once a year, and this one scratched that itch for me.The horror element is conveyed through the artwork, the plot, and the the general ambience. While I like the artwork overall, many of the female characters ended up looking very similar. The voice actors would occasionally stand too close to their mic resulting in some distortion in scenes where there should be none, but overall it was well plotted and scripted and did not overstay its welcome. I found the game slightly buggy at times - the walking animation was realy slow and the interface did not respond - shutting down and opening the game again sorted that out.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												First of all, this game has a great atmosphere, it's fantastic building tension. Throughout the game there were a number of sections where I knew what I had to do, but I really didn't want to because I knew it was going to be scary! Although sometimes the story can get a bit 'out-there', the overall plot draws you in. Characterisation is fantastic, a great mix of disturbing and ordinary people with some good voice acting. In particular the two protaganists are really likable, despite their tragic stories.  Occasionally the voice recordings sound a little poor, but this doesn't pull you from the game. I loved the orginal graphic style, which suited the atmosphere of the game, also making for some good use of colours. Even though it was a bit low-res there weren't too many "find the pixel" moments and the puzzles were fairly logical if you thought about them for a bit.Overall, if you don't mind a story and text heavy game, you will be pleasantly rewarded playing this dark twist on what depression can feel like. I loved it!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 16, 2014
												    The Cat Lady is easily one of the more interesting games i have played through. It is a dark story following a 40 year old woman with a love for cats that commits sucide but instead of just dying she finds herself in an odd realm with a rather trippy and dark journey ahead of her. To start, the story was really beautiful and dark, you are easily able to feel for and understand the characters and the strifes they are going through as they happen or are revealed. The game is very good about steering you in the right direction as far as knowing what is interactive in the world, by literally pointing to it as you pass by the item, and the areas are well set up to where getting lost or stuck is never a worry. There are a fair about of puzzles so if you're not at least ok at puzzles, this game might not be for you, but really they are not all that bad. The puzzles help with the lack of interaction and reaffirm that it is a game and not just a story being told to you. The controls are very simple, on just about any keyboard, you can easily play this game with one hand. This aspect actually helps you to simply relax and enjoy the brilliantly dark storyline, since you are not having to worry about complicated controls. The only problem I really had with this game was the save system it was, to put it blunt, BAD. When you wanted to save multiple times through the game it had to be a brand new file there was no overwrite action but overall that's not really a problem as long as you have the patience to name you save files accordingly, not that i ever did. Overall it was an amazing game. The cat lady is a very good game for anyone who likes dark stories and puzzles. I highly recommend this game to everyone, especially if you want a break from all the heavy action games and relax with a good story.

												Best narrative adventure game I've played in a long time--and I just finished playing Gemini Rue right before it, so that's saying something.  You do have to be in the right mood to play it, or else you should be willing to put yourself in the right mood.  The art style appears intentional and suits the tone of the game perfectly. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												The Cat Lady is mind-blowingly good.Which came as a bit of a surprise to me. There's wasn't that much in the trailer, screenshots, or description, which suggested that it would turn out to be such an unforgettable, stand-out experience.Somehow, the whole package manages to be so much greater than the sum of its parts. It gradually draws you into its own hugely compelling and intriguing world, and you find yourself really caring about the characters and their fates, and wondering what weird and unexpected paths lie ahead.The graphics and music - which from a distance threaten to be too 'indie' for their own good - turn out to be damn near perfect.Yes, aspects of the game are deliciously dark and twisted - that much is obvious from the trailer - but there's a great deal or intriguing story here which is grounded in reality: as the plot unfolds, you'll explore characters' histories, emotions, philosophies, and relationships. In other words, it's not some boring gore-fest.I also found the game to be refreshingly original. There really is nothing else quite like it. If you pick the game apart, then you can see it's influences and precedents, and even flaws. But taken as a whole, it is sublime.By the time I was about half way through this game, I found myself 'rationing' it into shorter sessions, so that it wouldn't be over too soon. A game this good comes along once in a blue moon, and I didn't want it to end.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 21, 2015
												Dark, depressing and beautiful. Whoever handled the writing truly knew what depression is. Atmospheric art design, soundtrack and very well written dialogues. Sure, there are some unrealistic parts here and there for example !!Spoiler alert!! "When Susan calls the police and after a long conversation they just completely ignore her. In real life I'm sure that police isn't that unprofessional. The whole conversation just sounds like something that a person with very low self esteem would imagine."But these parts grow insignificant when looking back at the game and the many great things it had.It scratches the topic of psychopaths, cowards, attention ♥♥♥♥♥s. We also meet with people that just simply live sad lifes and they all behave differently towards the world. Susan is clearly the purest of all these as she just bleeds and cries silently without anyone seeing her instead of ruining the life of those around her out of attention seeking or just cowardness. She is also the one that I can relate to the most.The gameplay and the puzzles are nice. They are not THAT challenging but challenging enough to make you feel good after solving them and there are always a change of pace to prevent the gameplay from becoming dull.To sum everything up: I would personally call this game a masterpiece^^ If you have an artistic side or had depression it can really touch you and make you care for the characters. I would not recommend this though to the average shooter type.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 18, 2015
												I loved the scenery, the sound effects, the choice of style for the characters as well. Of course, the soundtrack is amazing and I loved the opening credits! Wonderful voice actors really add to the story. The story is is very unique, and the trials of the protagonist on multiple-levels was very compelling. The sad irony of life was well portrayed here.I am very impressed, and despite the side-scrolling format, it was a definite gem. (Warning, if playing for hours right before sleeping, you are likely to have some twisted dreams :)The only thing that I wish this game could have done more of, was having the player's choices really affecting the outcome of the scenarios. There was a feeling of freedom and choice, but really it is pretty set from the beginning. I also greatly appreciated some of the challenges, but sometimes I was worried that I had a glitch when it took me forever to figure them out:SPOILER............The landscape on the pier and the 'Misery' for example. I think this game could use options for subtle hints here and there when a person feels stuck. One snag I also discovered, was when I did solve the puzzle correctly, but it was so specific to where I clicked the mouse (even trying it a few times) that I kept trying other avenues before eventually returning to the - almost - exact same spot and finding that I was right from early on.All in all, a definite must for those with a darker sense of humor and enjoyment in their game-play!

												"Achievement Unlocked: Go ♥♥♥♥ Yourself"10/10 Best Game.Actual Serious Review:ORIGINALLY WRITTEN ON NOVEMBER 18, 2013:Gonna use this slot for the Cat Lady, and maybe move this to the actual game page when it becomes available on Steam. All I have to say is... If you like cutting yourself, doing ♥♥♥♥ed-up♥♥♥♥♥♥to corpses, and cats, then boy, have I found a game for you!In all seriousness, it's a wonderful game and I enjoyed it a lot. The story is great, there was a moment where I was able to really visualize a narrative someone is verbally speaking to me without any visual aspects to it involved, which surprised me, since I'd say I'm a 90% visual-based and 10% audio-based person. Some of the puzzles can be a bit tricky, but can usually be solved by "examine everything, pick up everything, and use everything on everything" logic. I didn't need any external help, at any rate (beyond the video series that brough me to the game in the first place, techncally, but I didn't seek it out because I was stuck or anything), and as far as I can tell it's difficult or impossible to actually fail anything and need to restart. Which makes it feel more like a visual novel with puzzles at times, but that doesn't mean it's not worth your time. Oh, and everyone seems to think it's a horror game, but, it really isn't. It did make me jump once, and there was one part where the audio was so creepy I had to take off my headphones after a while, but the rest of it is basically just piano dischords at random moments, to the point of being almost cheesy. It's not Amnesia or Slender or anything, to be sure. And it has a great sense of humor, too, everything from a difficult old man who has hearing problems and repeats himself to actually being able to call the police when you're in trouble instead of solving the puzzles to escape, but only to have them be complete government airheads and be no help at all to you anyway. It's wonderful and I love it.I'd actually recommend people with clinical depression play this game. Which sounds weird, you'd think a game like this'd only make depression worse, but it has powerful messages in regards to that, especially the ending. It reminds me of a story I heard about a guy whose girlfriend recently broke up with him and the ending of Bastion helped him get through it. There's even a separate plotline that addresses flame arguments on the Internet. Are you really going to let some random nerd get you down, hm?THINGS I'D LIKE TO APPEND:Tech:The above review was for the 1.2 version from their website ( http://thecatlady.co.uk/ ), and there are definitely technical differences between that and the 1.4 version from Steam that I just played through recently. The verson I first played had no proper options menu and was locked to certain settings, including fullscreen 800x600 only, but other than a few engine quirks it was basically perfect, so it worked just fine. The new version has a basic options menu, the option for a windowed mode is particularly welcome, but it's still locked to 800x600, which makes the windowed mode kind of awkward. I also noticed some fairly terrible text bugs where both dialogue tree text and subtitles would get cut off, which got really irritating at times. There were also a few minor graphical glitches, namely with new user-friendly menu icons, and an item in my inventory was never deleted properly and I had it for the entire game. And on top of it all, I also got weird lag that would make the audio jutter for a second upon changing scenes. So yeah, I'm not sure if it's Steam vs. non-Steam or 1.2 vs. 1.4, but if you can get ahold of the older non-Steam version, I'd say that's definitely the better one, provided you don't care about a windowed mode/other settings, Steam achievements, and trading cards.A few engine issues plague both versions, but they're not really game-breakers as long as you bear in mind that this is an indie game that doesn't come with triple-A smoothness. Odd music cutoffs, confusing graphics movement, inability to overwrite saves, occasional iffy voice acting and quality (some halfhearted laughter, minor normalization differences, really wish one of the voice actors had used a popshield), clunky arrow controls and menu navigation, can't skip cutscenes, things like that. For the most part these don't really impede gameplay, but hearken back to a more retro style of gaming; if you grew up in the NES/SNES/DOS era, you'll do just fine.Gameplay:It's a visual novel point-and-click thing that uses metaphors to tell the story of a woman's struggles with clinical depression. Apparently "puzzle game without failure states" was my way of saying "point-and-click" the first time around. A lot of people do seem to think it's a horror game, and while it is very grim and creepy with an occasional jumpscare, it's definitely more story-centered than it is scare-centered. The story is absolutely bonkers though, which is definitely a good thing, considering how slow and bogged-down it can feel with dialogue sometimes. Also the soundtrack is one of the best in any game I've played to date, with a good balance of passive atmospheric background noise and songs that actively grab your attention and really drive home what's happening on the screen.Conclusion:If you like visual novels that carve corpses up like pumpkins and don't mind engine quirks to do it, then why do you not already have this?

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 25, 2015
												The Cat Lady is about depression. Full stop.As a metaphor, it’s fairly effective. A world out to eat you up, an implacable day-by-day pain, a life full of untrustworthy strangers who’ll hurt you if you get close, so you maintain an edgy distance, hostile or fearful. I don’t personally think the crazy-surreal-violent plot is meant to be taken literally, but I suppose it doesn’t much matter if you do take it literal. The theme is the same. This is a long-form treatment of the disease, and at least one of the better video game ones. If the Cat Lady can be a little uneven (and that’s actually arguably a strength), it conveys mood descriptively, and allows for moments of triumph, hope, and humor.Don’t expect anything polished. Do expect some goofiness, a general low-budgetality, typos, dreamy unexplained nonsense. But I found Cat Lady to be more effective than its occasionally clumsy components promised, and not as cruel as I feared. It’s not like Actual Sunlight, a game about depression where the “winner” of the game is preordained.In fact, it reminded me a bit of Infinite Jest, another messy, uneven treatment, and one that’s messy and uneven perhaps precisely because if you’ve been there, if you’re in there, the way out isn’t clear and isn’t clean and isn’t sure. Sometimes it’s going to be dark for a while, because the lights just won’t work, no matter how desperately you try to turn them on. But you close your eyes, you take a deep breath, and you keep doing in the dark, because you have to. You feel out new patterns, because you have to.

												This game is about depression, suicide, sociopathy and death.  Therefore, it is not for everyone.  However, if you're in the mood for a scary yet contemplative choice-based story that sensitively and deftly deals with one or more of the above issues, then by all means, have at! number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 26, 2016
												"The Cat Lady" is an atmospheric, narrative focussed adventure game. You play as Susan Ashworth, a woman who has just finished trying to kill herself. The attempt fails at the behest of a withered guardian angel who gives her life newer, bloodier meaning.When reviewing games, I often prefer to determine the game's intent subjectively and then evaluate it on whether or not it succeeded in that intent as opposed to a blunt numerical score. Knowing this, what was the intent behind "The Cat Lady"?The intent was clearly to tell a psychological horror story that delves into the extremes of violence and depravity human nature can take through an interactive medium. Does it succeed in this?Short answer? Absolutely. Why? * All the characters are voice acted, with only minor examination dialogue being omitted from Susan. Her voice actress in particular is very good and not once is it possible to think her a hollow mouthpiece by which the developer spouts psuedo-deep dialogue. Indeed, Susan Ashworth really is a believable, sad character. The supporting cast I can't 100% give a positive review about, particularly Mitzi. Although the acting itself is absolutely fine, for some reason it sounds like it was recorded on a toaster. Overall, its strengths shadow the weaknesses.* The surreal imagery is intriguing in its own right and prevents the player from ever knowing for sure what will happen next. Right from the get-go, you have to question whether or not what you're seeing is real. By putting the player on-edge like this, it readies them for the psychological assailment they will face throughout.* The art, from the character design to the environments, conveys a feeling of hopelessness and uncertainty, which is perfect for playing a character like Ashworth and especially in a story such as this. It's almost as if her own fears and doubts manifest themselves in the environments. It is used to evoke genuine horror without a single jump scare.* The actual gameplay is interwoven with plenty of insights from Susan. It's not a few button presses tacked onto a quick time event. This is indeed a game, with emotionally charged choices and dialogue options that can lead to the death of friends. In short, this isn't a game you're playing for the puzzles. The Cat Lady is full of dialogue, thought and creativity and should be played for the narrative. If you're looking for jump scares or something fun to stream on a Friday night, this isn't the game for you. If you're a fan of psychological horror and would like to get invested in a deep, dark and intelligent story, then at $10.00, "The Cat Lady" is absolutely worth your time, but it's not for the faint of heart.

												I've been waiting for this game to come down in price for a while, so when it did I was thrilled. I started playing right away and was mesmerised by the art style.The bad;-So much dialogue. Sometimes I just wanted to ditch it because I was bored of listening and talking. There are times when it feels like an interactive novel and not a game.-Eric - his voice acting is so bad it made his scenes lose any impact.-Saves - not being able to save over existing saves is a pain, especially as there is a limited number of times you can save.-I'm guessing from the postcode that this game is set in England, but everyone seems to have guns. I live in England and have never known anyone to own one or be able to get hold of them that easily. It seemed too American, even though the lead actually states 'This isn't America' at one point.The good;As someone who suffers from mental illness, I found this game incredibly helpful and feel everyone needs to play it, especially those who haven't encountered them themselves to get some understanding of what it is like.-Gorgeous game.-Fascinating story-A lot of good voice acting, esp the lead.-Interesting ideas.

												PSY HORROR, never liked honor games until this one. This Psy Thriller has limits of horror, made me want more of this game each time I play it. I can't believe I connected with the character on a personal level since we all now a days deal with these types of problems in the world that the game brings up here and there. If you wanted to sit down and pick apart each limit of this game, you can find so many underlining themes or meaning in this game its unbelievable. Having some medical background, I felt this was very real with how the characters talk, I truly believe you should answer or pick what you would pick if you were the character. Makes the game worth my money....below I wrote each time I stop to take a break, let you know how much I kept playing before stopping each time.**SAVING PROBLEMBefore you even play it go into your steamapps folder, right click on TheCatLady, uncheck read only, and apply.Now let me play this game, I will get back to you, Now that I can Save This♥♥♥♥♥♥as I go.**Hour and Half LaterAfter play about hour and half. I am addicted to it. Puzzles not gonna lie, make you think different and are pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ so far I need to go play more...brb**six hours after starting from the startI think ♥♥♥♥ is the favorite word in this game, nicely placed right when you need it in the story. A lot of it is story but answer it as you were the main character and you feel more connected with the story. Which this makes me like it a lot. I feel if you do not like puzzles which make you want to♥♥♥♥♥♥yourself in the end wondering WTF AM I DOING moments.....its ok try a walkthrough. Even if you beat it with or without the walkthrough it is so worth the 10 bucks.Yes you will figure out why the hell the game is called the Cat Lady at some point. Not sure how you will feel about it or if it means♥♥♥♥♥♥to you if there is a Cat or a damn Dog...I will let you know how I feel about the end once I am done.Starting chatper 6....**9hours laterAfter playing this game for 9 hours, of course I am sure it didn't take that long since I took a lot of breaks but still close to the time it took. I am not sure how to feel about the ending, or maybe endings as I was told by someone. WIthout any research of the game, only hearing there are different endings. I of course not sure if there isn't or not. I have only unlocked 56% of everything so I will have to go back and play through it again and let you know how it went differently or not.After finally coming to the end of the game, I enjoyed how it took place I believe France with the feel I had with it but maybe England since everyone was speaking english. I am very bad with details of real life events so I am not sure what unlining story the game may have but it did hit home. Though I enjoyed it very much. Made me want to keep playing more of these types of game. I really want to see these game makers make another one. I love the jokes in it because its dry humor so if you are a bubbly type of person, sorry you may not understand it. I love how well rounded the game is, between medical information you get and ways people would interact with enough other. The puzzles are a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥you really have to put yourself inside the story to figure the out, or be just as ♥♥♥♥ed up in the head which ever. I feel if this game would of been put out at any other time it would of been unrecommend because of how this PSY horror was told.Please make more like this, please even make happy games this style please so my mother can keep playing games too. For my first psy horror well first horror game played and beaten all the way through not quitting like a ♥♥♥♥♥ after 10mins :)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 26, 2016
												"The Cat Lady" is an atmospheric, narrative focussed adventure game. You play as Susan Ashworth, a woman who has just finished trying to kill herself. The attempt fails at the behest of a withered guardian angel who gives her life newer, bloodier meaning.When reviewing games, I often prefer to determine the game's intent subjectively and then evaluate it on whether or not it succeeded in that intent as opposed to a blunt numerical score. Knowing this, what was the intent behind "The Cat Lady"?The intent was clearly to tell a psychological horror story that delves into the extremes of violence and depravity human nature can take through an interactive medium. Does it succeed in this?Short answer? Absolutely. Why? * All the characters are voice acted, with only minor examination dialogue being omitted from Susan. Her voice actress in particular is very good and not once is it possible to think her a hollow mouthpiece by which the developer spouts psuedo-deep dialogue. Indeed, Susan Ashworth really is a believable, sad character. The supporting cast I can't 100% give a positive review about, particularly Mitzi. Although the acting itself is absolutely fine, for some reason it sounds like it was recorded on a toaster. Overall, its strengths shadow the weaknesses.* The surreal imagery is intriguing in its own right and prevents the player from ever knowing for sure what will happen next. Right from the get-go, you have to question whether or not what you're seeing is real. By putting the player on-edge like this, it readies them for the psychological assailment they will face throughout.* The art, from the character design to the environments, conveys a feeling of hopelessness and uncertainty, which is perfect for playing a character like Ashworth and especially in a story such as this. It's almost as if her own fears and doubts manifest themselves in the environments. It is used to evoke genuine horror without a single jump scare.* The actual gameplay is interwoven with plenty of insights from Susan. It's not a few button presses tacked onto a quick time event. This is indeed a game, with emotionally charged choices and dialogue options that can lead to the death of friends. In short, this isn't a game you're playing for the puzzles. The Cat Lady is full of dialogue, thought and creativity and should be played for the narrative. If you're looking for jump scares or something fun to stream on a Friday night, this isn't the game for you. If you're a fan of psychological horror and would like to get invested in a deep, dark and intelligent story, then at $10.00, "The Cat Lady" is absolutely worth your time, but it's not for the faint of heart.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 2, 2016
												I don't often write reviews for games after I play them, but this game deserves some recommendation. When I first got the game, I played 5 minutes of it and it just seemed slow and not too great. THOUGH that was most definitely not a bad thing. As I continued to play, it began to explain its self. I stopped worrying so much about the awkward gameplay and more about the story and the world. I got ridiculously immersed even though the gameplay was confusing and some processes took me a long time. It throws you in a world you know little about, but enough to guess and question. So learning the story as it reveals is extremely satisfying. The story offers deep perspective, it is very unpreictable, immersive, emotional and it does a very great job at making a real world setting sinister, creepy and without jumpscares, horriffic while remaining realistic. Which for a sidescrolling game like this one, I imagine would be awfully hard to do. Not to mention the artstyle. It is so inconsistent in textures - between realistic and pixelated - but it somehow manages to create the perfect aptmosphere  that's easy to look at. A unique and admirable artstyle. The games story and art makes up for the slow and at times awkward gameplay by far. I RECOMMEND THIS GAME IF:You would like to get immersed in a twisted creepy depressing story.You like puzzles.You like simple, though quality games.You're a fan of psyhcological horror games.And I recommend it to anyone else who's interested. It is well worth $10 for sure.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2016
A Long Review for The Cat LadyThis game is my first purchase here on Steam. All I can say is that the story is brilliant but the voice acting is pretty bad. The puzzles are good though. I also like how the game messed up my mind on how I should make good decisions to get the right ending and achievements. I am done with al of the achievements now. Is it scary? Yes, it is scary if you thought about the story as a whole but like other horror stories, it has some boring chapters, too. I don't like Chapter 5 and 6. It didn't make it terrifying for me. Chapter 2 and 4 are my best bets because of the horrific atmosphere and unimagineable scenarios that will definitely make you terrified. Well, for Chapter 6, it must have been horrific for me but one thing that does not make sense is the part when Susan met Joe then everything went into a nightmare. When she finally woke up from the nightmare, she got back from her original place to meet up with Mitzi. Strangely enough, the items you got from the nightmare were in your inventory. It does not make ANY sense!! So, this is the reason why Chapter 6, for me, ruined the whole horror scenario. Other than that scene, there are some more questionable scenes for the couple Joe and Ivy Davis that I think if you have not played the first game called Downfall, you won't be able to understand what is going on with them at all. They should have made it more intense than the phrase "Devil came through here" and the screams. I mean is that suppose to scare me? In Chapter 5, things are good with the story-telling and finally, a revealation about Susan's past. What I didn't get was the pursuer. Why is he holding flowers and suddenly, attacked from nowhere? Do the developers want us to believe that this guy is just a psycho who breaks randomly on other people's flat? And why is he holding the same flowers that Susan remembered in her past? If he was the suitor of Susan in the past, she would have noticed his face from the confrontation but no.... He was just a psycho guy who wanted to kill them. I do believe it destroyed the whole sense of the story. How I wish it was Eric's relative or the suitor Susan met before. I want to also add the unnecessary bug I found in-game. It was in Chapter 2. The sarcastic nurse was repeating her own lines when she read the wrist band as Anne Burton before she injects me a drug. I wish the developers have fixed it. Story - 8/10 (great story but with some loopholes) Characters - 7/10 (Some characters does not make any sense like the Psycho guy in chapter 5. However, the main character, Susan Ashworth, has a good character development throughout the game) Graphics - 7/10 (There are some scenes that the character sprites seem inconsistent. I noticed that especially in the beginning of Chapter 2) Gameplay- 10/10 (Absolutely a good puzzle game) Atmosphere - 8/10 (The story makes you feel terrified except for Chapter 5 and 6) Audio - 7/10 (good ambience, sound and music but bad voice overs)Overall, the story is good. There are just some loopholes and unnecessary scenes that I wish was recognized and got fixed. Despite the negatives, I still think this is a good game and worth your time and money. You have to play this game untill the end to appreciate its beauty. The sounds and music of this game is great though. I like it a lot. Is this worth your money? Yes, it is worth your money especially if you're into Psychological Horror with Puzzle games. This is absolutely for you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 12, 2014
												The Cat Lady: The grim and haunting tale  of Susan, a depressed 40 year old woman,fighting her way to her salvation facing her  inner demons and the demons our society hides!The Cat Lady is a 2D psychological horror adventure with a unique  story.It has great soundtrack,very nice voice acting (especialy for the main protagonist) and beautifuly wierd artstyle.The writing and character dialogue is  mature and believable. No video game cliches here.Even though the story cannot be altered in great degree,there are some nice choices throughout the game and even a secret ending.The graphics are 2D hand drawn characters in a enviroment made,as far as i can tell,from  manipulated photοgraphs.The game is mostly black and white ,with some colors used to highlight parts of the world.The animations are poor,but the clunky movements somehow add to the wierd eerie atmosphere of the game.All in all the looks of the game are unique and fit the game perfectly.But the game its not without some faults.First of all,it has been made using the Adventure Game Studio and the game feels clunky at times.It has some wierd slowdowns on perfomance,that can be annoying.Also you cannot save more than 50 times,or overwrite/erase saves.50 seem a lot but i reached that number trying to complete some achievements,or explore all dialogue choices.The controls are a bit unresponsive at times and using the mouse might have worked better instead of just the keyboard.The sound levels are not normalised in some instances .Some of the voice actors didnt use decent equipment and you can hear easily the difference,for example between Susan and Mitzi.On the story side,i thought that some parts needed better development,like for example ,the guy with the hammer.But overall was great.But we are talking for a small indie game here and if you get into the story, the game's atmosphere  will make you want to finish the game,to see how this wierd tale end and you will ignore most of these issues! I personaly cant wait to see what else Remigiusz Michalski ,the creator, can make in the future with more time and budge on his hands.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 21, 2016
												Heavy. This is a game that tackles the depressive forces of the mind. As a game, its puzzles are straightforward, simple. There are some creative puzzles at play, but nothing brilliantly clever. As a story, it's quite remarkable. The game melds visual design with its storytelling to perfectly capture the fear - the depravity - of a sick mind. In many ways, the visuals are used as a catalyst to enhance this sad, sad story. The experience is an onslaught of grizly proportions. If you have never experienced the depths of a macabre human mind, the game will, perhaps, give you perspective of what it's like living with no hope, no resolution. I'd definitely recommend this game, if you are looking for something unconventional, somthing emotional, something insightful.

content:
Posted: November 18, 2016
												This is a game that I just can't seem to let go of. I watched a playthrough of the game quite a few years before I got the opportunity to buy it. In the time between these two encounters, my interest didn't fade in the slightest.Every part of this game is well done. The plot is compelling, the art is gorgeous, the atmosphere really sinks into your being and the characters of Susan and Mitzi are so developed! And the game lasts quite a while, so you have plenty of time to enjoy it.I love that the enemies in this game are part human and part otherwordly monster. From the moment I saw the nurse and her husband, and nearly crapped myself because of them, I knew I had come across a real gem of a game.The 2D graphics work surprisingly well with the horror aspects. Tentatively moving forward and seeing what comes into frame feels like peering around corners for a terrifying bogeyman.The sounds are excellently selected, right down to the somewhat gruff voice of Ms. Ashworth. This is a game that knew what emotions it wanted to evoke and how to do it.I encountered a grand total of ONE issue with the game: when Susan is about to be hauled off by the nurse's husband (in the fog scene) the frame rate plummets. But even then, the five minute wait for the game to return to normal is well worth it.This is the gold standard of Indie gaming. It's absolute perfection.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2016
												I just played this game for 7.5 hours straight.  Wow...  just... wow.Completely immersive storyline, great art, spooky sounds, killer soundtrack.  I was hooked instantly.  Now the sun's up and I need to get some sleep!If you're a fan of old school games like Maniac Mansion (which a section of this game gives a BIG nod to, BTW), I Have No Mouth And I Must Scream, and other classic PC adventure titles, don't even hesitate to pick this up.I did have the occasional glitch, mostly involving strange slowdown occurrances (which I read you can alleviate with increasing the buffer size in the setup), controls getting messed up temporarily (sometimes I'd just rapidly twitch or smash the directional keys and the game didn't like it...), etc., but they didn't discourage me at all.I only had a few ACTUAL complaints.  First off, the voice acting is VERY inconsistant.  Some actors obviously recorded their lines in COMPLETELY different setups.  You'll hear crystal clear dialogue one second, then another actor will sound super compressed, 3 dB lower in volume, and loaded with plosives due to a lack of a pop screen.  Then the next line it may sound different again.  I'm a recording engineer (and also did voice work for a little game called Space Quest IV.5, which was also filled with inconsistent dialogue), so I may notice it a lot more than the casual player.The other complaint?  There's no way to skip dialogue or cut scenes.  I face-palmed every time I accidentally examined the dress in the last chapter and had to hear the whole speech on what it needed... again, and again, and again...But I digress.  This is a HEAVY story line with some REAL emotional impact.  Serious stuff that makes you question life and  your choices.  That's what makes you keep going, and I ran through it in one sitting!  I unlocked almost half of the achievements and got the "good" ending, so now I have to go back and get the other endings :)

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												The Cat Lady's plot is best experienced alongside the atmosphere of the game so I won't write a long-drawn out review that glosses over it and I'll cut straight to the point:It's hard to find a game so atmospheric as this one and one that affected me so much. The disturbing aspects weren't played to hyperbole and still retained genuine shock value that very few other games can create. Alongside that, I found the most believable and human relationships in a video game from the friendship you see between the protagonists. The Cat Lady is best described as a psychological adventure/horror and while there is no actual pointing and clicking involved it comes very close to a point-and-click game. Though there are a few puzzles here and there, they're nothing too difficult or are they ones that require a good chunk of your time to sit and think about before solving. This creates a near-perfect set up for leaving you with minimal frustrations and distractions to take away your experience of this truly disturbing game that is character-driven and poignant to the very end. Pros:+Well-worth the price for the amount of hours a typical playthrough can take + the multiple endings and dialogue options +Artwork is unique and immersive when combined+Simple controls +Character-driven +Puzzle difficulty is varying but it never gets too hard or easy and presents a moderate challenge to players+Disturbing without having to delve into too many cliches of horror/thriller+When the voice acting is good, IT'S GOOD. All accents can be understood and are variedCons:-Backtracking in some areas can become particularly annoying and very few hints are given-Jump-scares, although in third-person and won't make anybody fly out of their seat, are frequent within the first few chapters and played with a chord that takes away from all subtlety to the point of annoyance-When the voice acting is bad, it becomes painful to listen to and cringe-worthy-Music is BAD and repetitive and the sounds are hollow and in low qualityI recommend this game for anyone who can take a bit of gore and disturbing element, and anyone who is tired of bad plots and unbelievable characters and wanting something /more/ from their indie adventure games.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 18, 2016
												Incredible game, honestly. It's rare you find such a good quality indie horror; I'd use this as a basis of what makes a good indie horror game even. It's unique whilst being low-requirement at the same time in terms of computer specifications. There are a few bugs, but they are literally minor things and I've only been inconvenienced once at the very start of the game /spoiler-but-not-really/ when removing the knife from the deers body, if you press the activate button twice the game will crash.There's evidence of low quality voice acting, but honestly I couldn't care less.In terms of horror even, it's not that scary, but it has a wonderful dark atmosphere and that's really what I refer to. It stays spooky, suspenseful and mysterious and all-that without resorting to jump-scares or paranoia of such. Although it touches on some dark themes such as domestic abuse/sexual assault and predominantly suicide, it's not done in a "shock factor" way and honestly paves the storyline wellStill leaves SO many questions open: Creates more questions than it answers. But that really just makes me want to play more.9/10; would give a full 10/10 but even I have to admmit the voice acting at times can really grate on me. Anne Burton's mic is the true parasite...

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 23, 2015
												This is my first review. My 4th steam game, and the only one I'm happy about buying from steam. I hate steam. I still hate steam...but if I get more experiences like this then maybe I will like steam someday. Maybe..It took 20 minutes to download....compared to the usual 4-6 hours.It was actually playable and working after it downloaded...first game on steam where i just press play and the game works.Its the first single player game I've played in a LONGGG TIME where I wasn't bored out of my mind. I got drawn in after about 10 minutes of playing....which is unheard of for me. I always play multiplayer games cause im always lonely for company. I always feel like im not really playing until I play with other people...so i always avoid single player games. and often am bored of single player experiences right at the start to the end.THis game gives me hope for future single player experiences. It's got a lower fixed resolution but it makes some truly gorgeous environments and scenery. There are plenty of times you don't'even notice the low resolution which is amazing. I'm not gonnna recommend something that looks ugly or is hard on the eyes. infact i hate low rez indie games that use giant blocky pixels....its too hard to see anyhting other than basic objects. This is game tho, is easy  on the eyes and pretty to look at. If you are put off by some of the screenshots, don't be. It only takes a few minutes to get used to. its one of the few games where many of the environments are interesting to just sit back and look at. You can see all the detail put into these environment....and i spent quite a bit of time admiring some of the objects and detailed stuff in many areas.Bad stuff? no options menu really, can't rebind keys....which is annoying given you are pressing enter and using the arrow keys all the time...its also weird cause other keys will copy some keys....but it never tells u this in teh tutorial. it just says arrow keys and enter...but you can also use space bar to skip scenes or asdw as well but these werent mentioned in the brief tutorial as i said. Also:  The first thing you see after pressing play is a really choppy ugly video showing the company/developer logo.I'm just having a blast with this game, not done yet and hope it keeps on going forever. I'm ready to buy more of this and i've only just played today. I wanna get back to playing it soon.....rly rly fun and full of surprises.  I'm just so happy and amazed by the amount of depth put into the environments and story so far. I feel like my choices in the dialogue, environments, and story in general really matter and are making a considerable difference in how the story goes.  The puzzles are also very challenging, and it is a welcomed challenege. I'll admit I had to go to a guide to figure out 2 of the puzzle components which happened to be back to back (spent alot of time trying to figure out on my own but failed). I figured out many difficult ones though and I'm always proud of myself afterwards. It doesn't hold your hand and explain how to do things....its very old school and makes you think really hard and outside the norm. even though i had to resort to a guide for a puzzle i got completely stumped by, its a totally welcomed challenge. I hope all the future puzzles are just as if not more challenging. I'm just having so much fun. SUpport these types of games and give me recommendations for more like this! The telltale games....the ones I've played..... pale in comparison to this game. They are just on totally different levels.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 20, 2016
												I remember reading about this game and it had just happened to be on sale at the time i believe. Even though i dont rely on personal / critic reviews, they sometimes help give me that extra nudge to buy. Well.... now from personal experience i can tell everyone thats reading this that i could not have been happier!!!  I absolutely fell in love with this game from the very start, to the credits. The story was one of the most unique experiences ive had in a while with a game "but in a really good way"   I highly recommend this game!Story - 10/10Music - 10/10   "my personal favorite part of the game"Gameplay - 9/10   "let me say one thing. if you dont care about amazing graphics, nor care about side scrollers, then you will be satisfied!!  Personally i love Harvester's artwork in this game. Another unique part of this game"Characters - 10/10   "You really end up connecting with the characters in the game which of course makes games so much more interesting"Game Length - Not gonna rate this but i do wish the game wouldve been longer.  Not that this a ridiculously SHORT game, i just wish there wouldve been a few more episodes at least...  but oh well.  I still stand by my point that this game was very very well worth buying. I think its normal price is $10 and knowing what i know now about this game id have payed that amount for it for sure.  Replay Value - Obviously none since its a pure story driven / psychological horror game and once you've beaten the game theres no point to play it again, unless its for the achievements which is what i did to 100% it.Overall - Great game.  Highly recommend everyone to experience this "imo" masterpiece of a game. Also forgot to mention this game will make you use your brain as well, almost exactly like Silent Hill soooo, why wouldnt you buy it right this second after topping my review off with that!!!    I hope this review was helpful to everyone who reads it and if you decide to buy this game I hope you have fun playing!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												I must preface this review with a note, this game was not quite what I thought it would be. A friend of mine gifted the game to me as I had wishlisted it based on a recommendation (and the name got me)Now, on to the review.The Cat Lady is a dark and suspenseful ride down the river of depression. As someone who has experienced depression intimately, it was quite the surreal experience. The art and interface was a surprise, but I got past it due to such an amazing and thoughtful story. I managed to play the game blindly and beat the game in about 8 hours. I did not end up getting the "perfect" ending, and for that I would need to play through the game again. The funny thing is, I really don't mind playing the whole thing over again.The game has a lot of dark overtones, course language, and gore. It deals with a lot of serious subject matter such as death, suicide, murder, and the loss of loved ones. If you can handle all that, I cannot recommend the game enough. It is a wonderful macabre tale of sorrow and suspense that must be experineced.

												So.... I`ve played this Game one minute ago. And I`m ... stunned. I got not much negative to say about this creation. The art-style is a bit stuttering, but this doesn`t bother me I think it`s a harmonious combination between art and storytelling. So the drawing style fits perfect in the whole concept. The game is less about horror and it tells more a deep, emotional story which is authentic to the feelings we all went through in our lives, some of us more than other. I my opinion the story is a lyric parable to things we are facing on our way in live. I see it specific in the parasites. On the other hand the game got a guiding principle. Particularly people with similar problems are more attached to the themes. So the game got a methascore 81/100. In my opinien this isn t enough, I see the reasons why some points had to be taken, but never 19 Points. I would give this game 91/100.

You can never guess what is going to happen next ...If you are into things like Twin Peaks, or Salad Fingers, to mention just some random "psychologically" intriguing stuff, this will be your kind of game ... Voice acting is kind of amateurish sometimes, but who cares (obviously they didn't use professional mics and/or did their recordings in somebody's living room). Plus sometimes the game is lagging a bit, but again, who cares. And don't forget to play Downfall as well!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 18, 2016
												This is a game that I just can't seem to let go of. I watched a playthrough of the game quite a few years before I got the opportunity to buy it. In the time between these two encounters, my interest didn't fade in the slightest.Every part of this game is well done. The plot is compelling, the art is gorgeous, the atmosphere really sinks into your being and the characters of Susan and Mitzi are so developed! And the game lasts quite a while, so you have plenty of time to enjoy it.I love that the enemies in this game are part human and part otherwordly monster. From the moment I saw the nurse and her husband, and nearly crapped myself because of them, I knew I had come across a real gem of a game.The 2D graphics work surprisingly well with the horror aspects. Tentatively moving forward and seeing what comes into frame feels like peering around corners for a terrifying bogeyman.The sounds are excellently selected, right down to the somewhat gruff voice of Ms. Ashworth. This is a game that knew what emotions it wanted to evoke and how to do it.I encountered a grand total of ONE issue with the game: when Susan is about to be hauled off by the nurse's husband (in the fog scene) the frame rate plummets. But even then, the five minute wait for the game to return to normal is well worth it.This is the gold standard of Indie gaming. It's absolute perfection.

I got stuck maybe 3 or 4 times throughout my 8 hour journey and had to look up a few things, however the ones I struggled through and figured out on my own were incredibly rewarding. Also the sound track is awesome. Check it out.

The only negatives for me were the fact that the game is controlled by keyboard only and the walking speed of the character gets a bit slow at times. I also found myself wishing that i could skip some of the dialogue during certain parts of the game. Overall though, those things weren't enough to detract significantly from the experience.8/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 8, 2016
												!Thematic spoilers!Although many other things have explored depression through horror before, The Cat Lady's take on this theme is unique in its execution. The adventure game style directly gives not only the player but the *character* agency in solving the games problems. Although the story illustrates how depression kills motivation, interest, and hope, in playing the game the player is helping Susan to fight back against her illness. In addition to this, I particularly like the character chosen to explore these issues, as the depression of single, middle-aged women is not the sort of thing one would expect to find in a video game unless it was used as the backstory for a villain. Although the game does at times fall into this trope slightly-- there are certainly mentally ill characters who are presented as villains *because* they are mentally ill --there is also a sense that these characters are there as warnings to Susan, which helps keep the story from sending totally mixed messages. That said, people who struggle with mental illnesses, particularly depression and suicidal ideation, may have some trouble getting through this game, as it can definitely hit very close to home.

I have to do it twice though because...a certain thing didn't happen at the end. Its kind of like having read the book and then watching a movie version come out. And its an amazing movie that I could relate to at times.Its a shame that there's achievements because that can get into the way of delving into the story but again, its good.PS: I have more cats than her.PSS: Too bad Konami can't learn from this.PSSS: Capcom too. Well maybe with the new RE.

Posted: January 24
												Disturbing. Deep. Beautiful but haunting.You're playing as Susan, a 40 year old suicidal jobless woman living somewhere in England, who upon attempting to kill herself is given another chance by a myserious entity: she's made immortal until she gets rid of 5 very bad people she will encounter. It really thrusts you into a semblance of what derelict poverty is like in the first world. You ncan understand and sympathize why she has chronic depression, why she's lonely and why she commits suicide.This is not "horror" per se. It's a scary, disturbing side scrolling novella that i only recommend if you are looking to explore very dark themes.

												Admittedly, I wasn't expecting much when I got the game. The story seemed interesting, but I didn't think it'd pan out. I was wrong, the first chapter wasn't my favorite, but it gets much better afterwards. The back stories are wonderful, and the multiple endings are worthwhile.This game really got me into indie games, and it's been challenging to find games I enjoy as much as this one. If they ever make anything related to this game, I am getting it. The writing is wonderful!Pros: -Well written story and dialogue-Choices affect story line, so multiple playthroughs are necesary-Simple puzzles make it active, so you're not just reading a story-While you can complete the game in a day (Think it was 6-8 hours per playthrough), it's not as stort as other indie games.-Art and music were enjoyableCons:-First chapter made this game seem like a gore-fest for kicks, but if you give it a chance it's worthwhile-Some of the puzzles aren't straight-forward, use a walkthrough if you get stuck-One glitchy area, when you are outside in the fog she walks very slow, but once you're past the cut scene it's fine.
